oai_dc:dc.dc:title: | a khumm called by a lion

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: ... a cunning woman of this race, who lived alone in a house underground, deceived and robbed /kwámmana . This was told in the Katkop dialect by !kwéiten ta //kën (L VI.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Story of |kua ka khumm

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: Words and sentences relating to sounds and music, given by !kweiten ta ||ken.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Words and sentences: by !kweiten ta ||ken

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: The story of the Great Water Tortoise, who deceived men belonging to the early race of Bushman by feigning illness (told by !kwéiten ta //ken), appears to be a variation of the above
mentioned myth (L VI.
4063). Testudo pardalis
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The story of the Leopard Tortoise

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: .. A man cut his wife open, because he believed that she had been greedy, and then discovering, with great distress, that she was with child, tries in vain to repair the harm he had done, by pinning her together with a stick, thinking that she would live (L VI.-2. 4064-4070).
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: What the man did to his wife when she was pregnant
Covers and first pages of Lloyd's Book V
3 or BC151_A2_1_052

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: Names and descriptions of nets, bags and things worn, found on an insert in the notebook.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Names and descriptions of bags, nets and things worn

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: To this myth [ ] belongs also the account of the reasons for the colours of the gemsbok, hartebeest, eland, quagga, and springbok, given in the Katkop dialect by Día!kwãin (L V.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The reasons for the colours of the gemsbok, the hartebeest, the eland, the quagga, and the springbok

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: An account of rain
making by means of dragging a water

animal over the land, in illustration of a Bushman painting copied by Mr J.M. Orpen ( for July, 1874, frontispiece), was given, in the Katkop dialect, by Dia!kwãin, who had it from his mother (BXXVII. 2540
2608). The beginning of this was repeated by him (L V.
4085), and two other accounts of rain
making were also given by him (L V.
4121). !giten
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Rainmaking (a version by Dia!kwain)

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: An account of rain
making by means of dragging a water

animal over the land, in illustration of a Bushman painting copied by Mr J.M. Orpen ( for July, 1874, frontispiece), was given, in the Katkop dialect, by Dia!kwãin, who had it from his mother (BXXVII. 2540
2608). The beginning of this was repeated by him (L V.
4085), and two other accounts of rain
making were also given by him (L V.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: What happened when the thong (with which they were pulling at the Water's Bull) broke or Kko
kkoro's story

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: An account of rain
making by means of dragging a water

animal over the land, in illustration of a Bushman painting copied by Mr J.M. Orpen ( for July, 1874, frontispiece), was given, in the Katkop dialect, by Dia!kwãin, who had it from his mother (BXXVII. 2540
2608, the two first pages only translated). The beginning of this was repeated by him (L V.
4085), and two other accounts of rain
making were also given by him (L V.
4121). !giten
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: A Rain story

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: The Bushman Doctor or Sorcerer (L II.
275). An account of these people was also given in the Katkop dialect by Dia!kwáin (L V.
4131), from whom we besides have two reports of cures performed upon himself. The first of these (L V.
4199) includes a speech made by the sorceress; the second relates how she cured him when injured by a Kafir (L V.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: About sorcerers

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: The Bushman Doctor or Sorcerer (L II.-1. 273-275). An account of these people was also given in the Katkop dialect by Dia!kwáin (L V.-3. 4122-4131), from whom we besides have two reports of cures performed upon himself. The first of these (L V.-3. 4132-4161, 4. 4162-4199) includes a speech made by the sorceress; the second relates how she cured him when injured by a Kafir (L V.-4. 4200-4230).

The healer (or !gixa) !kwarra-an heals ('snores') Dia!kwain. Afterwards she tells his mother all about her work and complains about her treatment by the people. The healer does not wish to do good work because she is angry that the people do not pay her. There are additional notes about 'sneezing' (|kamma) and what comes out afterwards.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The tale of a wise person or sorceress, what she said, when she talked with us

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: The Bushman Doctor or Sorcerer (L II.-1. 273-275). An account of these people was also given in the Katkop dialect by Dia!kwáin (L V.-3. 4122-4131), from whom we besides have two reports of cures performed upon himself. The first of these (L V.-3. 4132-4161, 4. 4162-4199) includes a speech made by the sorceress; the second relates how she cured him when injured by a Kafir (L V.-4. 4200-4230).

A note about the old sorceress !kwarra-an, where she lived and lives, her Dutch name (Mietje); how her husband ≠gerri-sse (or Jan Ronebout) and a son were shot by a Dutch man ('Boer') when out getting poison for their arrows.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: About the sorceress !kwarra
an
Covers and first pages of Lloyd's Book V
4 or BC151_A2_1_053

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: The Bushman Doctor or Sorcerer (L II-1. 273-275). An account of these people was also given in the Katkop dialect by Dia!kwáin (L V.-3. 4122-4131), from whom we besides have two reports of cures performed upon himself. The first of these (L V.-3. 4132-4161, 4. 4162-4199) includes a speech made by the sorceress; the second relates how she cured him when injured by a Kafir (L V.-4. 4200-4230).

A black man attempts to take Dia!kwain's mother's iron spoons (left to her by her dead husband) and has harmed her family in other ways (the same man poisoned Dia!kwain's aunt). Dia!kwain fights him and afterwards his throat is sore and swollen from the fight. His worried mother asks an old healer (!kwarra-an) to 'snore' him.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The story of a sorceress; that which she did when the Kafir had hurt my throat, she 'snored' me, when my throat was swollen

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: The 'Jackal’s Tower' still visible as a 'spitzkop' on the other side of the Zak River gives rise to a 'Jackal and Hyena' fable, told to Dia!kwãin by his mother ≠kámme–an (L V.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: How the Jackal deceived the Hyena
Covers and first pages of Lloyd's Book V
5 or BC151_A2_1_054

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: The vicious Water–tortoise and the charitable Ratel (Mellivora), a fable related to Dia!kwãin, by his mother (L V.
4291). aterskilpad
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Mellivora
The story of the Ratel (or ) and the Waterskilpad

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: The vicious Water–tortoise and the charitable Ratel (Mellivora), a fable related to Dia!kwãin, by his mother (L V.-5. 4265-4291).
The Ratel used to be a man.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Mellivora
A further explanation of the ratel (or ): why it is like a man

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: The Knorhaan (Brandkop) who married his sister. Told to Dia!kwãin by his mother (L V.-5. 4292-4320). Apparently a version of the fable imbedded in the Anteater’s Laws.

The Kwa-kkwara (or Koran Brandkop) pretends to be a child and cries and hides his 'grown-up things'. A girl carries him about and he sleeps with her. The girl's mother tells the girl's older brother who puts the Kwa-kkwara's head into the fire. Kwa-kkwara screams ('||kha! ||kha!') and darts out of the fire, revealing himself to be a grown-up man.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The story of the Kwa
kkwara

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: The Lion jealous of the voice of the Ostrich. In the Katkop dialect by Dia!kwãin, who heard it from his paternal grandfather, (L V.-5. 4320-4344).

The Lions wish to kill the Ostrich and eat its lungs whole and raw so that they can call in the same attractive way. One of the Lions fights the Ostrich but does not kill it at this time. Dia!kwain and the other children are advised by Dia!kwain's grandfather to swallow the Ostrich's lungs whole and raw so that their voices can be fine, like that of the Ostrich.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The story of the Lions and the Ostriches
Covers and first pages of Lloyd's Book V
6 or BC151_A2_1_055

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: The Anteater, and its handsome musical pet, the Lynx. Related to Dia!kwãin by his paternal grandmother Ttwóbboken !kauken (L V
4377). !kummi
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The story of the Lynx and the Anteater

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: Habits of the Bat and the Porcupine, etc. By Día!kwãin, from his parents (L V.-6. 4378-4403).
What Dia!kwain's parents told him about the bat and the porcupine who inhabit the same hole and go about together seeking food.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: A belief about the bat and the porcupine

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: Habits of the Bat and the Porcupine, etc. By Día!kwãin, from his parents (L V.-6. 4378-4403).
About the fine hearing of the porcupine and how the people hunting it must not make a noise or it will hear them.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: About the fine hearing of the porcupine

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: What Maidens (and young men) must not say or do, to avoid the wrath of the Water. By Dia!kwãin (L V.-6. 4377 rev.-4407 rev.).
Girls and youths and the rain: what they are taught and what they must do, eat and avoid.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Things girls and youths must avoid (the rain's things)

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: More about what Dia!kwain's parents instructed him about the porcupine; children should not eat the things that are at the back of the porcupine's neck.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: A note about the porcupine

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: Some Bushman children advised by their parents to be self-reliant in seeking food, in order to prepare themselves for the loss of their natural protectors. Related by Día!kwãin (L V.-6. 4404-4411 rev.-4413 rev.).
This advice includes the waiting and watching for porcupine and other teachings relating to 'great things'. This is 'not a little story', but a 'great story', and is the story of the porcupine.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Parents instruct children how to get food, or, How D.H's father and mother instructed their children to get food

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: An account of the magic protection afforded by the Mantis to the Hartebeest and to the Eland (that to the latter being chiefly described here), dictated, in the Katkop dialect, by Día!kwãin (L V.-6. 4411-4434).
If a man has shot an eland he must perform certain actions to ensure that |kaggen (the Mantis) doesn't come to them or that the eland doesn't get up and run off.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The hartebeest and the eland belong to the Mantis

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: Some remarkable superstitions concerning the Hartebeest, whose head is said to resemble that of the Mantis; and also a curious charm made from the foot of the Hartebeest, and used by Bushman women for their children as a protection against the Mantis (L V.-6. 4414 rev.-4418 rev.).
The hartebeest's head resembles that of |kaggen (the Mantis), so it feels itself to be 'Mantis's thing'.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The hartebeest resembles the Mantis

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: Some remarkable superstitions concerning the Hartebeest, whose head is said to resemble that of the Mantis; and also a curious charm made from the foot of the Hartebeest, and used by Bushman women for their children as a protection against the Mantis (L V.
4418 rev.). None
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: A mother's prohibitions with regard to the hartebeest and her child

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: Words in the Katkop dialect, from #kásin (B XXV. 2355-2360), from !kwéiten ta //ken (L VI.-1. 3882, 3859-3897), and from Dia!kwãin (L V.-6. 4434 and 4435, 8. 4615 rev., 9. 4653 rev., etc.)
. A list of |xam names for parts of the body, including the 'great throat artery', head and neck bones, and sinews.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Words and sentences: parts of the body
Covers and first pages of Lloyd's Book V
7 or BC151_A2_1_056

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: Hunting the Porcupine, its habits and faculties (L V.-7. 4436-4456).

The hunters sleep outside the porcupine's house so that it cannot smell them. The porcupine almost 'sees' with its nose, and the porcupine's eyes seem useless or 'sit for nothing' as it cannot see out of them.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Porcupine hunting: we go to sit waiting for a porcupine and some of the habits of the porcupine

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: The young man of the ancient race, who was carried off by a Lion, when asleep in the field. A very affecting legend, in the Katkop dialect, related to Dia!kwãin by his mother ≠kámme–an (L V.-7. 4457-4525).

The Lion places the young man in a tree and goes off to get water to drink. The Lion spies on the man and sees him move and decides to drink quickly and run back to eat him. The man springs from the tree and runs home where the people wrap him in hartebeest skins and mats and hide him in the house's 'bush-screen'. The Lion comes and the people shoot at it, but it is not harmed. Eventually the people tire of trying to kill the Lion and ask the man's mother to give her son to the Lion. As the Lion kills the man the people shoot and stab it and it dies.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The Lion and the man's story; what the Lion formerly did to the man or The young man of the Ancient Race, who was carried off by a Lion, when asleep in the field

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: The name of the Lion not to be spoken by children. In the Katkop dialect, by Día!kwãin, from ≠kámme-an (L V.-7. 4526 and 4526, 8. 4527-4562). Another version of this warning (L V.-8. 4563-4573).

The |xam avoid saying the lion's name so the flies cannot hear and report to the lion what they say; some of the lion's habits when killing game; what people must do when stealing game from a lion; they make signs or hand gestures to signify the lion instead of saying its name.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The avoidance of the name of the lion
Covers and first pages of Lloyd's Book V
8 or BC151_A2_1_057

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: The name of the Lion not to be spoken by children. In the Katkop dialect, by Día!kwãin, from ≠kámme-an (L V.-7. 4526 and 4526, 8. 4527-4562). Another version of this warning (L V.-8. 4563-4573).
Children must never disrespect the lion or 'play with its name', or it will remember and teach them a lesson when they are adults on the hunting-ground.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The children taught to use another name for the lion

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: A full-grown Bushman, whom the narrator knew, punished by a lion for having eaten forbidden portions of the lion’s prey, as a child. Told by Día!kwãin (L V.-8. 4574-4617 1/2, 9. 4618, with notes upon 4616 rev. and 4617 rev.).

|xam parents tell their children about what happened to Xwerri-kau, as a lesson about the eating of certain things: Xwerri-kau (who had eaten prohibited parts of game as a child) was pursuing a quagga when a lion sprang on him, and the quagga lay down to die once it saw that the lion had bitten him. This story illustrates how lions remember what children do and take revenge in various ways on the hunting ground when they are grown-ups. It also contains information about the hunting-ground.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: What the lion did to Xwerri
kau; and what parts of game should not be eaten by little children

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: A full-grown Bushman, whom the narrator knew, punished by a lion for having eaten forbidden portions of the lion’s prey, as a child. Told by Día!kwãin.(L V.-8. 4574-4617 1/2, 9. 4618, with notes upon 4616 rev. and 4617 rev.).
An account of how a lion dreams and how it has the ability to make things obey their will (they 'work things').
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The lion's dream
Covers and first pages of Lloyd's Book V
9 or BC151_A2_1_058

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: Springbok will lead people to a lion. Their knowledge of distant things gained by their fine scent. In the Katkop dialect, by Dia!kwãin, from his parents (L V.-9. 4619-4651).
Also, game knows the time of men's deaths, and as such their behaviour must be observed. The springbok tells people things if they understand its actions.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The springbok's story

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: note explaining the curious name of the son of a sorceress.(L V.-9. 4652 and 4651 rev.). The naming of the Bushman Ssu-!kui-ten-tta (or Snore-White-Lying or 'Witbooi').
[A] His mother 'snored' people without a kaross.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The explanation of the name Ssu
!kui
ten
tta (or Snore
White
Lying)

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: Death of the narrator’s first wife, which was foretold by springbok and gemsbok. By Dia!kwãin (L V.-9. 4653-4688).

An account of what the springbok did when Dia!kwain's first wife (Mietje) died. Ssu-!kui-ten-tta points out that he had told Dia!kwain that the actions of the game foretold what was happening at home.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: What the springbok and the gemsbok did when they knew that Dia!kwain's wife would die

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: note respecting sorcerers who assume the shape of birds or jackals, on p.4701 rev.).
[A]About '||khabbo's place' where sorcerers turn themselves into jackals if they want to kill people or birds, so as to fool people into thinking they are these animals.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: ||kabbo's place

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: The Owl and the Black Crow foretell the approach of the Lion. By Dia!kwãin (L V.-9. 4689-4706 1/2, 4696 rev., and 4697 rev.).
Parents teach that when the owl screams and acts a certain way it means a lion is coming to take them in their sleep. The black crow also warns of the coming of the lion.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The owl and the black crow
Covers and first pages of Lloyd's Book V
10 or BC151_A2_1_059

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: An old sorceress (a relative who befriended the narrator’s family), her power of turning herself into a lioness, her pet springbok, etc. By Dia!kwãin (L V.-10. 4707-4743).

Dia!kwain's aunt, the sorceress Ttanno !khauken, changes herself into a lioness to see what her people are doing and to take care of them. Dia!kwain's father kills her short-horned springbok, but she is not angry even though it is not a food springbok, but a tame one (it was her 'heart's springbok').
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The Bushman doctress and sorceress Ttanno !khauken

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: Remarks upon sorcerers, their dress, etc. (in explanation of one of Mr Stow’s copies of Bushmen paintings), by Dia!kwãin (L V.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Told in illustration of the picture of the dance of sorcerers (Mr Stow's number 8 and 9)

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: Explanation of various personal names was given, in the Katkop dialect, by Díä!kwãin (L V.-10. 4751-4754, 4758-4777, 18. 5373 rev., 19. 5505 rev. and 5506 rev., 20. 5572 and 5573, 5605-5607).

Dia!kwain's mother named his brother Ko-bbo because the people at their place blamed her family for all the misfortunes that occurred there. They called Dia!kwain's people 'Bbo' and threatened them. These same people killed Dia!kwain's grandmother and grandfather 'with sorcery' and intended to kill the rest of his family as well.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Why Dia!kwain's brother Ko
bbo received his name

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: More about the great sorceress Ttanno !kauken who did not understand Dutch: the parents taught the children to respect the great sorceress in many ways.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: A great Bushman doctress and sorceress Ttanno !khauken who did not understand Dutch

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: Names and information about Dia!kwain's brothers and sisters.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: About Dia!kwain's relations

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: Explanation of various personal names was given, in the Katkop dialect, by Díä!kwãin (L V.-10. 4751-4754, 4758-4777, 18. 5373 rev., 19. 5505 rev. and 5506 rev., 20. 5572 and 5573, 5605-5607).
!kweiten ta ||ken is an 'orphan's name'.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Why !kweiten ta ||ken received her name

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: The preparation of tinder. In the Katkop dialect, by Díä!kwãin (L V.10. 4761 rev.4764 rev., note). Tinder–making, by |han≠kass’o (L VIII.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The preparation of tinder from a certain thorn tree

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: kao ≠oro
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The making of a needle from a springbok's foreleg

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: Explanation of various personal names was given, in the Katkop dialect, by Díä!kwãin (L V.-10. 4751-4754, 4758-4777, 18. 5373 rev., 19. 5505 rev. and 5506 rev., 20. 5572 and 5573, 5605-5607).
The reason for the naming of Dia!kwain's uncle, |kai kwa.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Why Dia!kwain's uncle |kai kwa received his name

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: The power over ostriches possessed by /uhérre (maternal uncle of Díä!kwãin). This is followed by a long discourse concerning successful and unsuccessful hunting, as well as by a prayer, addressed by the mother of the narrator to the dead, that her husband’s hunting might prove more fortunate. The result of this prayer is described. Allusion is also made to the belief that unsuccessful hunting may forebode danger to the hunter. In the Katkop dialect, by Díä!kwãin (L V.-10. 4778-4795-4868).

Dia!kwain's uncle |uherre had in the past asked his spirit ancestors to give the people bad luck with the game because they had abused him. A man says that |uherre made an ostrich come to him, but complains that it is a lean bird. An old woman warns him that magicians first send lean, old and ugly things to test them. The people must eat the lean ostrich, after which fat ones will be sent to them. Dia!kwain's mother (and other women) beat the digging stone on the ground to pray to the spirit-people. The story moves on to a more general narrative about game-sorcerers and spirit-people.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The power over ostriches possessed by Dia!kwain's uncle, |uherre or 'Blaitje'

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: The names for August and September were given by Díä!kwãin, by whom it was also stated that the names for all the months are known to the old people. In the Katkop dialect (L V.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Moons' (months) possess their names
Covers and first pages of Lloyd's Book V
11 or BC151_A2_1_060

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: Dia!kwain's elder sister, |a
kkumm, comes upon an owl as she journeys from !kau
|nunu (Kenhardt) at sunset, and it behaves as if it is going to snatch her. When it leaves she is afraid because her mother had told her that when an owl leaves at sunset a beast of prey is near.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: How an owl (by its conduct) made |a
kkumm think that danger must be at hand and how she was sought for by a lion, which spoke to her in a man's voice

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: The power of Game Sorcerers continues after death. Prayer addressed to them by the mother of narrator. (L V.-11. 4801 rev.-4809 rev.).

Dia!kwain's mother tells of spirit-people who are dead game's sorcerers. The people do not see them but their sorcery is still around and they do not altogether die. There follows her prayer to the spirits of the sorcerers who formerly possessed game.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: |nu
!ke or magicians who have died still possess power, and ≠kamme
an's prayer to them

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: The Lion. Power over the time of sunset, and over the water–skins of the Bushmen, possessed by him. Flies tell him that a Bushman intends to fetch water, to-day. Caution in fetching water is recommended. In the Katkop dialect, by Díä!kwãin (L V.-11. 4869 rev.-4879 rev.).

Dia!kwain's mother tells of lions and their doings when they want to catch and eat people. They make the sun set quickly to catch people out in the veld away from home and they make the waterskin tear .
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Avoidance behaviour relating to lions
Covers and first pages of Lloyd's Book V
12 or BC151_A2_1_061

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: The lion made the rain in order to confuse the man so he wouldn't know where his house was and the lion could catch him. The lion made it rain and waited in a cave for the man who sought refuge there.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The man who sought refuge from the rain in a cave, and found a lion there before him

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: Dia!kwain's cousin, Ttai tchuen, escapes from a lioness by remembering all the things her parents taught her about the doings of lions. She acts fearlessly and shines a button at the lioness to dazzle her and twirls around to scare her out of the den. Ttai tchuen leaves her mat behind so that the lioness will think it is her.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The adventure of a girl, named Ttai
tchuen, with a lioness who had young cubs
Covers and first pages of Lloyd's Book V
13 or BC151_A2_1_062

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: The Maiden who would not listen to her parents, and was punished, together with those around her, by the angry Rain. In the Katkop dialect, by Díä!kwãin (L V.-13. 4981-5022).

A story about the Early Race (the !khwe ||na ss'e !k'e) and the Rain, when the Porcupine was a man and how it came by the quills on its back and neck. The Porcupine's sister is a new maiden and behaves disobediently, and the Rain becomes angry and kills with lightning because it feels the girl does not protect the people. The brother must address the angry Rain in an effort to direct it to a different place. The new maiden is caught in a storm, even though she had been told not to go out. She is taken up by a whirlwind and becomes a snake.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The maiden who was taken up in a whirlwind by the agency of the angry Rain and became a great snake

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: The Young man (of the early race) who was changed into a porcupine. He is said to be the brother of the girl in the preceding legend. Remarks regarding the porcupine follow. In the Katkop dialect, by Díä!kwãin (L V.-13. 5023-5039, and 14. 5040-5054).

A tale of the Early Race (or !khwe ||na ss'e !k'e) in which the brother of the maiden taken up in a whirlwind by the angry Rain is transformed into a Porcupine. Parents tell their children to avoid eating the back of the porcupine's neck and tail, because that is where the hail sits. Also about porcupines and the stars.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: How the brother of the maiden taken up in a whirlwind became the Porcupine; followed by various remarks about porcupines
Covers and first pages of Lloyd's Book V
14 or BC151_A2_1_063

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: The form of a jackal, or of a little bird, is sometimes assumed by friendly sorcerers.In the Katkop dialect, by Díä!kwãin (L V.-14. 5055-5078 1/2

). Sorcerers transform themselves into jackals and birds when they want to watch over their people who have moved away and whom they have loved. Wise people can tell when a bird is a sorcerer and tell him all is well.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: How sorcerers sometimes assume the form of a jackal or of a bird; how they then act

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: A dead Sorcerer, name !nuin|kúïten, asked by the narrator’s father for rain; which speedily came. In the Katkop dialect, by Díä!kwãin (L V.-14. 5068rev.-5078-rev.).
Dia!kwain's father, Xaa-ttin, prays to his ancestor, the dead rainmaker !nuin-|kui-ten, for rain.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: How Xaa
ttin asked (or prayed to) the dead magician (named !nuin
|kui
ten) for rain, which was speedily bestowed
Covers and first pages of Lloyd's Book V
15 or BC151_A2_1_064

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: The sorcerer !nuin|kúïten. In the Katkop dialect, by Díä!kwãin (L V.-15. 5079-5101, 5104-5109).
The sorcerer !nuin-|kui-ten becomes a lion and goes about just to look at people, not to hunt them. !nuin-|kui-ten teaches Dia!kwain's father his magic because he feels that he is about to die.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: !nuin
|kui
ten (who was a sorcerer or magician)

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: The sorcerer !nuin|kúïten. In the Katkop dialect, by Díä!kwãin (L V.-15. 5079-5101, 5104-5109).
A song sung by Xaa-ttin (Dia!kwain's father) after the death of the magician !nuin-|kui-ten.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The broken string

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: The sorcerer !nuin|kúïten. In the Katkop dialect, by Díä!kwãin (L V.-15. 5079-5101, 5104-5109).
A song that Dia!kwain's father Xaa-ttin used to sing: when he used to sleep he would hear a person calling him (the sorcerer !nuin-|kui-ten).
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: What Xaa
ttin used to sing (the broken string)

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: The dream of Díä!kwãin, before he received news of his father’s death. Further omens, etc. In the Katkop dialect by Díä!kwãin (L V.-15. 5110-5146).

Dia!kwain dreams that he and his father are cutting up a sheep and a Dutch man ('Boer') threatens to beat them to death for killing the sheep. Dia!kwain awakes at daybreak and tells his wife that the dream had spoken like a person, of things that would come true. Dia!kwain's mother comes to tell him his father has died.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The dream which Dia!kwain had before he received the tidings of the death of his father

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: The relations of wind, moon, and cloud to human beings after death, etc. (L V.-15. 5147-5158).
What happens when the |xam die.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: What happens when we die

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: The shade not to be sat in, unless it is really summer. In the Katkop dialect, by Díä!kwãin (L V.-15. 5149 rev. and 5150 rev.).
Dia!kwain's mother told him what happens if one sits in the shade when the weather is not very hot.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Sitting in the shade

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: A version of the Moon and Hare story (which treats of the Origin of Death), preceded by a prayer, addressed to the young Moon. In the Katkop dialect, by Díä!kwãin (L V.-15. 5159-5168 1/2, 16. 5169-5198).
A prayer to the new Moon and an account of the origin of death.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: A prayer addressed to the Moon, and another version of the Moon and Hare story

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: Mode of getting rid of the evil influence of bad dreams. In the Katkop dialect, by Díä!kwãin (L V.-15. 5160 rev.-5163 rev.).
What Dia!kwain's mother did when she wished to get rid of the evil influence of bad dreams.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: How to get rid of the evil influence of bad dreams
Covers and first pages of Lloyd's Book V
16 or BC151_A2_1_065

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: The near approach of a 'Commando' is heralded by a mist. In the Katkop dialect, by Díä!kwãin (L V.-16. 5199-5205).
The |xam can tell when a commando is coming to attack them by the mist that comes in the morning.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: How the approach of a commando is foretold by the mist

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: About the Moon and death; good and bad moons; the stars also know things the people do not understand and the Moon sees things that will come to pass; if it is looked at, the Moon can allow game to live, even if the game has been poisoned or shot.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The Moon

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: !ka !karro !ka !karro
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: !ka !karro
A small insect called , said to resemble the Moon, used by Bushmen women to ascertain if the men will bring food home

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: The coming of different kinds of moths to the fire at night foretells the killing of certain types of game. The moths resemble different types of game.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Moths coming to the fire of Bushmen by night foretell the killing of certain kinds of game

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: The |kaggen (or the mantis) that sits on the hunter's quiver foretells that the owner has successfully shot and killed a hartebeest on the hunting

ground. If the hunter's wife kills or drives away the |kaggen the hartebeest will recover and live because it, as well as the |kaggen, has not been respected. The game must be respected in order to kill it successfully.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The coming of the Mantis [the mantis] to sit upon the quiver of the Bushman father at home foretells the shooting of a hartebeest
Covers and first pages of Lloyd's Book V
17 or BC151_A2_1_066

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: rooi klip

A series of six inserts on the inside cover of Book V-17 which contain brief references to falling stars, earthquakes and sorcerers, as well as some |xam names for certain animals. Reference is also made to the 'speech' of ants and there are a few lines about a 'tiger'. Most significantly, there is a note on drawings made by Dia!kwain's father on rocks and ostrich skins and the preparation of painting substances, such as (or red haematite).
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Words and sentences (and Dia!kwain's father's drawings)

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: About the hunting of game and the eating of flesh of certain game beforehand, such as eating slow
moving rather than fast game when going off to hunt.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: !nanna-sse
(hunting observances)

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: The hunting of eland and related ceremonies. There are many things the hunter must do to show respect for the eland, as it is a 'magic thing' and |kaggen (the Mantis) will try to revive the game and keep it from dying. The verso notes contain further details of these practices. Pages 5359v
5361v contains warnings about the casting of shadows (translated by Dorothea Bleek).
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Ssa ka Kumm
(the eland's story)

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: What the |kaggen (Mantis) does to see whether the people respect the eland.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The Mantis and the hunting of eland
Covers and first pages of Lloyd's Book V
18 or BC151_A2_1_067

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: More ceremonies performed when cutting up eland, as it is a 'magic thing'.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Further ceremonies in cutting up eland

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: Explanation of various personal names was given, in the Katkop dialect, by Díä!kwãin (L V.-10. 4751-4754, 4758-4777, 18. 5373 rev., 19. 5505 rev. and 5506 rev., 20. 5572 and 5573, 5605-5607).
Accounting for Dia!kwain's mother's 'little' name, which was |ko-an.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Dia!kwain explains his mother's 'little name'

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: !num !num Aloa amasis
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: !num-!num
About a moth called by the Bushmen and said to pour lice upon them

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: Successful Ostrich hunting foretold by the coming of a moth (Celœna renisigma, Walker). In the Katkop dialect, by Díä!kwãin (L V.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: |goro
A Bushman belief about a moth called , the coming of which to the fire at night foretells the slaying of an ostrich (or the finding of ostrich eggs) by one of the men

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: A new maiden secretly eats the marrow from inside the ostrich's thigh
bone, although she is not supposed to.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The new maiden who ate the ostrich marrow from the thigh
bone of the ostrich without the knowledge of her people

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: A man called Gemsbok Leg, or !kwai
!kwa, goes hunting with a companion and they pursue a leopard that seems to disappear, but it has deceived them and is lying in wait. It kills !kwai
!kwa before he can warn his companion, who is also attacked.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Leopard hunting: the fatal adventure of !kwai
!kwa and his companion, and advice about leopard
hunting
Covers and first pages of Lloyd's Book V
19 or BC151_A2_1_068

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: Names of three Bushmen and another Native, who were at the Breakwater Convict Station in 1875, together with a little information regarding them. Taken down in English (L V.-19. 5445-5447, 5453-5456).

≠gerri-sse (Jan Ronebout) provides Lloyd with some personal details and the names of his closest relations (his mother, father and older brother Hendrik, who was also imprisoned at the Breakwater Convict Station). ≠gerri-sse's mother (!kwarra-an) was from ||kabbo's country and 'understood greatly'.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Jan Ronebout or ≠gerri
sse (at Breakwater and later at Mowbray)

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: Names of three Bushmen and another Native, who were at the Breakwater Convict Station in 1875, together with a little information regarding them. Taken down in English (L V.-19. 5445–5447, 5453-5456).

Jan Plat provides Lloyd with some personal details and the names of some of his closest relations, including his wife and parents. He was related to Dia!kwain (his wife was Dia!kwain's niece), grew up with Dutch people ('Boers') and understood |xam well.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Jan Plat (at Breakwater; looked over later at Mowbray)

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: Names of three Bushmen and another Native, who were at the Breakwater Convict Station in 1875, together with a little information regarding them. Taken down in English (L V.-19. 5445-5447, 5453-5456).
≠enn (Klaas Paai) provides Lloyd with some personal details and the names of some of his closest relations, including his wife and parents.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Klaas Paai or ≠enn (at Breakwater)

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: Inquiry regarding name and dwelling–place. In the Katkop dialect, by Díä!kwãin (L V.-19. 5448-5452).
Dia!kwain longs to hear the words of his own language.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Thy name which is a Bushman name, what is it?'

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: Names of three Bushmen and another Native, who were at the Breakwater Convict Station in 1875, together with a little information regarding them. Taken down in English (L V.-19. 5445-5447, 5453-5456).

Hendrik Ronebout (patient convict number 7910) provided these details of personal information while at the Breakwater hospital. He gave the names of his parents as well as details of where he came from.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Hendrik (Ronebout) at Breakwater hospital

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: Dia!kwain's grandfather (!xugen
ddi) told him that game was once tame. The game acted as oxen do and allowed the people to stroke them, but a person called Chaser
of

food was in the habit of stroking the Quagga and then beating it, making it run away. Dia!kwain's grandfather was in the habit of frightening and beating away the game because he did not want the animals to stand still and be killed.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Game once tame: why it grew wild

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: Falling Stars. Certain ceremonies in connection with them. In the Katkop dialect, by Díä!kwãin (L V.-19. 5478-5483, 5481 rev.,-5483 rev., note). At the death of a sorcerer, his heart falls (as a shooting star) out of the sky and goes into a water pit. The doings and power of sorcerers, etc. (L V.-19. 5483-5505).
Falling stars go into the waterpit and sound like the rain; sorcerers' hearts also fall down from the sky and go into the waterpit with a thundering sound; the customs of sorcerers.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Falling stars

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: Bushman Presentiments, etc. A feeling which tells us something that happens in another place. In the Katkop dialect, by Díä!kwãin (L V.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: A presentiment

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: Further details concerning what occurs at the death of a sorcerer, and concerning the harmful and beneficial doings of sorcerers (L V.-19. 5506-5530). When a sorcerer dies, an earthquake takes place, and a star shoots. Even when asleep, a sorcerer knows what is going about in the night; and takes care of the people, defending them from the sorcerers. (L V.-19. 5531-5536 1/2).

Sorcerers' hearts sound like the rain when they die and their hearts fall into waterpits. Parents say they fear falling stars, because they know things that happen and always fall for a reason. Sorcerers can send their sorcery to different places to 'spirit' people away or kill them.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: About sorcerers: their death, their snoring work, earthquakes and the rain

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: He changes himself into a jackal, and goes to find out what is detaining his people, when they do not return home. In the Katkop dialect, by Díä!kwãin (L V.-19. 5506 rev.-5512 rev.).
Sorcerers' hearts become stars and come out of the sky when they die. In the form of a jackal, sorcerers seek people from their homes at night to see where they are and how they are doing.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: More about sorcerers

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: Explanation of various personal names was given, in the Katkop dialect, by Díä!kwãin (L V.-10. 4751-4754, 4758-4777, 18. 5373 rev., 19. 5505 rev. and 5506 rev., 20. 5572 and 5573, 5605-5607).
Dia!kwain's explanation of the name his mother gave him after her family was roughly beaten by people who she thought showed no pity.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Dia!kwain's explanation of the name which his mother gave him
Covers and first pages of Lloyd's Book V
20 or BC151_A2_1_069

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: What the Grass Bushmen do when angry. Karosses not to be beaten upon the ground, for fear of causing illness, and for fear of sorcerers. A way in which the latter cause illness is here mentioned. In the Katkop dialect, by Díä!kwãin (LV.-20. 5537-5556).
Karosses are 'magic things' which must be respected. Sorcerers watch how people treat magic things and can kill those who do not show respect.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Karosses must not be beaten upon the ground, for fear of bad consequences

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: Brief mention is made of a kind of blue mist, which resembles fire–smoke, and is illness. In the Katkop dialect, by Díä!kwãin (L V.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: !kh'o
The : a blue mist which resembles smoke

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: !ho,
Dia!kwain's brother (Ko-boken) is standing up at dawn, despite warnings against doing so from his father. A little whirlwind, or comes and pushes him over and he staggers and has to lie down.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: !ho
The and Ko-boken

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: In a peculiar state of the atmosphere, in which sounds can be heard at a considerable distance, sitting, instead of standing, is recommended; for fear of evil consequences. Standing over those who are sitting, on account of its injurious effects, is also objected to, etc. In the Katkop dialect, by Díä!kwãin (L V.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: !ho
The

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: Gargling forbidden by the Bushman mothers, for fear of evil consequences. In the Katkop dialect, by Díä!kwãin (L V.-20. 5569 rev. and 5570 rev.).
Children are not allowed to 'play' at gargling, although they may wash their throats if necessary.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Gargling

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: Explanation of various personal names was given, in the Katkop dialect, by Díä!kwãin (L V.-10. 4751-4754, 4758-4777, 18. 5373 rev., 19. 5505 rev. and 5506 rev., 20. 5572 and 5573, 5605-5607, translated).
About Dia!kwain's father Xaa-ttin who received the name Clay-hand after he had an accident while running after springbok; he got his foot stuck in clay and fell, dislocating his thumb.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Xaa
ttin's accident

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: The Bushman names for a few Stones were given by Díä!kwãin (L V.-20. 5574 and 5575), and by lhan≠kass’o (L VIII.-21. 7818, 7834).
A list of the |xam and proper names of stones and gemstones, given by Dia!kwain at the Philadelphia Exhibition.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The names of stones

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: A certain portion of the Ostrich not to be eaten by children. In the Katkop dialect by Díä!kwãin (L V.-20. 5573 rev. and 5574 rev.).
||xabbitten ||xabbitten ate the forbidden part of the ostrich and developed growths on his face afterwards.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Parts of the ostrich not to be eaten by children

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: The great star !gãunu, which singing, named the stars. By the position of certain stars, named by !gãunu, the porcupine knows the time for returning home. In the Katkop dialect, by Díä!kwãin (L V.-20. 5576-5580).
The star !gaunu named small stars 'aquilae' – they influence the porcupine at dawn and are thus called the Dawn's stars.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The great Star !gaunu, which singing named the stars

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: goura goura
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The young man who was changed into stone, by the glance of a new maiden

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: A fragment, regarding the ceremony to be performed by the maiden, was also given by Díä!kwãin (L V.-20. 5592 and 5593, translated, and 5591 rev., note).
An account of the ceremony performed by a new maiden with her father's hunting dogs to protect them and help them hunt well.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: A fragment of an account of a ceremony performed by Bushman maidens in order that their father's dogs should hunt well

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: Explanation of various personal names was given, in the Katkop dialect, by Díä!kwãin (L V.-10. 4751-4754, 4758-4777, 18. 5373 rev., 19. 5505 rev. and 5506 rev., 20. 5572 and 5573, 5605-5607).
An account of how Dia!kwain's brother-in-law, Mansse, was given the nickname of !kau |ho an, or 'Stone-knee', after he tripped and fell and cut his knee on a stone.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: How 'Mansse' obtained the name of !kau ||hoan

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: The rain is angry with us, if we talk to a maiden against her wish. (L V.20. 5608
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The girl who snaps her fingers at her parents and the rain

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: We should not allow a maiden to snap her fingers at us; the wrath of the Rain against us being thereby aroused. In the Katkop dialect, by Díä!kwãin (L V.-20. 5618-5622, 5624).
An account of the maiden who snaps her fingers at the people, which makes the rain 'lighten' and try to kill them. The rain 'shoots' at the people when the girl shouts at them.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The maiden who snaps her fingers at the rain (and causes lightning)

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: !goura

An account by Dia!kwain of the time that he played the while the rain fell and caused lightning at night. The rain struck them with lightning and they could not see and his mother tells him that the rain wants to kill them.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Dia!kwain plays the bow in a thunderstorm, or, The thunderstorm
Covers and first pages of Lloyd's Book V
21 or BC151_A2_1_070

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: Dia!kwain comments on George Stow's copy of a Bushman painting (no. 1) which features figures and various animals (numbered). He describes the doings of the |xam with regard to hunting. Dia!kwain goes on to describe the habits of the hunting leopard.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Explanation of Mr G. Stow's pictures: 1 (habits of the hunting leopard)

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: The Moon is not to be looked at, when game has been shot, for fear of evil consequences. In the Katkop dialect, by Díä!kwãin (LV.-21. 5643-5654).

Hunters lower their heads and do not look up when they have shot game, because the Moon's 'water' would cause the game to live (the Moon's water is what the people observe lying on bushes, which resembles 'liquid honey').
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The Moon, not to be looked at, when game is shot

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: Sneezing to be avoided when game has been wounded. How to obviate the ill effect of a Sneeze. (L V.-21. 5654-5659).
Mothers tell the children about how sneezing affects the death of game. Wounded game jumps up if the children sneeze.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Sneezing: to be avoided when game is shot

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: Sneezing in the early morning considered to be unfortunate. In the Katkop dialect, by Díä!kwãin (L V. 21. 5654 rev. and 5655 rev., note). How to destroy a Sneeze. (L V.
22. 5658 rev., note). kkoroken
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: kkoroken
Destroying the sneeze or

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: The Stars were formerly people. Some details regarding their singing. The opening of flowers from their buds compared with the former ways of the star. In the Katkop dialect, by Díä!kwãin (L.V.-21. 5660-5668, and 5661 rev.-5663, rev., note).
Stars resemble the Moon and used to be people. The stars resemble the budding flowers on trees. The stars burn like little fires.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Stars and flowers

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: garraken ≠ku yam
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: A song sung by the star !gaunu, especially by the Bushman women

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: !gaunu is also !guonni and is at the bee's hole. He bewitches (or 'stabs') people (to death) if they go to the hole where he is. Dia!kwain says the fathers told them that !guonni is a 'thing' which 'pinches the chest' and knocks people down.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: !gaunu

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: Stars and game behave in a similar way: when an animal is wounded the stars arouse its heart and make it want to walk.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Stars and game

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: Stones must not be thrown at the !kuerri-|nan (a little bird which is supposed to belong to the Rain). The evil effects of so doing exemplified in the case of the narrator’s cousin. In the Katkop dialect, by Díä!kwãin (L V.-21. 5698-5707).

Children should respect swallows and not throw stones at them, for fear of being killed or made ill by sorcerers. Kki-a ||ken fainted and got ill after throwing stones at a swallow with some other little boys when he was a child.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Swallows

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: Regarding various Bushmen. Partly in English after and partly in Bushman (L V.
21. 5702 rev. and 5703 rev.). kku'obbo
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Kki
a
||ken who threw stones at swallows

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: The locusts (with the locust birds which accompany them) are set free by Sorcerers. Stones not to be thrown at the locusts. (L V.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: kerri
The locust bird or ||
Covers and first pages of Lloyd's Book V
22 or BC151_A2_1_071

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: How to relieve a little child from the alarm caused by the sound of an earthquake. In the Katkop dialect, by Díä!kwãin (L V.-22. 5728-5735).

Earthquakes happen at the time when sorcerers seek people to take away. Shadows must not fall on other people in the early morning because this is when invisible sorcerers can see people and stab them down.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Earthquake

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: The human heart is believed to fall down at death. A star likewise falls. (L V.-22. 5731 rev.-5733 rev., note).
When people are about to die, their heart does not 'stand' as it did but falls like the star.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Falling stars

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: An explanation of No. 2 of Mr G.W. Stow’s collection of copies of Bushman Paintings was given, in the Katkop dialect by Díä!kwãin (L V.-22. 5739-5742).
The painting features figures (numbered) and animals. Díä!kwãin describes some of the hunting methods of the |xam.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Explanation of Mr G. Stow's pictures: no. 2

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: The Rain Sorcerer, ||kunn. In the Katkop dialect, by Díä!kwãin (L V.-22. 5743-5754).
||kunn says that the people have spoken harshly to him, as if he really owned the rain. They scold him when it does not fall, but forget that they asked him for it when the rain does fall.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The rainmaker ||kunn

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: The Bushman Doctor or Sorcerer (who may be of either sex.) By /han≠kass’o (L VIII.
7774). Remarks upon sorcerers, their dress, etc. (in explanation of one of Mr Stow’s copies of Bushman paintings), by Díä!kwãin. (L V.
4757.) A curious description of a dance and other doings of sorcerers was given in explanation of No. 3 of Mr Stow’s copies of Bushman paintings (L V.
5775). Further details regarding sorcerers (suggested by Mr J.M. Orpen’s copy of Bushman paintings – published in the for July, 1874.) were also given by Díä!kwãin (L V.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: ken
Mr G. Stow's picture no. 3 (the || dance)

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: The Bushman Doctor or Sorcerer (who may be of either sex.) By /han≠kass’o (L VIII.
7774). Remarks upon sorcerers, their dress, etc. (in explanation of one of Mr Stow’s copies of Bushman paintings), by Díä!kwãin (L V.
4757). A curious description of a dance and other doings of sorcerers was given in explanation of No. 3 of Mr Stow’s copies of Bushman paintings (L V.
5775). Further details regarding sorcerers (suggested by Mr J.M. Orpen’s copy of Bushman paintings – published in the for July, 1874.) were also given by Díä!kwãin (L V.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: ken
Healers (sorcerers) and the || dance

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: Death. The stars know the time at which a Bushman dies, and the fall of one announces, to those who are not aware of it, that something bad has happened. When, after this, a 'Hammerkop' (Scopus umbretta), flies, calling out over the Bushmen, the people know that someone belonging to them has died. Girls who have been killed by lightning are changed into stars. Girls who have been taken away by the water become like a beautiful water–flower, which will not allow itself to be plucked, and disappears when approached. Such flowers must be let alone. The place in the sky in which lightning appears should be looked at, so that the lightning may not kill us by stealth. In the Katkop dialect, by Díä!kwãin (L V.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Stars and death

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: Apparition seen by the party returning from the burial of the narrator’s wife; followed by the account of an apparition seen, on another occasion, by the narrator’s brother–in–law. In the Katkop dialect, by Díä!kwãin (L V.-22. 5810, 23. 5811-5832).

Dia!kwain and his people were returning from burying his wife when they saw an apparition that resembled Dia!kwain's wife. He believed it to be something that appears at the time when sorcerers take people away. Dia!kwain's brother-in-law, Mansse, also saw an apparition on the hunting-ground. Apparitions resemble people in some ways, but are also different.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Concerning apparitions (or How, when the first wife of Dia!kwain was buried, those returning to their homes saw the apparition of a little child)
Covers and first pages of Lloyd's Book V
23 or BC151_A2_1_072

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: A ceremony performed with the Brachycerus (African Ground Weevil) in order to preserve young babies from convulsions. In the Katkop dialect by Díä!kwãin (L V.-23. 5833-5840). The Brachycerus used to cure illness in little children. By /han≠kass’o (L VIII.-21. 7822–7825).
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Custom observed with Bushman children, when too young to walk

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: The crying of the Wind believed to forebode evil. In the Katkop dialect, by Díä!kwãin (L V.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The crying of the wind is an evil omen

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: A certain old woman named /xannan-/xannan, who had power over the wind. In the Katkop dialect, by Díä!kwãin (L V.-23. 5842 rev., 5845, 5845 rev. and 5846 rev.). The protection extended by the Wind to /xannan-/xannan. (L V.-23. 5862-5871).

About the old woman called |xannan |xannan (or ≠na a -an) and what she did with the wind when the people scolded her and made her angry. Dia!kwain's grandfather would ask |xannan |xannan to open her kaross so that the wind would blow out of it and blow away the mosquitos which kept him awake at night.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: |xannan |xannan and the wind

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: The crying of the Wind tells the beasts of prey where to find people, and when it blows strongly they can approach the dwelling unheard, etc. (L V.-23. 5846-5857).
People must hide when the wind blows strongly, as it means that the lion is coming for them and the blowing hides the sound of its approach from the dogs.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The crying of the wind tells beasts of prey where to find people

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: Resemblance between /xannan–/xannan and an ostrich. In the Katkop dialect, by Díä!kwãin (L V.-23. 5858-5862). The son of /xannan-/xannan. (L V.-23. 5860 rev. and 5861 rev.).

The old woman |xannan |xannan did not resemble other people: she resembled an ostrich and also walked like one. She lived at the Sak River with Dia!kwain's people, where he observed her actions firsthand.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: |xannan |xannan

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: Information regarding the family of 'Jan Plat' (a mixed Namaqua Hottentot and Bushman) was taken down, in English, after Díä!kwãin (L V.-23. 5872, 5871 rev. and 6872 rev., 25. 6006 rev., note). 'Ruyter' (a relative of the preceding). In the Katkop dialect, by Díä!kwãin (L V.-23. 5873-5880).

About the man called Ruyter (brother to Jan Plat); the names of his relations in |xam and Dutch and some details about them. Ruyter was brought up by white men and beaten to death by a Dutch man ('Boer') called Koos Struys who accused him of not herding sheep well.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Jan Plat's story about his brother Ruyter

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: About the Baboons and the Quagga, who were formerly people when those who are now people were not alive. Even though they are animals their organs still smell like they did when they were people.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Baboons and quagga are people

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: The Bushmen are said to have learnt the ≠gebbi–ggu from the Baboons, by whom it is still believed to be played. It was formerly, it is said, played also by the Ostrich and the Lion; but they fought and lost the power of playing it, becoming merely wild animals. (On page 12 of Dr. Bleek’s 'Second Report concerning Bushman Researches' (Cape Town, 1875), mention is made of a fable entitled, 'The Lion jealous of the voice of the Ostrich'.) In this piece, the above–mentioned quarrel between Lion and the Ostrich and the game of ≠gebbi–ggu is related. The Baboon, on the contrary, still understands like a man, and speaks, sounding like one. In the Katkop dialect, by Díä!kwãin (L V.-23. 5884-5890.) The ≠gebbi–ggu, as performed among the Grass Bushmen, was described by /han≠kass’o (L VIII.-22. 7978 and 7979).

The Baboon taught the ≠gebbi-ggu in the earlier times when Lions and Ostriches sang the ≠gebbi-ggu along with the Baboon. Only the baboon still speaks and understands and sings the ≠gebbi-ggu, sounding like a man.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: ≠gebbi-ggu
Baboons and the

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: |khui
|a is out hunting and shoots a mother baboon who is carrying a child. The father baboon goes to find the child and asks |khui
|a to leave it alone and not kill it, as he has already taken the baby's mother from him. |khui
|a is frightened and picks up his things and leaves them alone.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The adventure of |khui
|a with a family of baboons
Covers and first pages of Lloyd's Book V
24 or BC151_A2_1_073

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: Baboons not to be answered, when they address a Bushman in the early morning on his way to the hunting ground. They must, also, be alluded to in a very guarded manner, lest they should know that they are being spoken of. In the Katkop dialect, by Díä!kwãin (L V.-24. 5902-5910, 5905 rev. and 5906 rev., note).
Baboons are not 'good people' and do not 'merely' want to sit and talk as people pass. The baboon gets angry and teases. It mocks and deceives people as they pass by.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Baboons should not be spoken with

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: Certain cuts to be made upon the bow, when a Baboon has been killed. A similar ceremony to be observed with regard to the Hyena. A Baboon, when killed, resembles a man, in 'making cloud'. In the Katkop dialect, by Díä!kwãin (L V.-24. 5911-5916, 5911 rev., note).
Dia!kwain's father told him that the baboon's bad influence, brought about by its death, would live on in (or curse) the bow if the bow was not cut, causing the influence to leave the bow.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Cuts to be made on a bow when a baboon has been killed

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: Certain cuts to be made upon the bow, when a Baboon has been killed. A similar ceremony to be observed with regard to the Hyena. A Baboon, when killed, resembles a man, in 'making cloud'. In the Katkop dialect, by Díä!kwãin (L V.-24. 5911-5916, 5911 rev., note).
When a hyena has been killed, the bow is also cut with lines (as with killing a baboon) to remove the hyena's curse from the bow. This is so that the hyena's 'actions' will not be on the bow.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Cuts to be made on a bow when a hyena has been killed

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: What is said to people whose actions are disagreeable (or 'not nice'). The person is cursed and others are angry with him. The people question his treatment of them.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: What is said to a person whose actions are disagreeable

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: When shot, baboons will often try and throw the arrow back at the hunter and kill him too. When hunters see a baboon pull out an arrow and hold it in a certain way they must tell it that it is a 'girl's arrow', which will shame the baboon.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Baboons try to shoot people – means of preventing It

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: Baboons are said to speak the Bushman language and to possess wives. Their use of Ss’ó|õä, which informs them of matters otherwise unknown to them. In the Katkop dialect, by Díä!kwãin (L V.
5925 rev.). ss'o |a
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Baboons speak Bushman, and have wives

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: The name of a Bushman seems to be known to a Baboon, even when the latter beholds him for the first time. In the Katkop dialect, by Díä!kwãin (L V.-24. 5927-5929).
When a baboon sees a person it calls his or her name even if has never seen the person before. It tells the name to the others as the person passes by.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Baboons know our names

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: Baboons plan to attack ||xabbiten ||xabbiten. ||xabbiten ||xabbiten asks them what they are saying and then makes remarks about their ugly appearance and climbs a Krieboom tree. He deceives the baboons by calling out to white farmers as if they were near, because baboons fear white men and their guns.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Baboons and ||xabbiten ||xabbiten

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: A means of defending a dog from a Baboon, by telling him that it belongs to a young woman. (L V.-24. 5948-5956).
The people deceive the baboons and the baboons act as if they were not intending to kill the dog, but merely wanted to play with it.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Means of defending a dog from baboons

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: ...further described the value attached, by the Bushmen, to Ss’ó/õä found in the possession of Baboons; also its great use to the latter. The hair of the Baboon considered as a charm (L V.-24. 5957-5967).

Baboons keep Ssho |oa (ss'o |a) in their cheek, which people take out and keep when they kill them. They believe that this stick of Ssho |oa prevents the baboon from feeling pain and illness. Baboons live long and don't know illness, but if they do get ill it is severe and kills them.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Baboon's ss'o |a and hair used as charms against illness

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: Chippings of Gemsbok, Quagga, Ostriches, etc., executed by Xãä–ttin (father of the informant), to be found at the place (not yet identified) called !kaññ, where these animals used formerly to come to drink. In English, after Díä!kwãin (L V.-24. 5963 rev., note).
About the chippings made by Dia!kwain's father Xaa-ttin before the Dutch ('Boers') came. The chippings depict various game animals near to where the animals used to drink.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Chippings made by Dia!kwain's father (before the time of the 'Boers')

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: In former times, when animals were people, the Baboons were jealous of a young Quagga woman, who lived with them, on account of the notice attracted by her great size. For this reason, as well as for her fatness, they killed her, telling the other people that her flesh was that of a young gemsbok. In Katkop dialect, by Díä!kwãin, who had it from his father Xaättin (L V.-25. 5993-5997). The Punishment of the Baboon, which appears to be a continuation of the above fable, was narrated to Díä!kwãin by an older female relation named Ttuobboken !káugn (L V.-24. 5974-5991). An explanatory note to the story of the Punishment of the Baboon was also given by Díä!kwãin from information received from his mother, ≠kámme–an (L V.-24. 5992).

An account of when Baboons were people and ate human flesh, and were cursed as a result: the Baboon cooks 'gemsbok's' flesh on the hunting-ground and takes it home to feed the people, but deceives them because it is actually the flesh of a human being. The people are suspicious and question a child who was there on the hunting-ground with the Baboon. The child tells them that they are actually eating human flesh. The people plot to punish the Baboon and make him sit on hot stones so that he burns his buttocks. Baboons' tails are still hard and carry the burn marks to this day, because the people cursed the Baboon to eat only certain plants and bitter-tasting food and retain this appearance.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Baboons who ate human beings

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: In former times, when animals were people, the Baboons were jealous of a young Quagga woman, who lived with them, on account of the notice attracted by her great size. For this reason, as well as for her fatness, they killed her, telling the other people that her flesh was that of a young gemsbok. In Katkop dialect, by Díä!kwãin, who had it from his father Xaättin (L V.-25. 5993-5997). The Punishment of the Baboon, which appears to be a continuation of the above fable, was narrated to Díä!kwãin by an older female relation named Ttuobboken !káugn (L V.-24. 5974-5991). An explanatory note to the story of the Punishment of the Baboon was also given by Díä!kwãin from information received from his mother, ≠kámme–an (L V.-24. 5992).
A story of the Early Race (or 'First Time') when all things were people. The Baboons eat a woman who lives with them because she is fat.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The woman eaten by Baboons: a fragment of the account
Covers and first pages of Lloyd's Book V
25 or BC151_A2_1_074

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: In former times, when animals were people, the Baboons were jealous of a young Quagga woman, who lived with them, on account of the notice attracted by her great size. For this reason, as well as for her fatness, they killed her, telling the other people that her flesh was that of a young gemsbok. In Katkop dialect, by Díä!kwãin, who had it from his father Xãä–ttin (L V.-25. 5993-5997). The Punishment of the Baboon, which appears to be a continuation of the above fable, was narrated to Díä!kwãin by an older female relation named Ttuobboken !káugn (L V.-24. 5974-5991). An explanatory note to the story of the Punishment of the Baboon was also given by Díä!kwãin from information received from his mother, ≠kámme–an (L V.-24. 5992).
When the Quagga was a person she resembled a boulder and the Baboons feared her size and killed her.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The woman who was killed by the Baboons

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: The Baboons are also said to assemble together and play at the ≠gebbi–ggu, at night, like the Bushmen, singing like the Bushman women, and imitating the songs which they have heard the people sing. (L V.
6005). ≠gebbi
ggu
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: ≠gebbi-ggu
Baboons dance the

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: A curious description of a dance and other doings of sorcerers was given in explanation of No. 3 of Mr Stow’s copies of Bushman paintings (L V.
5775). Further details regarding sorcerers (suggested by Mr J.M. Orpen’s copy of Bushman paintings – published in the for July, 1874) were also given by Díä!kwãin (L V.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Picture of Mr Orpen's

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: ≠gebbi-ggu
Jan Plat's aunt Natta sang and taught the people the singing of the . She could imitate (by singing) a ewe's call to its young as well as the call of a partridge, using different parts of her throat.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: ≠gebbi-ggu
Jan Plat's aunt Natta sang the

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: The !kóroken-!kóroken (Telophonus . . .) must not be mocked by the Bushman children. The result of so doing described. In the Katkop dialect, by Díä!kwãin (L V.-25. 6014-6024). The !kóroken-!kóroken is said also to know what is passing at a distance, and to come and tell things to the Bushmen. Partly in English after and partly in Bushman (L V.-25. 6021 rev. and 6022 rev.).
It comes and tells people the bad things it knows about. It tries to make people understand what it is telling by coming to them again. According to Dia!kwain there are many stories about it.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: !koroken !koroken
The telephonus ()

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: The tip of the tongue of the Springbok is not eaten by children. In the Katkop dialect, by Díä!kwãin (L V.-25. 6025-6030).
When the springbok's tongue-tip is eaten, the person stumbles over a stone and stubs his or her toe.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Eating the springbok's tongue
tip

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: A description of the preparation of Meal, from the !kaùru ( . . . . . ) berries, was given, in the Katkop dialect, by Díä!kwãin. This is said to have been done formerly by the Quagga, in the days when she was a woman, and carried a sieve (L V.-25. 5997 rev.-6001 rev., note).
In Early Times the Quagga and the Baboon were people. The Quagga possessed a mat or a sieve that she used when making flour or meal out of roasted and ground-up berries.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Quagga makes flour
Covers and first pages of Lloyd's Book VII
1 or BC151_A2_1_075

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: The Old Man, the Little Hare, and the Lions. Related by ≠giri–sse (L VII.
6040, partly translated). A fragment of the above story was also related by ≠giri–sse (L VII.
1. 6031). Explanatory note in the Katkop dialect, by Díä!kwãin (L VII.
1. 6031 rev. and 6032 rev.). kumm
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Fragment of a story about the old man, the little Hare and the travelling Lions

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: The Old Man, the Little Hare, and the Lions. Related by ≠giri–sse (L VII.
6040, partly translated). A fragment of the above story was also related by ≠giri–sse (L VII.
1. 6031). Explanatory note in the Katkop dialect, by Díä!kwãin (L VII.
1. 6031 rev. and 6032 rev.). kumm
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The old man's song (written again separately, from ≠girri
sse's dictation)

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: Words and Sentences. Given by ≠girri-sse (L VII.-1. 6041-6044).
Includes the sentence 'I come from the strong water', meaning the Breakwater Convict Station.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Words and sentences: given by ≠girri
sse

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: One person not to stand over another in the early morning. By ≠girri-sse (L VII.-1. 6045 and 6046).
A fragment of the account of what happens when one stands in the early morning.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: A fragment of the story of the early morning

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: About Hendrik Beren, an employee of Mr Willmott, and some words given by him.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Personal history of Hendrick Beren and some words

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: Words and Sentences. Given by 'Jan Plat' (L VII.-1. 6046a-6046c).

Some words and sentences given by Jan Plat at Charlton House in Mowbray. The contribution includes some personal details, such the names of some of his relations. On p.6046c Lloyd notes that Jan Plat and Dia!kwain left Calvinia together.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: From 'Jan Plat' at Charlton House, Mowbray

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: An account of Jan Plat's movements with his travelling companion, Dia!kwain, and his meeting with his wife, who was keeping sheep in Louriet. A further account of Jan Plat's travels with Dia!kwain and the farmer Louw, whose sheep Dia!kwain had been keeping. Jan Plat states that Dia!kwain went with Louw to Kenhardt and then to the Free State.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Personal history of Jan Plat (he leaves Calvinia with Dia!kwain)

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: Name, etc., of a Bushman at the Amsterdam Battery, in 1879 (L VII.-1. 6046g). Words. Given by Xu gwai (L VII.-1. 6046g-6046j).
Also known as Jantje George.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Amsterdam Battery, near Cape Town: July 15/79

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: Name and other information regarding 'Friedrich Hortnoop', a relative of Díä!kwãin’s (L VII.-1. 6046f, 60461, 6046k rev.).

Some personal information given about Jan Plat's travelling companion, a |xam called Friedrich Hortnoop (or Frederick Hottentot) including the date and place of his trial and a brief physical description. His prisoner number was 7061. Friedrich Hortnoop left Mowbray in the company of Jan Plat on 10 January 1884 to return to Bushmanland. His grandfather was Dia!kwain's father's brother.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Personal history of Friedrich Hortnoop
Covers and first pages of Lloyd's Book VIII
1 or BC151_A2_1_076

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: Some names of animals and other things from daily life given by |han≠kass'o.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Words and sentences given by |han≠kass'o

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: Information regarding narrator’s family. In English after and in Bushman by /han≠kass'o (L VIII.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Genealogical information concerning the family of |han≠kass'o (or Klein Jantje)

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: Explanatory remarks concerning copies of Bushmen Paintings and Etchings, collected by Mr. H.C. Schunke and deposited in the Grey Library. Partly in Bushman by and partly in English after |han≠kass'o (L VIII.-1. 6054-6057, 6061-6073).

A list of remarks by |han≠kass'o alongside the numbers (I-XXIV) of a collection of copies of paintings found in the Grey Library. These paintings are mostly of animals and rainmakers and their work with the rain.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Remarks concerning copies of Bushman pictures nos. I
XXIV Collected By Mr H.C. Schunke, and deposited in the Grey Library

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: Cattle drink at the water and eat grass, and then sleep when they are full.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: About cattle

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: !khoa ka ||kerri-ssi !kau
The rain's 'things' (or ) of |han≠kass'o's country have large bodies and dwell in water; some of them kill people when they bite them.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: !khoa ka ||kerri-ssi !kau
An account of the rain's things or

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: khuken
|u |unu, !khoa ka ||kerri
ssi !kau)
