The

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: !khou, (!khoa ka ||kerri
ssi !kau)
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: !khou
The or water tortoise

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: Names of various Bushmen and Bushman women, with information regarding them.–Partly in Bushman by and partly in English after lhan≠kass’o. (L VIII.–1. 6078–6081, 4. 6370 rev., Note, 11. 6969 rev., Note 14. 7278 and 7277 rev., 20. 7749 and 7750, 7750 rev., 7748 rev. and 7749 rev., 27. 8437, 8435 rev. and 8436 rev., 31. 8744 rev., 8772 rev., 32. 8808 rev.)
Biographical information about some |xam individuals and their relations.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The personal histories of various people

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: The !ãù, or shaped rib-bone, used by Bushmen in eating certain food. By /han≠kass’o (L VIII.-1. 6082).
The facing page contains a note as to how it is shaped or 'worked'.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: !au
The or shaped rib-bone used by Bushmen in eating some kinds of food

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: The /khu, or Bushman soup spoon. This is a brush of native manufacture, the stem of which is also used to scratch the fire together. By |han≠kass’o (L VIII.-1. 6083 and 6084).

The |khu is made by the men who bind together the back hairs of the |gipp (Proteles, or aardwolf). There are also details about the springbok's 'paxwax', or |kuerri, in this account of the making of the soup spoon.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: |khu
The or Bushman soup-spoon

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: !kabbi,
About the or partridge, named by |han–kass'o after seeing one in a picture.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: !kabbi
The : a bird which has white legs and is eaten

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: ka kau
About the | bird, which laughs at the wild cat and is not eaten by people.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: |ka kau
The : a little bird said by the Bushmen, by whom it is not eaten, to laugh at the wildcat

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: Arrow making, and Arrow poisoning. (L VIII.-26. 8293-8302, 8315-8334). Two kinds of Arrow. (L VIII.-10. 6923 rev. and 6924 rev., note). Arrow heads, etc. (L VIII.-1. 6086 and 6087). Description of the spur, or barblet, sometimes added to the Arrow shaft by Bushmen. (L VIII.-31. 8770–8773, and 8767 rev., note). The adhesive substance used by Bushmen is making Arrows. Preparation thereof. (L VIII.-1. 6088-6091). The marking of Arrows. (L VIII.-26. 8289-8392). Arrow Bags. (L VIII. 30. 8663 rev., note).
About the making of arrow-heads: the head is made from a white stone and fixed into the end of a reed; they are used for shooting springbok.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Arrowheads

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: Arrow making, and Arrow poisoning. By /han≠kass’o (L VIII.
8334). Two kinds of Arrow. (L VIII.
10. 6923 rev. and 6924 rev., note). Arrow heads, etc. (L VIII.
1. 6086 and 6087). Description of the spur, or barblet, sometimes added to the Arrow shaft by Bushmen. (L VIII.
31. 8770–8773, and 8767 rev., note). The adhesive substance used by Bushmen is making Arrows. Preparation thereof. (L VIII.
6091). The marking of Arrows. (L VIII.
8392). Arrow Bags. (L VIII. 30. 8663 rev., note). kwae
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: kwae
The adhesive substance (|) used in arrowmaking and its preparation for use

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: kauru-opua,
The || or a small water-hole, is found in flat stones on the ground.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: kauru-opua
The ||, or little water-hole found in rock or stone

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: Rain–making. By |han≠kass’o (L VIII.-1. 6093-6095).
The work of the rainmakers; how they 'grasp' the rain's 'ribs'. Also about the rain and the north wind.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Rainmaking, when the wind is in the north

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: Wind and Weather. The Four Winds. By /han≠kass’o (L VIII.-1. 6096–6101).
The north wind blows underneath the rain-clouds and makes them strong.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The north wind

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: Wind and Weather. The Four Winds. By /han≠kass’o (L VIII.-1. 6096–6101).
The west wind turns back the rain-clouds and sends them to the east.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The west wind

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: Wind and Weather. The Four Winds. By /han≠kass’o (L VIII.-1. 6096-6101).
The south wind blows, 'standing above', and 'makes dust'.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The south wind

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: Wind and Weather. The Four Winds. By /han≠kass’o (L VIII.-1. 6096-6101).
The east wind is cold and blows strongly. The people have to make shelters and light fires to warm themselves when it comes.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The east wind

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: Drought. By /han≠kass’o (L VIII.
1. 6102–6106). When the west wind turns back the rain
clouds there is a drought or 'want' of rain and the people are thirsty and have to travel far to fetch water.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Want of rain

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: Certain kinds of Food, used by Bushmen. By /han≠kass’o (L VIII.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Food of the Bushmen, found in their country

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: The employment of the !gõin–!gõin (the !gõin–!gõin consists of a [variously–sized] blade of wood, attached by a little cord to a short stick. The latter is held in the hand of the performer, and the blade of wood (attached to the string) is then, by means of the stick–handle, whirled about in the air, producing a strong whirring sound. When several of these instruments are used at a time, a considerable effect must be produced), followed by the account of a Bushman dance, in which the men dance, one woman beats the drum, and the rest of the women sit, clapping their hands for the dancers. By /han≠kass’o (L VIII.
!goin
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: !goin-!goin
The use of the , followed by an account of a Bushman dance

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: The Bushman drum, and dancing–rattles. Mode of preparation of the latter, by the women. By /han≠kass’o, (L VIII.-1. 6127-6137).
The drum is prepared by pulling springbok skin over a pot's mouth. The men tie springbok's ears on their feet (the insteps) as dancing rattles to make sounds while they dance.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The preparation of the drum; ears of springbok are tied to the feet of the men who dance

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: The Bushman drum, and dancing-rattles. Mode of preparation of the latter, by the women. By /han≠kass’o, (L VIII.-1. 6127-6137).
The springbok's ear dancing rattles are made from dried springbok's ear skin with berries sewn inside.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The preparation of the springbok's ears

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: The Bushman drum, and dancing-rattles. Mode of preparation of the latter, by the women. By /han≠kass’o, (L VIII.-1. 6127-6137).
see A description of how the springbok ears are tied to the top of the male dancer's feet after being prepared and filled (with berries).
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: How the prepared springbok's ears are tied on

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: The names of the wife, son, and daughter of the Mantis. By /han≠kass’o (L VIII.-1. 6137 rev.).
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The names of |kaggen's wife, son and daughter

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: An account of how ||kabbo's tobacco pouch was stolen by a dog ('Blom') while he slept at night, and of the subsequent search for it.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The loss of ||kabbo's tobacco bag, which was stolen by a hungry dog, belonging to !gou !nui, named 'Blom'

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: ||kabbo's song sung on the occasion of the theft of his tobacco pouch by the dog 'Blom'. It concerns his 'tobacco
hunger'.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: ||kabbo's song on the loss of his tobacco pouch

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: wa kwara Eupodotis afra
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: kwa kwara
The , or korhaan malkop

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: , kwa kwara Eupodotis afra
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: kwa kwara
The song of the , or korhaan malkop
Covers and first pages of Lloyd's Book VIII
2 or BC151_A2_1_077

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: Names of Animals, mainly identified at the South African Museum. Given by /han≠kass’o (L VIII.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Words and sentences given by |han≠kass'o at the South African Museum

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: Another version of the story of the Crow Messengers appears, here, in connexion with the adventure related above ; /kwámmana and his companion being, in this instance, those who were found by the successful bird (Corvus scapulatus). (L VIII.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Crows and a note on secretary birds

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: The Mantis and |kwámmana go out visiting together. The Mantis involves himself in a quarrel with a young “Dasse” (Hyrax), and stones fall upon him and |kwámmana. The latter, upon whom they lie loosely, is first rescued; while the Mantis owes his rescue to the entreaties of his wife, who prevails upon the people to take him out.–His teasing and troublesome ways are much blamed. (L VIII.–2. 6165–6193, and 6195.) Another version of the story of the Crow Messengers appears, here, in connexion with the adventure related above; |kwámmana and his companion being, in this instance, those who were found by the successful bird (Corvus scapulatus). (L VIII.–2. 6147–6157) By the same narrator was also given the Rescue of |kwámmana and the Mantis, and their return home. The Blue Crane, who is the elder sister of |kaggen, pities his sad condition.–Specimens of the peculiar manner in which the Bushman language is spoken by the wife of |kaggen, and by the Ichneumon, respectively, are here given. (L VIII.–2. 6196–6231, 3. 6232–6236.) A note regarding the ≠kam–!kwê, a member of the party which went to the rescue of /kwámmana and his companion (L VII.-2. 6195 rev. and 6196 rev.).

|kwammana and |kaggen (the Mantis) both drink from ostrich egg-shells offered to them, |kwammana by the young bee and |kaggen by the Dassie who passes water into his shell. |kaggen curses the Dassie when he tastes its urine and the mother Dassie makes rocks roll on |kaggen and |kwammana. The people take |kaggen out from under the rocks only because his wife has asked them to.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The Mantis and |kwammana visit the Dassie's house
Covers and first pages of Lloyd's Book VIII
3 or BC151_A2_1_078

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: The Mantis visits the abode of the Ticks, attempts to take some of their food, and is well beaten by them. He flies away, goes into the water, and returns home where he is pitied and lectured by the Ichneumon. By /han≠kass’o (L VIII.-3. 6236-6258, 6267-6269). Also (L VIII.-20. 7790-7811; L VIII.-20. 7812-7816, 22. 7906-7956).
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The Mantis and the Ticks

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: The !khaü (a lizard of the genus Agama), which interferes with the coming of the rain–clouds. Springbok hunting follows the rain. (L VIII.
6271). !khau, kochelman !khau
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The !khau lizard and the rainclouds – springbok hunting follows rain; and the song of the !khau lizard

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: The |kain |kain bird stabs a girl in the breast when she lies ill. The |kain |kain rubs her blood on his nose and goes to another girl. The |kain |kains come to the house of |kaggen (the Mantis) and |kaggen tells the girl's mother to give her a knife to take to bed with her. The girl stabs the bird when it comes, and the other birds scatter and run away. The people remark that |kaggen warned them about the |kain |kain, even though he usually lies and teases.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The |kain |kain, the girls and the Mantis

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: The !kwái–!kwái, the Mantis, and the Children. The !kwái–!kwái, who was formerly a man, and is now a bird (in appearance somewhat resembling a 'duiker'), comes, during the absence of their parents, to kill the children. They are defended by the Mantis, who causes the death of !kwái–!kwái. By /han#kass’o (L VIII.
6333). A note to the above story was also given by /han#kass’o (L VIII.
18. 7596, 7597 and 7595 rev.). !kwai !kwai
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The !kwai !kwai, the Mantis and the children
Covers and first pages of Lloyd's Book VIII
4 or BC151_A2_1_079

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: Names of various Bushmen and Bushman women, with information regarding them. Partly in Bushman by and partly in English after /han#kass’o (L VIII.-1. 6078-6081, 4. 6370 rev., note, 11. 6969 rev., note 14. 7278 and 7277 rev., 20. 7749 and 7750, 7750 rev., 7748 rev. and 7749 rev., 27. 8437, 8435 rev. and 8436 rev., 31. 8744 rev., 8772 rev., 32. 8808 rev.).
A note on the personal history of |han≠kass'o and names of his relations as well as an explanation of one of the names: Stone-Earbone.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Personal history of |han≠kass'o

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: The !gwá–!nuntu, whose grandchild is carried off by Elephants, and recovered by himself. By /han#kass’o (L VIII.
6455 !xwe ||na ssho !kui
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The story of !gwa !nuntu and the Elephants

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: ...It was also stated by him that the Bushmen were formerly Springbok, and were changed into Bushmen by the Mantis (L VIII.-4. 6365 rev.).
In the Early Times, when people were springboks, they cried like children when |kaggen (the Mantis) shot them. |kaggen said they should become people because of how they cried.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: When Bushmen were springbucks and cried

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: The approach of strangers causes us to become drowsy. By /han≠kass’o (L VIII.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The approach of strangers makes Bushmen sleepy
Covers and first pages of Lloyd's Book VIII
5 or BC151_A2_1_080

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: The Rhinoceros and her daughter’s suitors. By /han≠kass’o (L VIII.-5. 6456-6504).

The She-Rhinoceros has two daughters. The youngest is Driving Away (Ssuai-ssuai-||a-|uhan), who asks her mother for food as a reward for telling her (by means of a song) when people come to court her elder daughter (!kwa !khe). The She-Rhinoceros chases them away with her short horn, and the !gwiten (Silver Fox) throws a stick at them as they run away, complaining about the dust that has been kicked up. The Leopard goes to !kwa-!khe and the younger sister starts her singing again. The elder sister asks her to stop, but Driving Away still wants the reward of food from the She-Rhinoceros and sings about the new suitor. The mother instructs her to fetch the long horn, because it is the Leopard and he will not be afraid of her. !kwa-!khe beats her mother on the back with a stick and leaves with the Leopard. The cowardly suitors (the Jackals and Hyena) see the Leopard bringing !kwa-!khe as his wife and discuss how they would have married her had her mother not fought them.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The She
Rhinoceros and her elder daughter's suitors
Covers and first pages of Lloyd's Book VIII
6 or BC151_A2_1_081

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: The Mantis (/kaggen) makes and brings up a young eland. /kwámmana, who is informed of its existence by the Ichneumon, kills it, to the grief of /kaggen. The latter, having pierced the gall of the dead eland, takes an ostrich feather to wipe it from his eyes, which feather he then throws up into the sky, ordering it to become the Moon. A description of porcupine hunting, in which the moonlight is of service, follows. This story, which /han≠kass’o had from his mother, /Xabbi–an, throws light upon one or two points which had remained somewhat obscure in the versions earlier collected (L VIII.-6. 6506-6595 1/2).

|kaggen (the Mantis) takes one of |kwammana's shoes and soaks it in the water. It grows into an eland and |kaggen returns to look at it again and again. The Ichneumon sees the eland while he is pretending to sleep and tells his father (|kwammana) about the eland. While |kaggen is away, |kwammana kills the eland. |kaggen is angry with the people for killing the eland without telling him, as he is the one who made it. He pierces a gall, which breaks and covers him so that he can no longer see. He finds a feather, which he picks up and throws into the sky and which becomes the Moon.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The Mantis makes an eland

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: A description of porcupine hunting, in which the moonlight is of service, follows (L VIII.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Porcupine hunting

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: When the lion is coming, he is preceded by an apparition which resembles a real lion. By /han≠kass’o (L. VIII.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The coming of lion

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: Different customs concerning the eating of the Porcupine. By /han≠kass’o (L VII.-6. 6590 rev.-6594 rev.).

The people who live where the sun sets (the place where Dia!kwain and his people come from) roast and eat the porcupine on the hunting-ground, but |han≠kass'o's people take the porcupine home when there are no springbok.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Mode of eating porcupine
Covers and first pages of Lloyd's Book VIII
7 or BC151_A2_1_082

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: !kuerre-!kuerre
About the bird and what people say when it flutters its wings.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: !kuerre-!kuerre
The (a bird)

tonno (L XXII. 10407
10413). Ditto.By /han≠kass’o (L VIII.
1. 6059 and 6051, 7. 6598 rev.). Names for certain bones, etc. (L VIII.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Words and sentences given by |han≠kass'o: parts of the body

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: About the locust as well as the bird that eats it.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Locusts

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: The Mantis and his son–in–law /kwámmana are both to be seen in the rainbow, the Mantis uppermost and /kwámmana underneath. (L VIII.-7. 6600 rev. & 6601 rev.).
|kaggen (the Mantis) and |kwammana can be seen in the rainbow and are the same colour as the part they live in. The people call the rainbow by |kwammana's name.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Rainbow (|kaggen and !kwammana)

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: Names for Colours, etc. Given by /han≠kass’o (L VIII.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Words and sentences given by |han≠kass'o: names of colours and patterns

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: When it seems as if the rain will break, the people start seeking springbok. An account of the driving and shooting of springbok, and hunting methods in general.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Springbok hunting

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: The !gwé plant, from which poison is derived. (L VIII.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: About poison

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: What the owl says.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: What the owl says

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: kui sse
A girl takes | hair and throws it into the sky, where it becomes locusts, which jump away.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The girl who made locusts

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: When a swarm of locusts comes flying past the people must go to the place where the locusts settle and make fire. The rainmaker, |kannu, grew locusts and gave them to the people.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: About locusts

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: ||kunnu who possessed locusts and rain, and was entreated for rain by a relative of the narrator. (L VIII.-7. 6639 rev. -6646 rev.).
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: |kannu the rainmaker

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: The hail considered to be the legs of the rain. (L VIII.
7. 6652 rev., note). Also, some words pertaining to rain and related weather conditions.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The hail is the rain's legs

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: kerri
The || bird drives locusts into bushes while the sun is shining, which they do not normally do.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: ||kerri
The bird and locusts

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: The ill effects of eating !kùï ( . . . . ) were mentioned by /han≠kass’o (L VIII.7. 6679 rev., note). gambro, kui
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Gambro |kui
Covers and first pages of Lloyd's Book VIII
8 or BC151_A2_1_083

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: The Son of the Wind. By |han≠kass’o (L VIII.-8. 6687-6708).

|na ka ti's mother tells him not to say the name of the son of the Wind until his father has made a hut for them. When the father is finished, |na ka ti calls the Wind's name and then runs to the hut. The Wind blows away the people's houses, except for the Wind's hut. The Wind's mother picks up the son of the Wind and it stops blowing. A strong shelter must be made before calling the Wind's name.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The son of the Wind

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: The Wind was formerly a man, but is now a bird, and lives in the mountain. By /han≠kass’o (L VIII.
6713, and 6694 rev., note).
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The Wind

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: The Wind thought to be seen, in the form of a bird, by the brother–in–law of the narrator when a child. By /han≠kass’o (L VIII.-8. 6713-6724).

||goo-ka-!kui (Smoke's man, or Witbooi Tooren) told |han≠kass'o that he had seen the Wind at the mountains at Haarfontein (or ≠ko a xa) and had thrown a stone at it, thinking it to be a bird. As a result the Wind blew hard and took up dust.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The Wind
Notes to the story of

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: Wind–making; followed by a long discourse upon springbok hunting. By /han≠kass’o (L VIII.-8. 6725-6769 rev.).

The people beat the bushes with a stick and call to the north wind to help them travel quickly in front of the game. The hunters do not wish to shoot while the springbok are running, as they are too numerous. Some hunters drive, some run and some wait in a screen to shoot the springbok. Bewitched springbok do not fall even when shot, and must be left alone.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Windmaking and springbok hunting

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: kuarri
A note on how || is eaten by porcupines, but is poisonous to people.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: kuarri
The porcupine eats ||

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: A note on the locust and its names, proper and |xam, as well as its appearance.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: ||kabba-|kha
Locusts or
Covers and first pages of Lloyd's Book VIII
9 or BC151_A2_1_084

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: Names of Animals, mainly identified at the South African Museum. Given by /han≠kass’o (L VIII.-2. 6141-6145, 9. 6770-6775, 21. 7817, 7819-7821, 7842 and 7843, 7843, 7846, 31. 8790 rev. and 8791).
A list list of |xam names of animals given by |han≠kass'o at the South African Museum as well as some details about them.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Words and sentences given by |han≠kass'o at the South African Museum

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: A game played with the Phyllomorpha paradoxa or 'Withered Leaf' Insect. By /han≠kass’o (L VIII.-9. 6775-6785).
The withered-leaf insect distracts crying children and the people protect it from burning in the fire and laugh at its head-nodding movements.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Phyllomorpha paradoxa
The (or withered-leaf insect)

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: ≠Nuturu dances for the children and sings to herself until the people return. She takes off her 'face's horns' and the people see that her face underneath is white and beautiful. The hunters give her the fatty springbok breasts to eat and their own wives get lean meat.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The ≠nuturu

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: !haken, a food resembling 'Bushman rice' is also used by Bushmen. (L VIII.
9. 6789 rev., note).
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: !haken
, a food resembling 'Bushman rice'

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: Different kinds of rain. The children to hide from rain that is likely to be strong, for fear of the lightning. (L VIII.-9. 6813 rev.-6815 rev.).
Liquid rain falls gently, a big rain falls in hard streams, another rain 'makes lightening' and makes the place black.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Kinds of rain
Covers and first pages of Lloyd's Book VIII
10 or BC151_A2_1_085

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: kerri

The || bird eats locusts and is thus called the locust-bird. They drive the locusts into the bushes, where the people collect them and roast them in a fire. The people thirst after collecting locusts and need water. The rain then breaks and the people go and hunt for springbok.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: kerri
The ||: a bird which eats locusts; and locust-hunting

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: A Girl being angry with her mother, because the latter asked her for a certain kind of food which she had put to roast in the fire, threw it with the wood–ashes that were upon it, into the air. The food was changed into stars, and the ashes became the Milky Way. By |han≠kass’o (L VIII.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: !huin
The new maiden who threw into the sky; which became stars, and the wood ashes which were upon it, the Milky Way

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: The Mantis and Kóro–tuíten. The Mantis learns from Kóro–tuíten how to obtain 'Bushman–rice' (i.e. larvae of the ants) with ease; but, acting ungratefully towards his instructor, he soon loses his newly acquired power. By /han≠kass’o (L VIII.-10. 6885-6939). A note states that Kóro–tuíten was formerly a man of the early race (L VIII.-10. 6885 rev.). 'Bushman rice' may be dug by both men and women. By /han≠kass’o (L VIII.-10. 6888 rev., note).

|kaggen (the Mantis) is out hunting when he comes across Koro-tuiten, who flies down into a 'Bushman-rice' hole and carries out a kaross full of 'Bushman-rice' (ant larvae). |kaggen asks Koro-tuiten to anoint him with its perspiration so he too can get lots of 'Bushman-rice'. |kaggen breaks all his things (including his digging-stick), but gets a kaross full of 'Bushman rice'. He returns home and goes out to meet Koro-tuiten again, and fills many karosses of 'Bushman-rice'. Koro-tuiten asks him to divide his 'Bushman-rice', but |kaggen refuses. The next day when he tries to dive into the earth he crushes his brow, because the earth is now hard.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The Mantis and Koro
tuiten

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: ... the account of a visit paid by /kwámmana, with a young Ichneumon and the Mantis, to the abode of the 'Löffelhund' (Proteles); where the Mantis again gets into trouble. (L VIII.1-6939–6944, 11. 6945-6977).

|kwammana and the Ichneumon visit the Proteles (|ku) and |kaggen (the Mantis) insists on coming with them. |kwammana begs the mother Proteles for a little Proteles to eat and she gives him a lean one. They return home with meat for the women, but |kaggen turns back and returns to the Proteles's house where he calls for the mother Proteles to give him another of her children. She knocks him into the fire he has built and he returns home, where |kwammana and the Ichneumon scold him for his foolish actions.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: |kuamman
a, accompanied by the Mantis and the young Ichneumon, visits the house of the |ku, or, The Mantis and the Proteles

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: Arrow making, and Arrow poisoning. By /han≠kass’o (L VIII.-26. 8293-8302, 8315-8334). Two kinds of Arrow. (L VIII.-10. 6923 rev. and 6924 rev., note). Arrow heads, etc. (L VIII.-1. 6086 and 6087). Description of the spur, or barblet, sometimes added to the Arrow shaft by Bushmen. (L VIII.-31. 8770-8773, and 8767 rev., note). The adhesive substance used by Bushmen in making Arrows. Preparation thereof. (L VIII.-1. 6088-6091). The marking of Arrows. (L VIII.-26. 8289-8392). Arrow Bags. (L VIII. 30. 8663 rev., note).
The names and uses of poisons and the feathering of arrows.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Feathered arrows and poison

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: Bushman rice' may be dug by both men and women. (L VIII.
10. 6888 rev., note). gambro None
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The digging out of 'Bushman rice'

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: A young ram springbok grows horns on his forehead when he becomes a grown
up springbok.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Springbok horns
Covers and first pages of Lloyd's Book VIII
11 or BC151_A2_1_086
Covers and first pages of Lloyd's Book VIII
12 or BC151_A2_1_087

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: The son of the Mantis is killed by the Baboons, and restored to life by his father. This piece contains specimens of the manner in which the Bushman language is supposed to be spoken by baboons. By /han≠kass’o (L VIII.-11. 6978-7014, 12. 7065-7094).

!gaunu-tsaxau, the son of |kaggen (the Mantis) collects sticks for his father to shoot at the Baboons and comes across some Baboons, who beat him and break his head. |kaggen dreams that the Baboons have killed !gaunu-tsaxau and are playing with his eye. He awakes and goes to join in the Baboons' game and the child's eye smells its father's scent and plays about so that the Baboons cannot catch it. |kaggen catches his child's eye and anoints it with his perspiration and it flies into the air and into the quiver's bag. He flies into the water and speaks to his child's eye, wanting his child to return to life again. It grows back into his son and |kaggen catches him and takes him back home.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: !gaunu
tsaxau (the son of the Mantis), the Baboons, and the Mantis

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: /kú–te–!gaúä, who could enter fire unharmed, enables the Mantis to do the same. The ingratitude of the latter to his instructor again brings him into trouble; and his newly acquired power deserts him. (L VIII.-11. 7015-7031, 12. 7032-7064).

|ku-te !gaua goes through fire and draws out cats, 'such cat's as had no equal in beauty' and then skins them. |kaggen (the Mantis) sings like |ku-te !gaua and also gets skins, but he refuses to share them with |ku-te !gaua. |ku-te !gaua angrily says that |kaggen and the skins will burn in the fire, which happens.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: |ku
te
!gaua and |kaggen

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: !haken, a food resembling 'Bushman rice' is also used by Bushmen. (L VIII.
9. 6789 rev., note). That !haken above which a certain fungus grows is given to the old people. (L VIII.
6954 rev.). !gu !gu !haken !haken
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Various foods and the protection of the rain for a fungus

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: Names of various Bushmen and Bushman women, with information regarding them. Partly in Bushman by and partly in English after /han≠kass’o (L VIII.-1. 6078-6081, 4. 6370 rev., note, 11. 6969 rev., note 14. 7278 and 7277 rev., 20. 7749 and 7750, 7750 rev., 7748 rev. and 7749 rev., 27. 8437, 8435 rev. and 8436 rev., 31. 8744 rev., 8772 rev., 32. 8808 rev.).
Personal information about a man called ||gabbe-Tka, or Piet Titus.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Note on a certain man

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: Personal information about a man called kkuirri
ttu (|han≠kass'o's uncle) who was killed by a white man over some missing oxen.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Note on kkuirri
ttu

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: The names of certain animals.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Words and sentences: names of animals

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: The mode of preparation of the !nábbe ( . . . . ), made from the tail hair of various animals. By /han≠kass’o (L VIII.-11. 7005 rev.-7007 rev.).
The tail and tail-hair of various jackals and foxes are compared and used in the making of the brush.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: !nabbe
The

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: kitten-|kitten
A bird found in Bushmanland called the |.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: kitten-|kitten
Notes on a bird (|)

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: A man, who has missed his aim in shooting, throws springbok bones, in order that another man may do likewise. (L VIII.-11. 7010 rev., note). !hau-!hau
is a charm made so that a man may make another miss his aim on the hunting-ground.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: !hau-!hau
Explanation of (a hunting charm)

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: The man (belonging to the early race) who ordered his wife to cut off his ears. By /han≠kass’o (L VIII.-12. 7095-7097).
A man thinks his younger brother's head-skin has been cut off, but he has in fact only had his hair shaved off.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The man who ordered his wife to cut off his ears

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: The Mason Wasp (? Genus Lyrops) who shot his wife for making a personal remark. By /han≠kass’o (L VIII.-12. 7098-7103).
The Mason Wasp shoots his wife with an arrow intended for the Hare, then cries regretfully when he sees that she is dead.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: How the !gabbaken
!gabbaken (the Mason Wasp) punished his wife for making personal remarks

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: The flesh of the Lynx not eaten by Bushman women. By /han≠kass’o (L VIII.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The lynx; its flesh eaten by Bushmen, but not by the Bushman women; the manner of hunting it, etc.

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: A tale of the Early Race about the !khau lizard, who brings home his own flesh as food so that his wife will think he has brought home a Quagga. Eventually the wife tells their child to go out with his father and see what flesh he is bringing and the child sees his father go into a whirlwind and come out rolling his flesh in a net. The woman throws away the husband's flesh and leaves him for her father's people.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The !kau who brought home his own flesh as food

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: Fat; division of into small quantities.(L VIII
7110 rev., note).
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The manner of dividing fat

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: !ka-ka |khueten
A note about a certain spider called the .
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: !ka-ka |khueten
The (a spider)

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: Huts made by the Bushman women. The shelter for them made by the men. By /han≠kass’o (L VIII.
12. 7111 rev. and 7112 rev., note).
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Regarding houses

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: The three children of the Mantis. By /han≠kass’o (L VIII.
7076 rev., note).
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Regarding the children of the Mantis

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: The Mantis is further said, by the Bushmen, to have given places their names. By /han≠kass’o (L VIII.
12. 7033 rev. and 7034 rev., note).
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The Mantis — giver of names to places

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: Various expressions for being angry or comfortable with another person.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Words and sentences: various expressions for being angry

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: What people say when talking about the flight of bees.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: guobba ||a !kwiten ||a

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: How various kinds of mice make their nests in Bushmanland.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: How various mice make their nests

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: Terms for various relationships by marriage. (L VIII.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Words and sentences: terms for various relationships by marriage

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: The hunting of hare, and its habits.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Hunting hare
Covers and first pages of Lloyd's Book VIII
13 or BC151_A2_1_088

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: A note regarding the latter stars [named by !gãunu] was given by /han≠kass’o (L VIII.-13. 7119 rev.).
About a rain called 'Aquilae's water' and about rain-clouds which resemble celestial bodies.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Aquilae's water

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: !khau
The song of the lizard's child, which it sings while following its father home after he has cut off his own flesh.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Song of the !kau's child

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: !koa
A song of the Early Race in which the (or Muishond) cuts off his own flesh with his knife and cooks and eats it, until his body grows small from all the cutting. He asks the west wind what to do.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The !koa (or Muishond)

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: The names of some Bushmen. (L VIII.-13. 7195 rev.).
Names of some of |han≠kass'o's relations.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Names of |han≠kass'o's relations

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: Names for certain Winds. (L VIII.-13. 7196 rev.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Names for certain winds
Covers and first pages of Lloyd's Book VIII
14 or BC151_A2_1_089

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: A story of the !khau (the Kochelman, or Agama lizard) in the Early Times when animals were people (7206opp). As he passes through the mountains, they squeeze and break him. The front of his body falls off and becomes !guru |na and his back falls of and becomes |xe
!khwai.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Agama
The death of the !kau (a lizard of the genus )

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: The death of the !kau kochelman, !khau
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The death of the !kau
Remarks by |han≠kass'o on the preceding story ()

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: The death of the !kau

|han≠kass'o's mother sends him to collect water and kills the leveret (hare) while he is away. |han≠kass'o' is upset and his mother tells him a story () to soothe him. She tells him not to play with meat (animals that will be eaten).
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: How |han≠kass'o's pet leveret was killed

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: The part of Bushmanland formerly occupied by //kábbo. Given by /han≠kass’o (L VIII.-14. 7215-7217).
A place called '||gubo' by the |xam is called 'Blaauwpits' by the 'Bastaards' because the rocks there are black slate. ||gubo is also ||kabbo's (Jantje Tooren's) place.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Places of the |xam

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: ||xuobbeten is carried away by the lion while she sleeps. It bites her head and kills her. It puts her in its mouth and carries her down to the water. The people name the water '||xuobbeten' because it has no bushes.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: ||xuobbeten and the lion

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: A story about the wind and the rain and the hunting of springbok. People who live facing the rain get their weapons wet, causing bowstrings to break. When the children shoot windward at the herd of springbok, they quickly turn and run leeward. The speaker intends to go and wait at the springbok's water
course or footpaths where they will turn and run along. The springbok must be driven by the women in the evening because they go leeward and behave better when it is cool.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Wind, weather and springbok hunting

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: Names of Trees and Plants, and other information regarding them, given partly in Bushman by and partly in English after /han≠kass’o (L VIII.
14. 7219 rev. and 7220 rev., note, 18. 7552 rev.

7833, 7835, 7847, 23. 8061 rev., 8062 rev. and 8063 rev.,8073 rev., 29. 8601 rev., 8606 rev., 8613 rev., 30. 8637 rev., 31. 8728 rev., 8790, 8791, 8789 rev.). The !kwana thorn tree (and bush) scratches and wounds people who do not wear trousers when they hunt porcupine in the bushes at night.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: !kwana
The thorn tree

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: The springbok resemble the water of the sea. There are so many of them the Dutch ('Boers') soon exhaust their ammunition shooting them.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The springbok resemble the water of the sea

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: The people laugh at the jackal because it is intelligent and timid.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The intelligence and timidity of the jackal

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: The mother springbok makes sounds to her kid as she travels and the young springbok responds: the mothers grunt and the kids bleat.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Springbok ewes and lamb's cries

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: The behaviour of male and female springbok and various hunting strategies.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Doings of the springbok and springbok hunting

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: |han≠kass'o's explanation of the term !nanna

sse: people put bones in a heap in a number of places. Different people take their finished bones and put them in the same place. Much is doneopposite the house of the man who shot the springbok. These practices ensure that the man who shoots springbok will not miss on the hunting
ground when next he hunts.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: !nanna
sse

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: The women must not eat meat from the shoulder blades of the springbok, or the arrows will miss the game. This is called 'when we shoot our death'.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Missing the game

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: The springbok possess magic or invisible arrows which make people ill. Little children are not allowed to play on the springbok's skin, because the springbok gets under the people's flesh and makes them ill.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Springbok possess magic arrows

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: A description of the springboks' bones and the |xam names given to them.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Springbok bones

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: The Bushmen anoint their heads with //hára (which is black and sparkling), mixed with fat, and rub their bodies with ttò. (L VIII.
7276 rev., note). Ttò or 'Roode Klip' is dug out from the mountain side. Precautions to be taken against sorcerers upon these occasions. (L VIII.
14. 7275 and 7276, 7279 and 7380). hara tto. ||hara Tto
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: ||hara Tto

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: The Bushmen anoint their heads with //hára. (which is black and sparkling), mixed with fat, and rub their bodies with ttò. (L VIII.-14. 7272 rev.,-7276 rev., note). Ttò or 'Roode Klip' is dug out from the mountain side. Precautions to be taken against sorcerers upon these occasions. (L VIII.-14. 7275 and 7276, 7279 and 7380).
An account of how tto (rooi klip) is obtained. When the people collect tto, they pound it and then anoint themselves with the mixture as protection against the sorcerers at the tto mine.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Tto tto

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: |han≠kass'o's grandfather Tsatsi puts different kinds of bones away in the sticks of the hut to avoid wounding the first finger of his right hand. If the bones are not treated properly and are eaten by the dogs, he will be wounded and will not be able to shoot properly.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Tsatsi's treatment of bones

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: |han≠kass'o's father
in
law, ||kabbo ('Dream' or Oud Jantje Tooren), throws bones away, and |han–kass'o does the same because he has married into the family.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: ||kabbo's treatment of bones

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: Names of various Bushmen and Bushman women, with information regarding them. Partly in Bushman by and partly in English after /han≠kass’o (L VIII.-1. 6078-6081, 4. 6370 rev., note, 11. 6969 rev., note 14. 7278 and 7277 rev., 20. 7749 and 7750, 7750 rev., 7748 rev. and 7749 rev., 27. 8437, 8435 rev. and 8436 rev., 31. 8744 rev., 8772 rev., 32. 8808 rev.).
For example, p.7277v tells of a man who became paralysed and lost the use of an arm while carrying a springbok.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: |xam names

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: The hunter is unable to kill a springbok if his companion has been killed. His arrows miss the springbok and if an arrow does hit the springbok it runs on as if not wounded. The women shave parts of the hunter's head (over the temples). This ensures that the springbok will come straight up to the hunters so they can shoot it at close range.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Unsuccessful springbok hunting after death of companion (means employed to make it more fortunate)

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: Sorcerers shoot with invisible arrows, causing illness. The sick man. The aid of the old women to be sought. By /han≠kass’o (L VIII.-14. 7287 and 7288; 15. 7289-7295).
The wounded person feels pain and weariness. The old women 'snore' sick people and remove what ails them. Once 'snored' the person will again feel comfortable.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Sorcerers shoot with invisible arrows, causing illness
Covers and first pages of Lloyd's Book VIII
15 or BC151_A2_1_090

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: The handsome child, who is ill, is not to be sent to fetch water. By /han≠kass’o (L VIII.-15. 7296-7298).
When a 'good-looking' or handsome person is ill he is taken care of because of his appearance.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: When a good
looking person is ill

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: The sorcerers see a handsome person and cause him to be ill. The dogs cannot sleep for barking at the sorcerers, and the sick man dies, although he has been doctored. (L VIII.-15. 7298-7303).

When a good-looking or 'handsome' person falls ill and dies, the !giten (sorcerers) seize that person. Every time he seems to get better they 'shoot' (bewitch) him again, making him ill, and he never recovers. Their arrows kill people even when they are being 'snored'.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Sorcerers are like lions

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: Some sorcerers are said to eat the flesh of the dead. (L VIII.
7306). !giten !giten !giten !giten
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: What sorcerers eat

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: The story of |kuken
|u |unu (a caterpillar, larva of Aloa) who was formerly a person of the Early Race. |kuken
|u |unu curses a girl and she falls ill. |kuken
|u |unu pretends to die and the girl dies after him and they are buried. The people move to a different watering
hole and |kuken
|u |unu digs up the girl's body and eats her. He follows after the people and repeats this process a number of times, cursing and eating different girls.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The story of |kuken
|u |unu

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: harriten
The | bird is found in Bushmanland and resembles a crow.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: |harritan
, the locust bird

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: kuken
|u |unu Aloa
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: kuken-|u |unu
Concerning the |, which is found abundantly, in Bushmanland

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: The manner of carrying firewood. By|han≠kass’o (L VIII.
15. 7360 rev. and 7361 rev., note).
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Manner of carrying firewood

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: A lion sits waiting for the sun to set so he can stalk people. The people lie down to sleep and the lion steals up on them and drags |a!karaken into the grove. The people name the grove '|a!karaken's grove' after |a!karaken who was carried there by the lion.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: |a!karaken killed by a lion

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: An insert containing an address to an old woman in which she is asked where she grew up as a child and what the place's name is. It asks her who her friends (or companions) were, and what her people's names are.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Oh old woman! At what place did you grow up?
Covers and first pages of Lloyd's Book VIII
16 or BC151_A2_1_091

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: An account of the hunting of porcupine and the practices that ensure its success (such as the treatment of their bones). The hunter is 'worked on' by the women before he goes to seek porcupine. The porcupine goes about only at night and remains inside its hole when the place is bright.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Porcupine hunting

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: The people wait for the porcupines to return to their hole and kill them as they return, including the female porcupine who returns last. Different members of the family get given meat from different porcupines and parts of porcupines.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The little porcupine

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: Various parts of the porcupine are given to specific people in the group, for instance the wife of the man who killed the porcupine eats its tail. The hunter and the children eat its shoulder meat.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Distribution of porcupine meat

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: Names for certain bones, etc. (L VIII.-16. 7401 and 7402).
|xam names and descriptions of various bones and tendons (found in animals).
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Words and sentences: names of bones

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: Porcupine's bones are gathered together and placed on an ostrich breastbone and pouredopposite the hut's entrance.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Treatment of bones

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: Different customs concerning the eating of the Porcupine. (L VII.-6. 6590 rev.-6594 rev.). Certain persons not allowed to eat the tail of the Porcupine. (L VIII.-16. 7405-7409, 7408 rev. and 7409 rev.). A part of the Porcupine is used to prevent the evil consequences of eating !kùï. (L VIII.-16. 7450 rev., note).
A story describing the habits of porcupines and the eating of them. The porcupine seeks food away from its hole and returns to a different hole.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Habits of porcupines

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: Different customs concerning the eating of the Porcupine. (L VII.-6. 6590 rev.-6594 rev.). Certain persons not allowed to eat the tail of the Porcupine (L VIII.-16. 7405-7409, 7408 rev. and 7409 rev.). A part of the Porcupine is used to prevent the evil consequences of eating !kùï. (L VIII.-16. 7450 rev., note).
Only old people and married women with their own huts can eat the tail safely.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: A girl does not eat porcupines' tails

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: A description of the preparation, cooking, eating and distribution of porcupine meat among the people. The men eat from the backbone, because they want the most meat to be given to the children.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Method of cooking and eating porcupine

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: The Rain believed to be ridden by sorcerers. By /han≠kass’o (L VIII.-27. 8399 rev. and 8400 rev., note). When the Rain is angry with anyone, people may be carried off in the whirlwind, and various transformations effected. The young women should propitiate a water pit, by means of 'buchu' and ttò. (L VIII.-16. 7418-7428.)

The old people say that when the rain is angry it wants to kill people. It takes the man who made it angry, and all his people, and turns them into frogs at the pond. Their karosses and quiver skins become springboks and their sticks become bushes.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Rain changes people into frogs

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: The porcupine's hole is stone on the outside and earth on the inside.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Porcupine's hole

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: When the people go digging for porcupine they pluck off its quills at its hole and place them neatly ('nicely') together so that the wind will not disperse them.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Digging for porcupine

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: The people fear the rain's animals because they are things the rain has put aside for its meat. They are the cobra, the puffadder, the tortoise and the great water tortoise.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Rain's animals

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: A young woman of the Early Race is carried off by the Rain in the form of a bull. By /han≠kass’o (L VIII.-16. 7434-7448).

The Rain courted a young woman of the Early Race, because of her scent. The young woman climbs onto the Rain's back and he starts to take her away to his home (the water-pit). The young woman rubs buchu on the Rain, which makes him fall asleep and she steals away from the Rain and returns home.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: A young woman of the Early Race of people carried off by the Rain, in the shape of a bull

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: Frogs are not to be killed, lest drought ensue. An exhortation, to the Bushmen, to be careful of food in time of plenty, is followed by a description of the jackal’s doings with regard to food, etc. (L VIII.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Rain protects frogs

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: An exhortation, to the Bushmen, to be careful of food in time of plenty, is followed by a description of the jackal’s doings with regard to food, etc. (L VIII.-16. 7449-7451, 7448 rev.-7450 rev., and 7452-7456).

When food is plentiful (in times of abundant rainfall) the people say that they must put the food away properly so they will not be like the jackal, which is always going along looking for where it has put its food (its 'plenty').
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Habits of jackals

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: Little children, among the Bushmen, are not allowed to eat the heart of the Jackal, on account of its great timidity. The heart of the Leopard may, on the contrary, be eaten by them. By /han≠kass’o (L VIII
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Children do not eat jackal's hearts

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: A description of some barter, containing allusion to the ill effect of eating Jackals’ hearts (L VIII.-16. 7456 rev.-7458 rev., 7460, note).
|han≠kass'o's maternal grandfather (Tsatsi) is given a dog by |gappem-ttu and it kills many jackals. Tsatsi gives a kaross to |gappem-ttu for giving him a dog that kills so many jackals.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Children do not eat jackal's hearts
Notes (to )

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: The Rain, in the form of an Eland, shot by one of the early race of people (which preceded the Bushmen in their country). The disasters which follow. By /han≠kass’o (L VIII.-16. 7461 and 7462, 17. 7463-7472).

A man of the Early Race hunts the Rain (which was formerly an eland) as it grazes. The next day the people try to roast the meat, but it vanishes on the fire and the Rain traps them in their hut. They become frogs and hop away.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The Rain, in the form of an eland, shot by one of the Early Race of people; and the disasters which followed
Covers and first pages of Lloyd's Book VIII
17 or BC151_A2_1_092

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: The Girl (of the Early Race) who killed the Children of the Rain, bringing, thereby, severe punishment upon herself and those who lived with her. By /han≠kass’o (L VIII.-17. 7473-7519).

A girl kills and eats a Water child, tidying up before her mother comes home. This happens a number of times, and eventually the Rain becomes angry and makes a whirlwind gather the hut and the girl into the pond, where she becomes a frog.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The girl of the Early Race who killed the children of the Rain

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: The names and some descriptions of millipedes and millipede
like insects.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Words and sentences: names of millipedes

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: The girl of the Early Race who killed the children of the Rain'
|han≠kass'o was told the story ' when, as a child, he complained about being given too little to eat.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The girl of the Early Race who killed the children of the Rain
The occasion on which the story was related to |han≠kass'o

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: |han≠kass'o's maternal grandmother, ≠kammi, was lean with starvation during the drought in their country, and his grandfather almost died from starvation during the same drought. The children were the ones who ran the steenbok down in the sun until they collapsed from the heat ('the sun is killing' them).
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The drought which caused |han≠kass'o's grandparents to starve

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: Children push a youth into the skin of a Fieldmouse and tell him to 'trot away', which he does, becoming a Lion. The children tell the Lion to go and lie down, which he does. The Lion charges the people and runs at his brother's wife, biting her in the head and dragging her into the reeds.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Young man of the Early Race put into a mouse skin and becomes a lion

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: The Mantis, the valiant Striped Mouse , the other Mice, and the Beetle . By /han≠kass’o (L VIII.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The Mantis, the Mice and the Beetle

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: A note describing different types of grasses found in Bushmanland, as well as various kinds of brushes (used for wiping the face).
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Grass in Bushmanland that resembles brushes
Covers and first pages of Lloyd's Book VIII
18 or BC151_A2_1_093

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: Two brothers succesfully hunt Lions with bones, until the younger brother goes out hunting alone and is killed. The elder brother waits at home for his younger brother and the Lions come and kill him.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Men who hunted lions with bones

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: A description of two edible plants found near water in Bushmanland.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Edible plants found near water

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: uha ke
||kamminya
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: uha
A waterpool called |

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: (Further details of the story of the men who hunted with bones.) The elder brother waits at home for his younger brother to return from hunting Lions. He sees the Lion's eyes shining and thinks they are stars and they approach and seize him. There follows a discussion of the bones the brothers made into knobkerries in order to hunt Lions.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Men who hunted lions with bones
Further details of

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: Some beliefs of the Bushmen with regard to clouds and wind, etc. (L VIII.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Clouds and wind

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: The ||ua (Fox) speaks, saying 'Thou art thinking thou art awake' and makes the Koranna sleep, even though they are supposed to be keeping watch.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Koranna commando destroyed by ||ua

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: |han≠kass'o speaks of the guns brought by the Koranna to his people's place when they acquired cattle. Before then the Koranna had used blades.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The Korannas brought guns (while they felt that they had not a little cattle)

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: All things were once people. They became beasts of prey when the Anteater and the Lynx cursed each other.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Beasts of prey were once people

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: Sneezing believed to be a sign that the name of the person who sneezes has been uttered. By /han≠kass’o (L VIII.
18. 7594 rev. and 7595 rev., note).
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Sneezing

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: The !kwái–!kwái, the Mantis, and the Children. The !kwái–!kwái, who was formerly a man, and is now a bird (in appearance somewhat resembling a 'duiker'), comes, during the absence of their parents, to kill the children. They are defended by the Mantis, who causes the death of !kwái–!kwái. By /han≠kass’o (L VIII.
6333). A note to the above story was also given by /han≠kass’o (L VIII.
18. 7596, 7597 and 7595 rev.). !kwai !kwai !kwai !kwai
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The !kwai !kwai, the Mantis and the children
A note to the story of

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: Certain kinds of Food, used by Bushmen. By /han≠kass’o (L VIII.-1. 6107, 18. 7598-7601).
An account of the food (plants and berries) eaten by people throughout the year.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Food eaten by Bushmen (five types of berries and roots)

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: A girl is becoming a new maiden and goes to lie down (in her hut). She says the Baboon's name. The Baboon sings to her so that her face will change shape and resemble his own. The girl runs away to the Baboon, who waits on the hill. She marries him.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The girl, of the Early Race of people, who married a Baboon

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: The !kháü (a Lizard of the Genus Agama) who would not listen to the advice of his wife, and was carried off by a lion. By /han≠kass’o (L VIII.
7745). !khau !khau
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The !khau carried off by a Lion

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: The Lion can transform itself into a man. (L VIII-18. 7630 rev., note).
The lion puts its tail over its head and trots along as a man does, because it feels that it resembles a real man.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Lion turns into a man
Covers and first pages of Lloyd's Book VIII
19 or BC151_A2_1_094

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: Remarks concerning copy of Chipping, No. 4. (L VIII.
7642). The dots resemble those that the people paint onto other people's heads with tto (rooiklip, or haematite). The objects in figures 3 and 7 (of the same chipping) resemble mat sieves.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Notes on chippings, or, Chipping no. 4

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: The Two Lions, the Lizards, the Blue Crane, the Rhebok and the Crow. By /han≠kass’o (L VIII.-32. 8859-8878, 8848-8852, 19. 7643-7656).

Two Lions (!gu and his companion, !haue ta ≠hou) kill the lizards !khau and |gi. They carry their flesh to the home of the Blue Crane and her companion, the Rhebok |ke-dde (the wives of the dead lizards), pretending to be the dead husbands. |ke-dde and the Blue Crane escape, but the Blue Crane returns home to fetch her child and is killed. The Lions find the others (|ke-dde, ||horu and |ke-dde's child), who wait for the Lions on top of a bare rock and are protected by the stones. The Black Crow draws |ke-dde up with a thong and heats stones on the ground below her house. The Black Crow throws the thong down for the Lion, and the Lion falls down onto the hot stones and dies.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The two Lions, the Lizards, the Blue Crane, the Rhebuck, and the Black Crow

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: |han≠kass'o tells the story of the abuse of |gui
an (or Doortje) who was beaten by her mistress, Trina de Klerck and also by Trina's husband Jacob. Trina de Klerck had used a thong to beat |gui
an and her husband Jacob had beaten her with a heavy Bambush (bamboo) reed after which she fainted. After that beating |gui
an was unable to see properly.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: |gui
an (Dootje) and her mistress, Trina de Klerk

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: Information regarding narrator’s family. In English after and in Bushman by /han≠kass’o (L VIII.-1. 6052 and 6053, 19. 7671, 26. 8302 rev.).
Information about the younger brother of |han≠kass'o's grandfather Tsatsi, called !xein (or Dirk).
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Dirk (!xein, son of Dootje)

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: Regarding some Bushman dialects. By lhan≠kass’o (L VIII.-19. 7672-7675).

|han≠kass'o comments on his understanding of other |xam dialects, spoken by 'Berg (Mountain) Bushmen' and 'River Bed people'. He can understand their language (≠kakken-≠kakken) even when it is different, because they are his fellows. The language spoken by another group (the |ke |ke ||en) resembles that spoken by the Nama.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: |xam dialects ('Berg Bushmen' and 'River Bed people')
Covers and first pages of Lloyd's Book VIII
20 or BC151_A2_1_095

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: Information regarding //kunn was also given by /han≠kass’o (L VIII.-20. 7746-7749).
|han≠kass'o speaks of the rainmaker, ||kunn, (who he observed making rain fall) and his relations.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The rain sorcerer ||kunn; two of ||kunn's children

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: Names of various Bushmen and Bushman women, with information regarding them. Partly in Bushman by and partly in English after /han≠kass’o (L VIII.-1. 6078–6081, 4. 6370 rev., note, 11. 6969 rev., note 14. 7278 and 7277 rev., 20. 7749 and 7750, 7750 rev., 7748 rev. and 7749 rev., 27. 8437, 8435 rev. and 8436 rev., 31. 8744 rev., 8772 rev., 32. 8808 rev.).
A man called Old Bakkis was alive when |han≠kass'o went to the Breakwater Convict Station, but had died by the time he returned.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Oud Bakkis or 'one nose'

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: Names of various Bushmen and Bushman women, with information regarding them. Partly in Bushman by and partly in English after /han≠kass’o (L VIII.-1. 6078–6081, 4. 6370 rev., note, 11. 6969 rev., note 14. 7278 and 7277 rev., 20. 7749 and 7750, 7750 rev., 7748 rev. and 7749 rev., 27. 8437, 8435 rev. and 8436 rev., 31. 8744 rev., 8772 rev., 32. 8808 rev.).
Includes the story of !kui-!kaxu (or Pained Chest) who was so named because he married a woman called Tuain-an who 'chased him with fire' and did not want him when they got married (7750v).
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Concerning different Bushmen

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: Explanation of the Bushman name for a certain rock, with a description of its situation. (L VIII.
20. 7751 and 7752). Hartloof Kloof
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Concerning places and topographical features in |han≠kass'o's country; his father
in
law's place is ||gubbo

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: Illness, for which the Doctor is called in, believed to be caused by butterflies. The narrator’s personal experience of this. Bushman children not allowed to throw stones at butterflies. By /han≠kass’o (L VIII.
7752. rev. and 7753 rev.). !gixa
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: !giten
Butterflies and

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: The Bushman Doctor or Sorcerer (who may be of either sex). By /han≠kass’o (L VIII.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The 'Bushman doctor'

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: [not translated]
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: !kuerri |nan
The and the rain

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: [not translated]
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: ||kerri
The(locust bird)

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: [not translated]
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: !kaua doro and the lion

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: [The recto pages are not translated] The place the story occurred was shown to |han≠kass'o as a child by a man called !kou (it was his place), who also told him the name of the place (which sounded like !gao
sse).
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The scene of !kaua doro and the lion

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: The Mantis visits the abode of the Ticks, attempts to take some of their food, and is well beaten by them. He flies away, goes into the water, and returns home where he is pitied and lectured by the Ichneumon. (L VIII.-3. 6236-6258, 6267-6269). In a further account of the Mantis and the Ticks, the Mantis pays a visit to the houses of the Ticks, is worsted by them, and escapes. Having been counselled by /kwámmana, through the young Ichneumon, he goes again to the Ticks, gets the better of them, and brings their sheep home (L VIII.-20. 7790-7811).

|kaggen (the Mantis) visits the Ticks, who see him coming and hide in sheep's wool. |kaggen tastes some food from one of their pots and the Ticks beat him. He flies away and returns to his house, where |kwammana tells him how to defeat the Ticks.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The Mantis and the Ticks

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: ...the visit of //khwái–hemm (the All–devourer) to the Mantis. The latter, by means of the Porcupine, invites //khwái–hemm to visit him. He comes, and presently swallows /kwámmana and the Mantis. They are rescued by young /kwámmana and another child, who cut the monster open (L VIII.-20. 7812-7816, 22. 7906-7956). //khwái–hemm is stated, by /han≠kass’o (on the information of his mother /kábbi–an), to be the father of the Porcupine (L VIII.-10. 6934 rev., note).

|kaggen (the Mantis) tells the Porcupine (his son's wife) to go to her father (||khwai-hemm), but she is afraid because there is not enough to feed him. ||khwai-hemm says that he will visit |kaggen, because he must have enough food to offer if he has invited ||khwai-hemm. ||khwai-hemm comes and |kaggen tells him to stop eating things, as there is nothing else to eat. ||khwai-hemm becomes angry and swallows |kwammana and then |kaggen. The children then each cut open a different side of ||khwai-hemm's body, and |kwammana and |kaggen fall out.|kaggen (the Mantis) tells the Porcupine (his son's wife) to go to her father (||khwai-hemm), but she is afraid because there is not enough to feed him. ||khwai-hemm says that he will visit |kaggen, because he must have enough food to offer if he has invited ||khwai-hemm. ||khwai-hemm comes and |kaggen tells him to stop eating things, as there is nothing else to eat. ||khwai-hemm becomes angry and swallows |kwammana and then |kaggen. The children then each cut open a different side of ||khwai-hemm's body, and |kwammana and |kaggen fall out.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The Mantis and ||khwai
hemm
Covers and first pages of Lloyd's Book VIII
21 or BC151_A2_1_096

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: A list of |xam names of animals.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Words and sentences: |xam names of animals

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: |han≠kass'o identifies and describes various insects (and some animals) found in Bushmanland.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Names of insects and notes on some of them (at the South African Museum)

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: A ceremony performed with the Brachycerus (African Ground Weevil) in order to preserve young babies from convulsions. In the Katkop dialect by Díä!kwãin (L V.
5840) The Brachycerus used to cure illness in little children. By /han≠kass’o (L VIII.
7825). !nu !nurussi Brachycerus,
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Brachycerus
The used as a means of cure for little children; the same insect not used again when another child is ill

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: A reed necklace employed as a remedy for a little child suffering from a cold (L VIII.-21. 7826 and 7827).
The women break and burn pieces of reed in the fire.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: A necklace of reed used to cure a little child's cold

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: Names of Animals (L VIII.-1. 6047-6049, 21. 7828-7830, 7834, 7836-7838, 7841, 23. 8068 rev., 8070 rev., 25. 8260 rev., 32. 8811rev., 8875 rev.). Names of Trees and Plants, and other information regarding them, given partly in Bushman by and partly in English after /han≠kass’o. (L VIII.-14. 7219 rev. and 7220 rev., note, 18. 7552 rev.-7754 rev., 21. 7830-7833, 7835, 7847, 23. 8061 rev., 8062 rev. and 8063 rev., 8073 rev., 29. 8601 rev., 8606 rev., 8613 rev., 30. 8637 rev., 31. 8728 rev., 8790, 8791, 8789 rev.).
|han≠kass'o provides the names of various plants and animals found in Bushmanland, as well as notes on how they are used, and details about and descriptions of them.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Names of plants and animals and notes on their use

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: Words and sentences given by |han≠kass'o naming certain animals and common terms.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Words and sentences: names of animals and other terms relating to daily life

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: Stone-knives. By /han≠kass'o (L VIII.-27. 8434). Reed and stone used for cutting purposes. (L VIII.-26. 8313 and 8314. The power of cutting possessed by a reed and by quartz. (L. VII.-21. 7826 rev. and 7827 rev., note).
The reed is sharp and can cut and hurt people. Quartz also cuts people deeply.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The power of cutting possessed by the reed and quartz
Covers and first pages of Lloyd's Book VIII
22 or BC151_A2_1_097

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: The song of the Mother Rhinoceros (not translated), accompanied by notes on movements performed in the singing and dancing of it.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The song of the Mother Rhinoceros

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: !xen (Dirk) is afraid of the female steenbok, who has a baby steenbok, and throws dust in the steenbok's eyes to make it afraid of him (as he is of it).
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: !xen and the steenbok

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: A Bushman, who becomes faint from the heat of the sun on his way home, throws earth into the air, so that those who are home may see the dust, and come to help him. (L VIII.-22. 7961-7969

). There follows an explanation of how the men get into the state at which they need to send dust signals. A person sends dust signals when he feels he is dying and will not reach home ('dying it is').
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Dust signals, or, A man who becomes faint from the heat of the sun on his way home, throws up earth into the air, so that those at home may see the dust, and come to help him

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: Remarks concerning copies of Bushman Paintings, given by Colonel Durnfold to His Excellency Sir Bartle Frere. By /han≠kass’o (L VIII.-22. 7969-7972, 7974 and 7975, 7983-7993, 23. 7995-8004). The mode of shooting practised by the |núsa Bushmen. By /han≠kass'o (L VIII.-22. 7972-7974).
|han≠kass'o identifies and describes various groups of people (as they appear in a copy of rock painting no. 2).
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Notes on rock painting copy no. 2 (!nu'sa and other groups)

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: |han≠kass'o describes a group of people who are fighting each other (as they appear in a copy of rock painting no. 3). A man on horseback has stabbed another. The people ask the other people for tobacco and fear the white men.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Notes on rock painting copy no. 3

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: A springbok Sorcerer, named !guerriten–ddé, was mentioned by /han≠kass'o. !gixa'
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: !guerriten
dde

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: The ≠gebbi–ggu, as performed among the Grass Bushmen, was described by /han≠kass'o (L VIII.
22. 7978 and 7979). /goo ≠gebbi
gu
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: goo ≠gebbi
gu

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: The Grass Bushmen. (L V VIII.-22. 7968 rev. and 7969 re., 7976 and 7977, 7980 and 7981, 7980 rev. and 7081 rev.)
. A description of the Grass Bushmen and the names of places in their country. |han≠kass'o saw them at a place called 'Bushlice' and at another place there called |koro-tten.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: On the 'Children of shortness' (the 'Grass Bushmen')

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: Remarks concerning copies of Bushman Paintings, given by Colonel Durnfold to His Excellency Sir Bartle Frere. By /han≠kass'o (L VIII.-22. 7969-7972, 7974 and 7975, 7983-7993, 23. 7995-8004).
|han≠kass'o describes and explains copies of rock paintings (no.'s 5-7).
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Notes on rock painting copy no. 5, no. 6. and no. 7

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: The people of |han≠kass'o's country do not kill a white springbok, because they believe that the other springbok will disappear.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The slaying of a white springbok will cause the other springbok to disappear
Covers and first pages of Lloyd's Book VIII
23 or BC151_A2_1_098

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: Remarks concerning copies of Bushman Paintings, given by Colonel Durnfold to His Excellency Sir Bartle Frere.–By |han≠kass'o. (L VIII.-22. 7969-7972, 7974 and 7975, 7983-7993, 23. 7995–8004).
|han≠kass'o describes a copy of rock painting no. 8., in which there is a depiction of a rain-bull in the clouds.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Notes on rock painting copy no. 8: the rain and the rain
bull

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: Remarks concerning copies of Bushman Paintings, given by Colonel Durnfold to His Excellency Sir Bartle Frere. By /han≠kass'o (L VIII.-22. 7969–7972, 7974 and 7975, 7983-7993, 23. 7995-8004).
|han≠kass'o describes a copy of rock painting No. 9, in which he thinks that the people depicted are 'Kafirs', or black people.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Notes on rock painting copy no. 9

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: ||kunnu and other old men dream of rain, which speedily comes. (L VIII.-23. 8005-8010).
One of the rainmakers calls to the rain, addressing it, and asks that it may fall gently and not angrily (as the old men have dreamt).
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Dreams and rain

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: |han≠kass'o relates the story of the flood at Victoria West, observed by ≠kuken
an and |han≠kass'o's wife, Ssuobba
||ken (Sara), who were both at Victoria West at the time it happened. The rain carried all the things and the people away down the river bed and some where crushed by collapsing houses.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Flood at Victoria West

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: The people fear the rain that comes at night – it had come and flooded Victoria West, which was situated in a ravine. They make a large (male) fire in an effort to disperse the rain
clouds that gather overhead.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: People fear the darkness's rain

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: Clouds. Preparations to be made for the coming rain; the springbok to be watched for, etc. (L VIII.-23. 8018-8029).
Jackal clouds are rain-clouds and are black. The people prepare their houses for a downpour, the men bringing bushes and the women 'making nice' the house so that they will not get wet.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Jackal clouds

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: Clouds. Preparations to be made for the coming rain; the springbok to be watched for, etc. (L VIII.-23. 8018-8029).

The old men address the rain and the rain-clouds. The rain-clouds 'go along and are becoming black' ('jackal-clouds'). People fear the rain while on the hunting ground and desire the rain thats brings the springbok.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Mode of addressing rain

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: Horns to be burnt, when the weather looks very threatening. (L VIII.-23. 8030 and 8031).
The people burn the outer layer of the springbok's horn to make the rain-clouds disperse when they see that they threaten to bring angry rain ('make war').
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Horns burnt for rain

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: Young, unmarried women and girls must hide themselves from the rain. (L VII.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Young unmarried women and girls must be silent and hide from the rain

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: ||kábbo (father–in–law of /han≠kass'o) was a Mantis’s man (i.e. believed to possess these insects). By /han≠kass'o (L VIII.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: ||kabbo ('Oud Jantje Tooren'), a 'Mantis's man'

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: An account of the doings of the Mantis when an Eland has been wounded. The protection afforded by the Mantis to the Eland is also alluded by Díä!kwãin, in 'Rules to be observed when an Eland has been shot, etc.' (L VIII.-23. 8033-8039).

When an eland has been wounded, |kaggen (the Mantis) is angry with the people (he 'does not love us if we kill an eland'). He does various things to trouble the man who shot the eland and thus make the eland get up and live and not die from its wounds. Also, when the people shoot gemsbok, hares appear, and if people shoot the hares then the gemsbok will recover and live.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Doings of the Mantis when the eland has been wounded

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: Snake Poison. By /han≠kass'o (L VIII.23. 8040 and 8041).
The effects of poison from the puffadder and another animal or snake.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Poison of the puffadder

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: The Ratel (formerly a man of the Early Race (or !xwe ||na ss'o !kui) dances for the girls of the Early Race, who clap for him to continue dancing all day long. The mother of the girls becomes suspicious at their lack of success in collecting food and sends a little sister of the girls to accompany them. The Ratel dances for them and the little sister runs away, so he returns to where the elder sisters are still sitting and kills them.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The Ratel and the girls of the Early Race

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: A certain white substance found upon a bush, formerly said to proceed from the Moon. By /han≠kass'o (L VIII.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: A white substance and the Moon

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: The making of Clay Pots. By /han≠kass'o (L VIII.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The making of clay pots

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: |han≠kass'o describes the tactics used in hunting springbok (referring to a numbered picture), in which ostrich feathers attached to sticks are stuck into the small bushes to resemble a person and divert the herd.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Tactics in springbok hunting

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: How the Feather Brushes used in springbok hunting are prepared and smoked. By /han≠kass'o (L VIII.-23. 8073-8075, 8083 1/2 and 8083 1/2 rev.).
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The preparation of feather brushes used in springbok hunting

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: Certain names not to be uttered. By /han≠kass’o (L VIII.-23. 8071 rev.).
|han≠kass'o's grandfather (Tsatsi) told him that he should never say a star man's name (or a star's man's name).
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: We do not utter a star man's name

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: The coming of an owl is considered as a sign of the approach of a Lion. An insult offered by a little child, to a fly, is reported by the latter to the Lion, as disrespect shown to himself. This, the Lion waits to avenge, until the child is older. By /han≠kass’o (L VIII.-23. 8058 rev., 8060 rev., 8078–8080).

|han≠kass'o's grandfather (Tsatsi) told him that an owl comes to the people when a lion is about to come to try and catch them. Also, children should not exclaim or breathe out through their nostrils in a certain manner if a fly ('lion's fly') is nearby, because it would tell the lion that a child had made light of the lion.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: An owl believed to foretell the coming of the lion

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: The Lion is believed to possess the power of assuming other forms. (L VIII.-23. 8075-8077).
It assumes the form of a hartebeest because it wants the people to try and head it as if it were game. It also assumes the form of a person (and wears a kaross).
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The lion has the power of turning itself into other things

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: The children call the lion different names by day and by night and wish to avoid insulting (or slighting it).
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Children do not say the lion's name at night

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: The Wild Cat believed to possess the power of turning itself into a lion. By /han≠kass’o (L VIII.-23. 8080-8083, and 27. 8399 rev., note).
|han≠kass'o's grandfather (Tsatsi) told him that a wild cat turns itself into a lion when many of its kind have been killed by hunters.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: A wild cat, when many have been killed by a person changes itself into a lion and kills the slayer

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: |han≠kass'o describes his dream of a group of prisoners. He mentions some of their names and describes the composition of the group.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: |han≠kass'o's dream of a gang of prisoners

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: The digging
sticks used by men are not weighted with stones. By /han≠kass’o (L VIII.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Digging sticks used by men
Covers and first pages of Lloyd's Book VIII
24 or BC151_A2_1_099
Covers and first pages of Lloyd's Book VIII
25 or BC151_A2_1_100

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: The Lioness and her adopted daughter, Tssi–!kuára–Ihin. By /han≠kass’o (L VIII.-25. 8084-8169, 8171 and 8172, 25. 8173-8176).

The Lioness (in the times of the Early Race) decides to keep a baby girl that she finds and names it Biting-Torn-Away (or Tssi-!kuarra |hin), and she grows up. The Lioness tricks a child into sending her brother to her at night, but his grandmothers, !kwa-!kwa and !kwa-kau, are also there (they are people and also trees).
