The Lioness tries to find a way of catching the young man on his own, but Biting-Torn-Away protects him and warns him how to behave around her mother. Whenever the Lioness tells a lie when she is near the fire, !kwa-!kau and !kwa-!kwa crackle from within it, causing her to move away. The Lioness kills a gemsbok and Biting-Torn-Away and the young man go to help her. The Lioness places some of the meat into a thong that she twists around her body, and asks Biting-Torn-Away to help lift her up. While Biting-Torn-Away lifts her mother's arms, the husband stabs her exposed flesh with his knife. The young man returns to his own mother's house, bringing Biting-Torn-Away with him.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The story of Tssi
!kuara |hin (the Lioness and her adopted daughter)

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: Names for Colours, etc. Given by /han≠kass’o (L VIII.-7. 6601, 6606 and 6605 rev., 24. 8170).
The names of different colours given by |han≠kass'o (possibly, Lucy Lloyd thinks later in 1897, in response to a painted card).
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Words and sentences: names of colours

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: The Man of the Early Race, whose head was of stone, the Lioness, and the Children. By /han≠kass’o (L VIII.-25. 8177-8197).

A Lioness gathers together many of the people's children because she is an invalid and needs them to work for her. Ddi xerreten (a man of the Early Race who has a stone head) goes to her house and points out to the children the fires of their own people in different ravines, until they have all gone home.When the Lioness arrives at her house she asks Ddi xerreten where her children are and he says that they are not her children. The Lioness hurts her jaw on his stone head and is left sitting angrily at her house.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Ddi xerreten and the Lioness

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: |gwai (a person who was formerly a beast of prey and a man of the Early Race) kills his sister
in
law and his brother
in
law is angry with him and seeks revenge (the title implies that |gwai is caught and killed but it does not happen in the story).
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The story of |gwai (who killed his sister
in
law, and was killed by his brother
in
law)

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: ttu ttutten ttu ttutten
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Ttu ttutten
The (birds)

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: !gwiten

The Wild Dog (or ) is stingy ('niggardly') to his wife (when they were people of the Early Race). He gives his wife the lean male pig, but takes the fat sow for himself, and she becomes thinner and thinner. She makes soup for her brothers, using the lean meat and not the fat. The Wild Dog tells his wife she must cook the sow's meat for them, because her brothers are not used to eating what she is making for them. The wife refuses.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The !gwiten who was niggardly to his wife

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: !k'anni
The is an ornament worn by men and women. |han≠kass'o says they are beautiful and look like things from the sea.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: !k'anni
The is an ornament worn by men and women

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: The mouth of an Ostrich egg–shell not to be left open. By /han≠kass’o (L VIII.-25. 8234 rev. and 8235 rev.).
If an ostrich eggshell is left open (not stopped up with grass), the wind blows into its open mouth and a snake will go into the empty eggshell.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: An ostrich eggshell, left open, will attract snakes

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: The Lion, the Jackal, the Chersina angulata, and the Hyena. By /han≠kass’o (L VIII.
8251). Chersina angulata,
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The Hyena's revenge

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: The youth of the early race, who saved the lives of the people at home by warning them of the approach of a Koranna war party. By /han≠kass’o (L VIII.-25. 8251-8261, 26. 8262-8268).

A youth of the Early Race is seen by a commando of Korannas, so he acts as if he were a little child ('swaying about'). There is some debate among the Korannas as to whether to kill the child or not, but eventually they help him load up his water bottles and send him on his way. He returns home and tells his people what he has seen, and they leave for the mountains. The Korannas come, believing the people to still be there.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The youth (of the Early Race of people) who warned those at home of the approach of a Koranna commando
Covers and first pages of Lloyd's Book VIII
26 or BC151_A2_1_101

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: The Bushman’s opinion of snuff–taking. By /han≠kass’o (L VIII.-26. 8266 rev. and 8267 rev.).
The |xam believe that a person who takes snuff has his brain eaten up by tobacco until it disappears.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: A person who takes snuff: tobacco eats up his brains

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: /kannan, who warned the people in vain of the approach of a Koranna war party, and was the only one who escaped. By /han≠kass’o (L VIII.-26. 8269-8285).

A woman called |kannan sees a Koranna commando and returns home to warn her people. An old man insists that she has seen little ostriches and |kannan says she knows she has seen real people, but the people do not believe her. The Korannas attack them and |kannan alone survives the slaughter of her people.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The escape of |kannan from the Koranna commando

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: Mountain Bushman. By /han≠kass’o (L VIII.-22. 7982 rev.-7984 rev.). Regarding Mountain Bushmen. (L VIII.-26. 8280 rev.).

A note about the 'Mountain Bushmen' (!kaugen !k'e), who live in the mountain 'kloofs' (or valleys) on the side of the Tki (a river). Another group of |xam (or branch of the 'Mountain Bushmen', called the !kaugen ss'o !k'e) lives to the south of the 'Mountain Bushmen'.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Mountain 'Bushmen'

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: !nana-an
The hunters call to make a wounded springbok die (or 'lie down') quickly (). They call out differently for gemsbok and ostriches.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: !nana-an
: the custom of calling to the wounded springbok

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: Arrow making, and Arrow poisoning. By /han≠kass’o (L VIII.
8334). Two kinds of Arrow. (L VIII.
10. 6923 rev. and 6924 rev., note). Arrow heads, etc. (L VIII.
1. 6086 and 6087). Description of the spur, or barblet, sometimes added to the Arrow shaft by Bushmen. (L VIII.
8773, and 8767 rev., note). The adhesive substance used by Bushmen in making Arrows. Preparation thereof. (L VIII.
6091). The marking of Arrows. (L VIII.
8292). Arrow Bags. (L VIII. 30. 8663 rev., note). kwae tto
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The marking of arrows

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: Arrow making, and Arrow poisoning. By /han≠kass’o (L VIII.-26. 8293-8302, 8315-8334). Two kinds of Arrow. (L VIII.-10. 6923 rev. and 6924 rev., note). Arrow heads, etc. (L VIII.-1. 6086 and 6087). Description of the spur, or barblet, sometimes added to the Arrow shaft by Bushmen. (L VIII.-31. 8770-8773, and 8767 rev., note). The adhesive substance used by Bushmen in making Arrows. Preparation thereof. (L VIII.-1. 6088-6091). The marking of Arrows. (L VI

II.-26. 8289-8292). Arrow Bags. (L VIII. 30. 8663 rev., note). An account of the making of arrows, using reeds, feathers rubbed with |kuai juice, sinew, ||kho and an arrow-head. The next day the people poison the arrows, when it is cold and the people do not perspire.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Arrow
making

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: Certain serpents and tortoises supposed to be kept in store by the Rain. (L VIII.

16. 7431 rev. and 7432 rev.). For fear of arousing the wrath of the Rain, a certain kind of tortoise is not to be eaten by young unmarried men and women. The Rain to be addressed when it appears to be displeased. (L VIII.
8309. The manner in which the Rain is addressed by the old men. (L VIII.
26. 8304 rev. and 8305 rev., note).
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The rain (and eating tortoises)

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: ddabba-i
The term is used when parents educate their children so that they have understanding and do not do 'foolish actions'.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: ddabba-i
An illustration of the use of

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: The names of those who are dead must not be uttered by the children at night. (L VIII.-26. 8310–8312).

According to |han≠kass'o's grandfather (Tsatsi), when people die they become spirit-people. If the names of the dead (the old people) are called as if they are still alive, they will come and harm the living.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Life after death

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: Stone–knives. (L VIII.-27. 8434). Reed and stone used for cutting purposes. (L VIII.-26. 8313 and 8314). The power of cutting possessed by a reed and by quartz. (L. VII.-21. 7826 rev. and 7827 rev., note).
The people break off a piece of the reed and use it to cut already cooked meat (which is easier to cut).
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Skinning and cutting

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: Ssauken. A game played among the Bushmen, in which both sexes appear to take part. By /han≠kass’o (L VIII.-26. 8335-8350).
It seems to resemble a dance in the people's movements.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Ssauken
(a game)
Covers and first pages of Lloyd's Book VIII
27 or BC151_A2_1_102

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: The Vultures, their elder sister (who was a girl of the early race), and her husband. By/|han≠kass’o (LVIII.-27. 8351-8373).

The Vultures make a woman (of the Early Race) their elder sister and live with her at her house. The elder sister's husband (a man of the Early Race) scolds the Vultures for devouring all the food, and the next day his wife goes with him to the hunting-ground, where she must eat (as his sisters-in-law eat everything at home). The Vultures look for food and see a springbok lying on the ground. They eat the dead springbok, looking around them (for the husband) as they do so, and leave meat for their elder sister, who approaches.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The Vultures and their elder sister

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: Signs made by Bushmen in order to show the direction in which they have gone. By /han≠kass’o.(L VIII.-27. 8374-8386).

If a member of the group goes off and does not return in time, the others make marks (acting as pointers) in the earth by pushing their feet along the ground, and if they are travelling away they place grass near these marks. In a second part of the account, |han≠kass'o decribes the manner in which branches are 'reversed' and arranged upside down (green tops in the ground) in a certain manner pointing to where the people have gone.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Signs made on leaving a place

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: Concerning certain Kafirs from the northern side of the Orange River. (L VIII.27. 8387-8390).
The black people ('Kafirs') in |han≠kass'o's country live to the north (or the 'other side') of the Orange River. He calls them 'Kaal Kafirs' and describes some of their customs and doings.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Others living north of the Orange River

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: Mat sieves said to be generally made by the Bushmen, but skin sieves by the Grass Bushmen and the Koranna
Hottentots. In English, after Díä!kwãin (L V.
25. VI note). Sieves supposed also to be used by the early race. By /han≠kass’o (L VIII.
27. 8391 and 8392). !yuiten !haken
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Mat sieves

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: The Story of !kó–g!nuin–tára, wife of the 'Dawn’s–Heart' Star. By /han≠kass’o (L VIII.–-7. 8393-8432). In a note, in English, after the same narrator, the younger sister of !kó–g!nuin–tára is stated to belong to the Early Race (which preceded the Bushmen in their country), (L VIII.-6. 6546 rev., note).

The She-Hyena (who is jealous of !ko'-g !nuin-tara and her child) poisons !ko'-g !nuin-tara and she becomes a Lynx and trots away into the reeds. The She-Hyena adorns herself in !ko'-g !nuin-tara's ornaments and marries the Day's Heart star. The Day's Heart asks why his wife is not attending to the child. The younger sister goes to !ko'-g !nuin-tara so that she may feed her child, but !ko'-g !nuin-tara's memory of who she is becomes increasingly vague, and she advises her sister to no longer come. Meanwhile, the Day's Heart has discovered the deception and goes to his wife in the reeds. She charges out of the reeds, but stops for one of the goats that they have brought with them. The people hold her down and anoint her with goat's blood and she is returned to normal, except for her ears which remain long and pointed so that she can retain her good hearing.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The story of !ko'
g !nuin
tara, or, !ko'
g !nuin
tara and the Day's Heart star

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: A certain small portion of the flesh of the Hare is refrained from by the Bushmen. In English, after /han≠kass’o (L VIII.27. 8398 rev.).
The people believe this flesh is from the days when the Hare was formerly a person.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Eating hare's meat

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: The Wild Cat believed to possess the power of turning itself into a lion. By /han≠kass’o (L VIII.-23. 8080-8083, and 27. 8399 rev., note).
|han≠kass'o's grandfather (Tsatsi) told him that when the wild cat is killed and brought home, it turns into a lion and comes to kill the hunter who killed it.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Wildcat turns into a lion

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: The Rain believed to be ridden by sorcerers. By /han≠kass’o (L VIII.-27. 8399 rev. and 8400 rev., note).
|han≠kass'o was told by his elders that dead people (who come out of the ground) are those who 'rode the Rain' (when living) and thus do so again (they are rain-sorcerers).
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Dead people are those who rode the Rain

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: Manner of carrying a young baby in use among Bushman women. Partly in Bushman by and partly in English after /han≠kass’o (L VIII.27. 8406 rev., note).
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: How children are carried

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: Words and sentences given by |han≠kass'o.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Words and sentences

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: kko in

Names given to animals by the |xam, including notes on who uses them (men or women, children and so on). This includes the anteater (its other name), the springbok, the ostrich, the eland (called 'meat' by men), and the hartebeest. This story also includes information about a man whom |han≠kass'o knew, who possessed 'leanness' (or ).
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The names of animals

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: Making knives out of different types of stone, which are used for cutting.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Cutting with stone knives

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: The making of Clay Pots. By /han≠kass’o (L VIII.-23. 8054–8067). Fragments of Pottery. (L VIII.-27. 8436 and 8437).
|han≠kass'o describes and identifies a broken clay pot. He believes it has been used to boil meat.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The old clay pot

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: Names of various Bushmen and Bushman women, with information regarding them. Partly in Bushman by and partly in English after /han≠kass’o (L VIII.-1. 6078-6081, 4. 6370 rev., note, 11. 6969 rev., note 14. 7278 and 7277 rev., 20. 7749 and 7750, 7750 rev., 7748 rev. and 7749 rev., 27. 8437, 8435 rev. and 8436 rev., 31. 8744 rev., 8772 rev., 32. 8808 rev.).

The information includes comments regarding their relationship with |han≠kass'o, places in Bushmanland, and the names of white men (farmers). Also includes information about the death of a man called ||khwih.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Details about various people known by |han≠kass'o
Covers and first pages of Lloyd's Book VIII
28 or BC151_A2_1_103

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: What Bushmen do when an eclipse of the sun takes place. By /han≠kass’o (L VIII.-28. 8438-8441).
They strike sticks together, as well as shoes, to make the sun come out.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: What is done by the Bushmen (men and women) in an eclipse of the sun

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: The Moon is not to be laughed at. By /han≠kass’o (L VIII-–28. 8441-8443, 8446).
People say that the Moon becomes angry when they laugh at it. People thus call it |ßkuan ttu to show it respect to try and keep it from going into the sky. The Moon's wife is ||ko'on.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The Moon not to be laughed at

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: The Moon in search of his wife. By /han≠kass’o (L VIII.-28. 8443–8445).
The Moon returns home and finds that his wife ||ko'on is not there.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The Moon seeking his wife, ||ko'on

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: Prayer to the Stars. By /han≠kass’o (L VIII.-28. 8447-8449). Prayer of the narrator’s grandfather to the star Canopus. (L VIII.-28. 8452-8458).
People pray to the stars so that they will be able to see game (that their dogs will kill for them) on the hunting-ground at night.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Prayer to a star

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: The stars call out 'Tsau! Tsau!'. The people say that the stars are cursing the springbok's eyes for them. When the stars came out, |han≠kass’o's grandfather Tsatsi prayed to them, asking to exchange his hungry heart with the star's satisfied one so he might also be filled up.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: What the stars say

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: The winds which are supposed to appertain to different persons. (L VIII.-28. 8459-8465).

After the wind has blown and dies, the place becomes warm from the sunshine (its 'eye' is warm). The wind becomes cold when a man kills an animal (the killed thing's wind) and the people say that his wind is cold. When it is hot the wind is gentle and not strong like the other.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Wind and stars

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: Rain follows death. The method of protecting the grave. By /han≠kass’o (L VIII.-28. 8465-8467).

When a person dies the rain falls, washing away their footprints ('a person who rains'). The people cover the grave with bushes, after which they heap stones 'nicely' on top of the bushes to cover them.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Rain washes out a dead man's footsteps

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: |han≠kass'o's step
grandmother (Ttuai
an) joyfully adressed Canopus and Sirius when there was enough food to eat.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Sirius and Canopus

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: Explanation of various personal names was given, in the Katkop dialect, by Díä!kwãin (L V.
5607). Also, by /han≠kass’o (L VIII.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The calling of Ttuai
an's name

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: Making fire with two pieces of stick. By /han≠kass’o (L VIII. -28. 8471 and 8472).
The people make fire (when they have no tinderbox) using two pieces of stick (from a divided arrow). The tree used for tinder is a dry Doornboom (thorn tree) that lies dead on the ground.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Making fire with two pieces of sticks; and tinder
making

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: |han≠kass'o describes a military parade (at the Grand Parade in Cape Town)The soldiers (British) are standing in rows. He describes their manoeuvres ('they stood still, stood in rows') as well as the movements of a dog which eventually left the parade and returned home.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: A review on the parade

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: The two brothers, of the Early Race, who collected ostrich eggs, and were chased by Koranna-Hottentots. By /han≠kass’o (L VIII.28. 8486-8506).

A story of the Early Race about a man called !kotta-kkoe who always swallows the ostrich eggs he finds, instead of putting them away. !kotta-kkoe's younger brother is more sensible and puts away the eggs in his bag. They run away from some Korannas, but !kotta-kkoe's stomach tears open from the weight of the eggs and his entrails fall into the river. !kotta-kkoe calls out to the Korannas to stop trying to kill him, as he is already dying from the huge hole in his stomach. The Korannas go after the younger brother and !kotta-kkoe draws together the edges of his stomach with a Driedoorn branch and escapes with his brother.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: !kotta
kkoe, his brother, ostrich eggs and Korannas

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: A young man of the Early Race marries ≠nerru (also a person of the Early Race). They are out collecting 'Bushman rice' and fill their bag, so the husband asks |nerru to use her kaross. She does not want to and he snatches it away from her. ≠nerru's bowels come pouring down. She replaces her bowels and returns to her mother's house. Her husband comes along looking for his wife, but ≠nerru's mother is angry with him for his lack of understanding.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: ≠nerru and her husband

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: ≠nerru
A description of the bird (in contemporary times).
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: ≠nerru
Description of the
Covers and first pages of Lloyd's Book VIII
29 or BC151_A2_1_104

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: !yoa
ka
ttu, the Blue Crane, and the Girls of the early race. By /han≠kass’o (L VIII.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: !yoa
ka
ttu, the Blue Crane and the girls

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: The |xam talk with the body of their tongue, whereas the Europeans speak with the tip of their tongue.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Difference between |xam and European methods of articulation

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: !nu!numma–!kuíten, who fetches crying children. By /han≠kass’o (L VIII.-29. 8555-8560).
Parents threaten their misbehaving children with !nu !numma-!kuiten (or 'White Mouth'), who kills children who cry.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: !nu !numma
!kuiten

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: How a parrot can make the lateral click like a person. (L VIII.29. 8556 rev., note).
A parrot seen by |han≠kass'o in Mowbray sounds like a person, because it can make the lateral click.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Spoken of a parrot in the village of Mowbray

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: The Anteater, the young Springbok, the Lynx, and the Partridge, by lhan≠kass’o (L VIII.-29. 8561-8602).

An Anteater (a person of the Early Race) steals a female Springbok child and disappears into her hole. The Lynx tells the young Springbok (named !khoukau) that the Anteater is not her real mother and they leave together, but the Partridge sees them and tells the Anteater. The Anteater follows after the two, under the ground, popping her head up sometimes to see where they are. The Lynx makes a loop with his bowstring and throws it around the neck of the Anteater, pulling her from the ground. The Anteater curses the Lynx, saying that he shall be a Lynx and go about by night. The Lynx curses the Anteater, saying that she shall be an anteater by night.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The Anteater, the young Springbok, the Lynx and the Partridge

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: What the Springbok mothers sing when they are soothing their Springbok children.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The song of the Springbok mothers

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: The Quagga, who was poisoned by her husband, !kuinssi/kauöken. By /han≠kass’o (L VIII.-29. 8603-8614, 30. 8615-8627).

The Tortoise takes a piece of liver away from the baby Quagga and shares it with other animals, who agree that it tastes so good that it must be Quagga liver. They tell the young He-Dog that he must have married game and that he must kill her so that they can eat her. One of the Quagga children lets her tears fall into the cooking pots, which break. The young He-Dog marries another Quagga and the Quagga's parents hold a dance and trample the young He-Dog to death.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The Quagga who was poisoned by her husband, !kuin'ssi
|kauoken

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: An illness which scratches and affects the throat which does not cause death.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: !hamman-xu
An eruptive illness called

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: Certain spots, where the jackal, or the hyena, has been, avoided by Bushmen, for fear of skin disease. By /han≠kass’o (L VIII.29. 8584 rev.-8587 rev.).
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Avoiding where the jackal or the hyena have passed water
Covers and first pages of Lloyd's Book VIII
30 or BC151_A2_1_105

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: The Ostrich who ran away with #kainyatára and gave him as a husband to her daughter. By /han≠kass’o (L VIII. 30. 8628
8636). ≠kariten
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: ≠kainyatara and the Ostrich

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: The reason why the Ostrich is represented as speaking without making use of click. By /han≠kass’o (L VIII.-30. 8628 rev. and 8629 rev., note).
The ostrich does not click because its tongue is not long.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The reason why the ostrich does not click

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: ≠kágára and !haunu, who fought each other with lightning. By /han≠kass’o (L VIII.-30 8637-8648).

≠kagara (a bird who was formerly a man) goes to !haunu (who is a rain's person) to take back his younger sister (!haunu's wife) and return her to her parents. There follows a fight (with lightning and thunder) and blood issuing from the nostrils of !haunu.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: ≠kagara and !haunu

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: ≠kágára and !haunu, who fought each other with lightning. By /han≠kass’o (L VIII.-30 8637-8648).
See|han≠kass'o's grandmothers used to tell him that ≠kagara was fighting with !haunu in the east when the weather thundered and when the clouds resembled mountains and were thick.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: ≠kagara's fight with !haunu in the east

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: Black lightning kills people. It comes up on them without them seeing it.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Lightning which is black, it is that which kills us

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: Certain kinds of food not eaten by adults. By lhan≠kass’o (L VIII.-30. 8649 and 8650).
The |xam do not eat pigs, fish, little birds and many kinds of mice.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Certain kinds of food, said not to be eaten by adults

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: The Wildebeest, the Mice, the Quaggas and the Mantis. By /han≠kass’o (L VIII.–30. 8651–8667).

The Long-nosed Mice (who are foolish) are hunting Quaggas on the hunting-ground and the Wildebeest does several things to make their hunt unsuccessful, including trampling the Mice as the Quagga stampede. |kaggen (the Mantis) dreams of these things and talks to the Striped Mouse (who is clever). The Striped Mouse outsmarts the Wildebeest and shoots him.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The Wildebeest, the Mice, the Quaggas and the Mantis, or why the (black) Wildebeest has a white or light coloured tail

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: The !käin (formerly a man of the early race, and now a little bird which is said to resemble the Lanius collaris), the Ostrich, and the Lizard. By /han≠kass’o (L VIII.-30. 8668-8670).
The !kain snatches the Ostrich's (the toi) head-hair, because he is vain and covets it (the Ostriches are also people of the Early Race). The !khau snatches the hair and pulls it over his own head.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The !kain who snatched off the hair of the Ostrich's head, and put it on his own head

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: The !kháü (a lizard of the genus Agama) and his daughter, the Mice, and the Mantis. By /han≠kass’o (L VIII.30. 8671
8736). Agama
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Agama
The Lizard, the Mice and the Mantis (includes the song of the lizard)
Covers and first pages of Lloyd's Book VIII
31 or BC151_A2_1_106

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: The admiration of Bushman women for the horse. The sound of the cantering of horses imitated by them. By /han≠kass’o (L VIII.-31. 8737-8740).
The people say that the horse canters, or dances because it feels proud on account of the women's admiration.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: How the Bushman women show their admiration for the horse

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: The admiration of Bushman women for the horse. The sound of the cantering of horses imitated by them. By /han≠kass’o (L VIII.-31. 8737-8740).
The women sit with a rolled up kaross between their knees and slap it making the sound of the horse.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: !kuppen
(imitation of the sound of horses)

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: Various modes of cursing in use among the Bushmen. By /han≠kass’o (L.VIII.-31. 8741-8743).
The people say 'Graveman!', 'Departed One!' and 'Be killed!' when cursing another man, wishing the other party to die.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Cursing

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: The Rain–maker and Sorcerer, /kaùnu. (L VIII.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: !gixa
The (sorcerer) |kaunu

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: Names of various Bushmen and Bushman women, with information regarding them. Partly in Bushman by and partly in English after /han≠kass’o (L VIII.-1. 6078-6081, 4. 6370 rev., note, 11. 6969 rev., note 14. 7278 and 7277 rev., 20. 7749 and 7750, 7750 rev., 7748 rev. and 7749 rev., 27. 8437, 8435 rev. and 8436 rev., 31. 8744 rev., 8772 rev., 32. 8808 rev.).
|han≠kass'o sees a photograph of a man called xu gwai who he thinks resembles a man called !nwa !koro. |han≠kass'o provides the names of some of his relations and information about them.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: A photograph of Xu gwai reminding |han≠kass'o of !nwa !koro

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: The male Ostrich believed to possess the power of returning once to life. (L VIII.31. 8750 rev.-8752 rev.).
The male ostrich is the one who returns to life after it has died and is called ||khabbi-ssin. The hen ostrich really dies and does not return to life.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Regarding the living again of male ostriches

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: berre berre
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Locusts

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: The locusts (with the locust birds which accompany them) are set free by Sorcerers. Stones not to be thrown at the locusts. (L V.-21. 5708-5719 1/2) (L VIII.-31. 8754-8758).

|han≠kass'o and ||hoaken !khe were told by |han≠kass'o's grandfather not to throw stones at locusts. A second part of the story concerns |kaunu who says 'locusts come out' when he wants to drive the locusts with the children.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Throwing stones at locusts

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: Locust birds not to be molested; etc. By /han≠kass’o (L VIII.-31. 8763-8765, 8763 rev. and 8764 rev.).
|han≠kass'o's grandfather ordered him not to throw stones at the locust birds, for if he did the locusts (and the locust birds) would disappear.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Locust birds

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: About |han≠kass'o's maternal grandfather Tsatsi (Tsa t'ssi), who was a passionate man (which is why he was never a 'sorcerer' or 'doctor'). He only ever listened to |han≠kass'o's mother. Tsatsi said that his daughter had softened his heart towards the people as he would have shot at them, because they had not acted nicely in his opinion.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Tsatsi

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: kuken
The name of the barblet (||) on the stems of arrows that catch in the flesh of the shot animal.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: kuken
The || and ostrich feathers

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: //kuken,

The people take a long ostrich wing feather and cut off the root to make a or barblet, that makes the arrow stick fast in an animal's flesh. The poison on the barblet dissolves off the barblet into the flesh.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: kuken
The ||

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: Names of portions of the body of an animal. By lhan≠kass’o (L VIII.-31. 8774, 8772 rev. and 8773 rev.).
|xam words and sentences, which appear to refer to parts of the body.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Words and sentences

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: A partly translated story about a man hunting gemsbok, sees a transformed lion and steps on his poisoned arrow, which pierces his foot, poisoning him.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Gemsbok hunting

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: Bushman terms for various degrees of relationship. Given by /han≠kass’o (L VIII.-31. 8788-8790, 32. 8792 and 8793, 8845-8847). Terms for various relationships by marriage. (L VIII.-12. 7067 rev. and 7068 rev., 32. 8794 rev.).
Words and sentences concerning relationships and what people call their various relatives, as well as terms for plants and animals. (Some given by !nanni and Tamme.)
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Relationships and other words (words and sentences)
Covers and first pages of Lloyd's Book VIII
32 or BC151_A2_1_107

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: Bushman terms for various degrees of relationship. Given by /han≠kass’o (L VIII.
8847). Terms for various relationships by marriage. (L VIII.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Terms of relationship

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: The Blue Crane, the two Lions, and the Mantis. In this story, the Blue Crane, while searching for the Frog’s husband, is killed and eaten by the Lions, and restored to life by the Mantis. By /han≠kass’o (L VIII.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: How the Blue Crane vainly sought for !kuommain |ka ||kau, was killed and eaten by the Lions, and restored to life by means of one of the bones of the Mantis (Part 2)

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: A note about the two Lions, !gu and !haue ta ≠hou. !gu eats people, but !haue ta ≠hou does not and is usually the one who scolds !gu about his doings.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Note on the two Lions

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: People give each other nicknames. For example Soppie (or Hendrick) was so called (by Andries, or !kaogen
≠kakken) because he poured soup down himself.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The giving of nicknames

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: The Frog, the Blue Crane, the Frog’s husband, and the Beetle. By /han≠kass’o (L VIII.-32. 8812-8820).

A tale of the Early Race in which the Frog (!ga) marries !kuommain |ka ||kau, but is embarrassed to relieve herself in front of him. Her body swells up and the Blue Crane makes a hole which the Frog vomits into. !kuommain |ka ||kau returns home and asks where the child is (his swollen wife had appeared as if pregnant). !kuommain |ka ||kau jumps up and runs away.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: !ga ka Kkumm. The Frog's story (Or, The Frog, the Blue Crane, the Beetle, and !kuommain |ka ||kau) (Part I)

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: The Young Woman of the early race whose breast was caught in a cleft of the rock. Her escape from the Two Lions. By /han≠kass’o (L VIII.-32. 8821-8842).

A tale of the Early Race in which a lazy young woman's breast gets stuck in the cleft of a rock. The two Lions (!haue ta ≠hou and !gu) approach her (intending to kill her), but she convinces them to go and drink water before eating her. She commands the water to 'Go away yonder!' and the Lions follow it in vain. She cuts off her nipple, releasing her breast from the rock, and pounds it together with !kai from the Lions' bag to make two balls which she leaves at the rock. When the Lions return they wonder where the girl has gone. Her nipple ball answers 'I am her!'. The two Lions spend the night trying to catch the girl and hurting their teeth biting at the rocks.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The young woman who disobeyed her mother, and fell in with the two Lions (!haue ta ≠hou and !gu)

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: A note describing how birds (and specifically crows) await the death of a thing by sitting opposite it.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Birds await the death of a thing

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: horu kochelman, !khau.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Note on lizards

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: The Young Woman of the early race whose breast was caught in a cleft of the rock. Her escape from the Two Lions. By /han≠kass’o (L VIII.-32. 8821-8842).
She sings 'My nipple shall grow into shape again' so that her breast will return to the way it had been (before it got caught in the rock).
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The song of the young woman, as she returned home

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: Bushman names for Stars. Given by /han≠kass’o (L VIII.-32. 8826 rev., 8842 and 8843, 8841 rev. and 8842 rev.).
The stars (in Orion's belt) are named according to the hunting of springbok.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Some of the stars (their names)

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: The Wife’s Parents. By /han≠kass’o (L VIII.-32. 8843-8845).
The way in which sons-in-law speak to their parents-in-law.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The father
in
law and the mother
in
law

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: Bushman terms for various degrees of relationship. Given by /han≠kass’o (L VIII.-31. 8788-8790, 32. 8792 and 8793, 8845-8847). Terms for various relationships by marriage. (L VIII.-12. 7067 rev. and 7068 rev., 32. 8794 rev.).
Some of these terms seem to be spoken by men or women and apply to relations of different genders and ages.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Relationships

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: Forms of Salutation used by Bushmen. By /han≠kass’o (L VIII.
8857, 8852 rev.). kuanna
i
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Greetings among the Bushmen (and times of the day)

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: Miscellaneous words and sentences given by |han≠kass'o.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Words and sentences
Covers and first pages of Lloyd's Book III
1 or BC151_A2_1_125

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: A good many genealogical notes and portions of Bushman family history have been taken down (B II. 349, 359 rev., 360-362, 364, 365 368-373, 376; BXXV. 2352, 2412 and 2416; L III.-1. 476-506; L IV.-1. 3452 and 3453; L VI.-1. 3895 and 3896.) From some of these materials, and from other sources, twelve genealogical diagrams (in oblong double folio) have been compiled, each giving all the known ancestors of one individual, frequently extending four, and sometimes five generations back.

||kabbo (and possibly also |han≠kass'o and |a!kunta) give names (|xam and other) and biographical details of their relations and some other people from their country. There are poignant notes relating how some of them died and their experiences with white people.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Genealogies

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: ||kabbo's maternal grandfather Ttono wo was killed by an adult rhinoceros. The names of some of Ttono wo's children are listed, with details of their personal history.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Genealogies: Ttono wo (who was killed by a rhinoceros)
Covers and first pages of Lloyd's Book IX
1 or BC151_A2_1_108

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: Philip' or Auma gives words in his language to Lloyd at the Grey library.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: From 'Philip' June '77 at Grey Library

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: A 'Hottentot' (or !Ora

speaker) called Auma (Philip, or Jaco'bama) provides Lucy Lloyd with words and sentences in a !Ora dialect. This includes his other names and those of some members of his family as well as parts of the body, numbers, weapons and other items from daily life.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Words and sentences: given by Auma (Hottentot, Namaqua and Setschuana)
Covers and first pages of Lloyd's Book XI & XII
1 or BC151_A2_1_109

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: A list of words and phrases in !kun (or the language of the Ongova of Hereroland, or present
day Namibia).
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Words in the dialect of the !kun or so
called 'Ongova Bushmen' of Hereroland

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: !nanni and Tamme contribute words and sentences, mainly furnishing the !kun names of animals that they saw in the South African Museum as well as some other vocabulary.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: September 1st, 1879, South African Museum (from !nanni and Tamme)

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: !nanni and Tamme (at Mowbray) contribute words and sentences relating to everyday life in their country. Some words have been given in Herero, but there are also references to other groups of people in the area, such as the Ovaherero and the Makoba (and what they call things).
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Words and sentences: given by !nanni and Tamme in Mowbray

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: !nanni and Tamme contribute words and sentences relating to everyday life in their country. There is a lot of information regarding food, what plants and animals are eaten by the !kun, other groups in their country, and animals. There are fragments of songs and names and descriptions of celestial bodies, plants and animals, as well as a general vocabulary. |han≠kass'o has provided various |xam words (often equivalents to the !kun words) on the verso pages. Some of the terms appear in other languages heard in !kun country, such as Makoba and Damara.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Words and sentences: given by !nanni and Tamme

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: sho sho sho sho
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Song of the sho sho

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: Tamme and !nanni both give the song of the ||ku, which they both heard from older people. !nanni heard it from a man called |kuirri, of his grandfather's people, and Tamme heard it from his uncle ≠namm
she. The ||ku is a small wild animal that resembles a jackal and eats ants and is found in the !kun country. Neither song has been translated.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Song of the ||ku

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: !nanni tells the song of the !kan ||ka ||karashe. This is a small animal eaten by the !kun which scratches out food from the ground called ||kauru.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Song of the !kan ||ka ||karashe

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: The names of some of Tamme's and !nanni's relations, living and dead.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Family trees

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: Tamme (and possibly !nanni) describes some of the things eaten by the !kun (and in particular by his father).
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Things eaten by the !kun
Covers and first pages of Lloyd's Book XI & XII
2 or BC151_A2_1_110

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: Tamme contributes words and sentences relating to everyday life in his country. The list includes !kun terms for weapons (especially arrows and arrow

making), parts of the body, plants and animals, cooking utensils, colours, numbers, weather, relations and words gained from contact with Europeans (such as tinderboxes and whipping). The names of !nanni's four brothers and sisters are noted and there are other references to the boys' personal experiences, including a fragment of a song !nanni sings when weeding, an occasional mention of the boys' parents, how |han≠kass'o 'takes' Tamme to 'sleep', how Tamme's father is dead and so on. |han≠kass'o has provided |xam equivalents for some of the !kun vocabulary and some of the notes on the verso pages are made by !nanni.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Words and sentences: given by Tamme

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: An account of the relationship between the sun, the moon and the stars, according to the !kun. It includes a description of the growth of the moon.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The moon, the sun and the stars

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: The names of !nanni's brothers and sisters.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The names of !nanni's brothers and sisters

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: Words in the language of the 'Ongova' Bushmen given in May /79 at the Grey Library
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Words in the dialect of the !kun or so
called 'Ongova Bushmen' of Hereroland
Covers and first pages of Lloyd's Book XI & XII
3 or BC151_A2_1_111

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: Words and sentences contributed by Tamme (and occasionally by !nanni). They include many references to personal experiences. These include the people of their country, information about their relations and early childhood memories, as well as numerous names and descriptions of plants and animals (mostly in relation to food and eating). There are also many songs and the names of various !kun known by the boys. |han≠kass'o provides many |xam equivalents to various !kun words.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Words and sentences: given by Tamme

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: ≠ne≠nebbi, None
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The song of the ≠ne≠nebbi (woodpigeon)

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: The song of the sauko which is a bird with a long bill. It seems that it eats a small buck.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The song of the sauko

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: Tamme's own song about the ||noruko djo
djo (a kind of butterfly or moth) which he identifies in the south African Museum in January 1880. The song has not been translated.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The song of the ||noruko djo
djo

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: Tamme and his family have seen and understand different people in their country. Tamme understands the languages spoken by the Ovambo, the Ovaherero and the Namaqua.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Tamme's family and their understanding of the languages spoken in their country

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: The song of the mother of the little buck. The mother antelope sings and cries about the loss of its kid.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The song of the mother of the little buck

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: ≠na≠n'arro,
The song of the or chameleon.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The song of the ≠na≠n'arro

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: Ngogan-a,
The song of the which is a little bird. The first line says it has gone away but the rest has not been translated.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The song of the Ngogan
a (a little bird)

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: The names of !nanni's mother and father and his grandparents.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The names of !nanni's relations

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: !ke tsa'ba djon.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The song of the !ke tsa'ba (a bird)

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: !ku
Information about various different peoples and other groups of !kun (or ) found in !nanni and Tamme's country. There is a list of these groups of peoples and their differences and similarities.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Different peoples and Bushmen in !nanni and Tamme's country

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: The names of some of the plants and animals eaten by the !kun (and by !nanni and Tamme in particular). Mention is made of respecting certain animals and the consequences of eating them (see 9177v).
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Food eaten by the !kun

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: A song of the |kam
ssin !ku (Sun Bushmen) mourning the loss of a son.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: A song of the |kam
ssin !ku (or Sun Bushmen)

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: The song of the Pit-making Bushmen (or !korro-ssin !kuwho sing of the burning or pain in their eyes.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The song of the !korro
ssin !ku (or Pit
making Bushmen)

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: !na !na'rishe
The song of the (a large bird). It sings of the disappearance of the people from its country.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The song of the !na !na'rishe (a bird)

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: The song of the ||gani (a kind of woodpigeon).
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The song of the ||gani (a bird)

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: The names of !nanni's grandparents and information about them (whether they are living or not and what !kun
speaking group they belong to).
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: !nanni's grandparents

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: The lion's song.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The lion's song

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: Tamme's (or possibly !nanni's) aunt was killed by elephants at night. His mother told his father who killed a person. Tamme's mother cried and the father kills another person the next day.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The death of an aunt

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: Tamme's father's heart aches so his mother tells his father to sleep in ashes. His father does as she says and becomes white from the ashes.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Sleeping in ashes

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: Tamme's younger brother dies so his mother sleeps outside at the back of the house. When a child dies, another child does not eat. Another child also 'must die'. When a person dies the people bury him or her in the earth.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Customs at death

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: An account of how Tamme came to be 'dispossessed' of his people. Tamme and his mother are at the Makoba village. Tamme is persuaded to go into a Makoba's house. The Makoba refuses to allow Tamme to return to his mother and people. The Makoba eventually give Tamme to the Ovambo, who hand him over to white men (9167).
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: How Tamme was taken by the Makoba and given to the Ovambo

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: Tamme recounts some of his experiences when younger. He describes other people he has met, such as a person called |kon
ta and his family. Tamme recalls when he was small ('so high') and his mother carried him on her back. He was able to see many things from that position. He feared the water, which was cold.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Tamme's experiences before coming to Mowbray
Covers and first pages of Lloyd's Book XI & XII
4 or BC151_A2_1_112

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: The names and descriptions of some plants and animals eaten in !nanni and Tamme's country. It includes notes on whether the food is eaten raw or cooked, and what food is found in the Damara's country.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Food eaten by the !kun

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: The people of !nanni's country do not make pots. The Makoba make pots and trade them with the !kun.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Pots and trading

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: !nanni's mother fears the night, whereas Tamme's does not. !nanni's father does not fear the night. In the darkness (which 'sat') lions kill one of the Ovaherero's cattle and their oxen go away.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The darkness

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: A little elephant falls into a game pit. It does not die because the mother elephant pulls it out.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The little elephant (which fell into the game pit but did not die)

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: Words and sentences given by !nanni and Tamme, including times, the boys' 'country', and Tamme's language (his 'speech is one, not many'). Many of the !kun only speak one language.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Words and sentences: times, country and language

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: When one of the !kun dies, the other people dig a hole in the earth and place the dead person inside it. When a man dies, his bow and stick are put into his grave with him. The grave is covered up with earth. Another man takes the dead man's arrows. After the people have buried the dead person they leave for another place (or 'country'). They do this because they fear or respect death and the dead person.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Burial

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: The names of Tamme's brothers. One was still living when he left his country and another three had died.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The names of Tamme's brothers – dead and alive

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: An account of an incident involving Tamme's father in which he asked a party of men for a bow. Tamme says that his father had killed a person and was killed by 'another man'.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Tamme's father

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: !nanni's father (|umma
tchi
gua) told him what to eat and what to avoid. !nanni's father had been instructed by his father (Karu) in the same matters.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: What !nanni's father told him (what to eat and avoid)

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: !goa

A story in which an elephant father and mother dig out a pit for a little elephant near to a tree. The mother elephant puts the little elephant in the pit and fills the pit with earth. At sunset the elephant mother awakes and lifts the little elephant out of the pit. The two of them run down to the water and the mother puts the little elephant into the water.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The little elephant

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: !nanni's father wore a back
dress of genet (or sua). He also wore a back
dress of weasel (or muishond, or dda). He wore a front
dress of ||ko. When he goes away he hangs up the back
dress.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: !nanni's father's dress

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: When a person dies, the !kun (!nanni's people) do not immediately leave the place of death but leave as a group on another day. In !nanni's maternal grandfather's country, the dead go into the Moon.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Burial (another account)

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: !nanni and Tamme give the names of some plants and animals found in their country. This includes some information about them, as well as if and how they are eaten.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Words and sentences: plants and animals

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: When people are ill, some of the people 'doctor' the afflicted person and stand and make various gestures. Other people sing (and do not make gestures). Other people beat the drum. Dreams put 'a thing' into a person and makes them unwell.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Curing illness (and the trance dance)

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: About the dream (or ||gan

a) of !nanni and Tamme's country. In !nanni's country a dream put 'a thing' into a person and this makes them ill. In Tamme's country, a dream speaks to him. The dream speaks to many people who hear it. The people told Tamme that when a person dies he or she becomes a dream (or ||gan
a). The dream's heart aches when this happens and kills another person (it puts a 'thing' in them).
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The dream

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: A brief account of the making of huts, or grass houses. The people put poles into the ground after digging holes. They fix the poles firmly into the holes, putting leaves in the spaces around the poles (or sticks). They cover these over with grass and sweep the floor of their huts.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Huts

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: !nanni and Tamme give the names of some birds and bird's eggs found in their country. This includes some information about the birds as well as if and how they are eaten, and what they eat.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Birds and bird's eggs

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: !nanni and Tamme provide words and sentences including the names and descriptions of some plants and animals found in their country (mostly edible).
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Words and sentences: plants and animals

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: When the !kun hunt and kill an elephant they fear and respect its heart. One person alone cannot eat it and the hunter avoids eating it altogether. If the hunter were to eat the heart an elephant would kill him on another occasion. The heart is shared out amongst the other people. It takes five days to eat an entire heart. The people cook elephant heart in a pot.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Elephants (eating their hearts)

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: The !kun hunt elephants and then trade elephant tusks and other parts with the Makoba in exchange for food (and cattle to use as meat). A Makoba tells !nanni's people to go into 'another country' and seek and kill other large elephants to bring tusks back for him. In exchange he will give !nanni's people a small animal (a cow or calf).
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Trading with the Makoba and elephant tusks

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: Tamme (and possibly !nanni) gives words and sentences relating to many aspects of daily life in their country (mostly to do with food). Mention is also made of the name used by !nanni's and Tamme's people when speaking of the lion (its name is avoided by the !kun).
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Words and sentences: plants and animals (and avoiding the lion's name)

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: !nanni's paternal grandfather (Karu) told him to be quiet and told him the story of the Hyena (or ||gaxa) who entered the Lion's house. The Lion had forbidden the Hyena to talk like the Lion did (the Lions talked). The Lion puts food to cook on the fire (which seems to be caterpillars). The Lion wakes the Hyena and tells it to say 'Mmmm' and eat the little caterpillars, but the Hyena says '≠naa!' instead. It does not want to eat the hairy caterpillars. The Lion listens to the sounds that the Hyena makes and objects to its speech. The Lion pierces the Hyena's hindleg and it says '≠naa!' several times and then '≠e sho
sho!' as well and runs away.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The Lion's story, or, The Lion and the Hyena

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: Beating a stone upon the ground protects the people from lightning. Only women beat stones on the ground. !nanni's (?) paternal grandmother did this and said 'Fall into the water!' and the lightning (or rain) fell into the water.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Beating a stone on the ground

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: Tamme gives the names of his paternal and maternal grandparents, as well as his father's paternal grandfather. 'Tamme' appears to be a family name.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Tamme's grandparents

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: This is a story about |xue and his wives (!nanni says that he saw |xue, his house and child while !nanni was with the Herero). |xue resembles a lizard one day, a |ou (a small buck, probably a steenbok) the next, and a little tsema and a ||ha and a python (≠ni), all on different days. When |xue dies he resembles the |ou (and has horns). As |xue lies there dead his wives see him and come and pick him up and carry him to the house. The elder (or 'greater') wife makes a fire to cook the kid, and puts his body on the fire. |xue calls out, objecting to being put on the fire. The second wife takes |xue to her house and covers him with a kaross. He bites it and becomes a kid again. The second wife kills him and puts him in a cooking pot, shutting him in and covering him. He becomes an ant and bites his second wife. His wife crushes his ant's head and throws |xue down on the ground.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: |xue and his wives

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: An account of how two !kun (called |xue and ||namme) go into the house of a |nani. They sit down at the |nani's fire to warm themselves because it has been raining. A |nani child sees them and wakes his father and tells him that two !kun are warming themselves at the fire. The !kun men run away and the |nani father chases them and aims at them with his bow and arrow. The |nani throws an axe at the retreating men but misses them and |xue shoots and kills him instead.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: |xue, ||namme, and the |nani, or, The |nani

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: Tamme's father told him about |xue, as !nanni's grandfather Karu had told him. !nanni talks about |xue but Tamme does not. Tamme gives his mother's father's name.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Tamme does not tell about |xue

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: Words and sentences, including the name of |xue's second or younger wife, as well as the names for houses.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Words and sentences (including a note on |xue)
Covers and first pages of Lloyd's Book XI & XII
5 or BC151_A2_1_113

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: |xue becomes a small bird (by the name of ||kouri) and is taken hold of by his child. His child's mother warns the child to leave |xue alone, but the child refuses, saying he wants to take hold of his father. The child puts |xue down on the ground and he flies up into the sky. |xue becomes a larger bird (called !kuarra, which seems to be an eagle) and his child sings out for !kuarra to 'divide my hands'. The bird flies down and grabs the child's mother's head in its claws. She angrily curses |xue saying 'let a lion take |xue!' because she wants him to vanish. The people take hold of |xue and beat him until he dies and vanishes.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: |xue and his child

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: An account of some of the different people found in Tamme's mother's country.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Peoples of !nanni and Tamme's country

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: Words and sentences including the names of weapons and things belonging to different peoples found in !kun country (the Makoba, the Shimbari and the |nani). There are also descriptions and names of some edible plants, berries and trees.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Words and sentences: things belonging to different peoples in !nanni and Tamme's country, and plants and trees

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: The !kun call spirits (or dreams) ||gan
a. Other people in their country (namely the Makoba and the Ovaherero) call them different things when they speak of them.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: ||gan
a (spirits or dreams)

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: |xue pours water on his sleeping wife and she curses him. His wife takes a fire
stick and beats his forehead and |xue runs off to another place where he sleeps on the ground. At sunrise the wife's father looks for |xue, calling for him as he goes. |xue rises up and his father
in
law gives him food to eat. |xue goes with his father
in

law to his house where |xue's wife waits. She says that he had resembled many different things while he was gone and that she had seen him. He had been a man at sunset and a lizard at sunrise. She warns him that he will get killed by another man when he goes in this form into another country.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: |xue and his father
in
law

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: !naxane !naxane
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: |xue becomes !naxane

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: |xue becomes a buffalo. In this form he eats grass and his wife sees him. [incomplete]
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: |xue as a buffalo

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: tchaxa tchaxa tchaxa ≠nue
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: |xue as tchaxa

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: |xue becomes an ostrich and goes into a rock. He becomes an owl and dies and flies eat him. |xue's wife carries him to her house. She fetches a large pot and puts him in the pot, pours water on him and builds a great fire, intending to cook him. |xue cries because he is afraid of the fire and his wife asks if it is her husband who cries. |xue's wife breaks the pot and |xue says 'I say |xue', revealing himself. |xue's wife cries.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: |xue as ostrich and other things

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: |xue becomes a spirit and kills his child. |xue's wife goes out and when she returns to the house she sees the dead child there and accuses |xue of killing it. She takes a fire stick and burns |xue with it. |xue cries out, runs away and climbs a tree. The sun sets and rises and sets and rises again and |xue descends the tree. |xue's wife speaks to her father who goes out searching for |xue and when he finds him he slaps |xue and then carries him home. There |xue's father
in
law throws a stick at him and |xue runs away. |xue becomes a little snake and bites the father
in
law, who cries out and then dies. |xue becomes a large fly and flies away, and as he does so the father
in
law rises again. |xue becomes a butterfly and then becomes |xue the man again. When he sees his wife's father alive again carrying a big stick he runs away. [The ending is inconclusive.]
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: |xue is a spirit, and kills his child

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: !nanni and Tamme belong to different groups of !kun. Tamme is one of the Yabbi and his country was the Tsaba. !nanni was a ||no and his country was the Kaku i ra.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Bushman groups

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: !gau naxane
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: |xue and the ostriches

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: sa

The Hai-||umm resemble the !kun. They speak the same language as the Berg Damaras and also speak !kun and the !kun understand their language. The Hai-||umm's country is near that of the !kun. The !kun buy something called from them.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Hai ||umm

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: !gau
The grasshopper of !nanni's and Tamme's country (called the ) eats small grass flowers. The little grasshopper eats the blades of the grass and the large grasshopper eats the stems.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Grasshoppers

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: dui shao !naxane
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Further changes of |xue

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: At sunset |xue becomes |xue and lies on the ground and sleeps on his own. At sunrise he awakens and sees the sun and becomes ||gui (a tree). His wife sees the ||gui and picks some of its fruit. The ||gui vanishes and |xue becomes a fly instead. |xue's wife is upset about the ||gui vanishing and lies on the ground to cry. |xue in the form of the fly settles on the grass (called go o).
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: |xue as a ||gui tree and a fly

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: In this story |xue becomes an ant, a butterfly, a fly, water, a buffalo, a snake, a tsan, a ||xuonna and a bird. |xue chases his wife in a variety of forms and eventually dies. His wife picks him up and puts him inside her kaross, but drops him when he becomes a ||xuonna. She goes on into her father's country. In another part of the account (also told to !nanni by Karu) |xue also becomes !naxane, an owl, a fly, a bee, a hyena and, finally, an ant. As a bee he bites and kills his father. |xue performs a doctoring ceremony and his father rises up and chases |xue. |xue and his father fight. Eventually, |xue settles on his father's head and he dies. |xue's father takes him off his head and sets |xue down on the ground, where he becomes an ant.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: More about |xue

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: !nanni's paternal grandfather Karu tells him that the doings (or works) of |xue are numerous and not one, but many.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The doings of |xue are many
Covers and first pages of Lloyd's Book XI & XII
6 or BC151_A2_1_114

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: |xue is water, a lizard, grass, a |nu

erre bird, a dead elephant, a buffalo, a tsan, an Omuherero and a snake (a ||ge). |xue makes reeds at the water and grabs one of the woodpigeons. |xue becomes |xue and rises up and grabs the bitten woodpigeon and plucks out its feathers, putting them on his head. |xue puts the woodpigeon's body on hot embers and eats it. He hears an Ovaherero and hides. |xue flies away to his mother's country where he sees his father. |xue's mother and father become afraid of him and run away. |xue chases his father, all the while loudly speaking the Berg Damara language. |xue fears the large black reeds where his father hides. |xue sits and drinks water from a little hole and cries for his father. His father sees him, but leaves because |xue is an Omuherero. |xue searches for his father and cries when he does not find him.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: |xue, his father and changes

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: The names of |uma's and Da's parents. |uma's father's name is ||e
|kue and his mother's name is ||kabbe
!!ne
a (?). Da's father's name is |xoa
ku and his mother's is ||xauti.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: |uma and Da: the names of their parents

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: !gauka

|xue's father (|xe ||n'u) sees a bird (called ) and |xue goes to look at it and dies. His father carries him back to his mother's. At sunset |xue arises and calls out to his father. When he comes running to |xue, |xue dies and changes into a mouse. When his father sees him he takes an arrow and shoots him. |xue gets up and chases his father. |xue's mother beats his father on the head with a stick. |xue and his father fight and die and shoot at each other.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: |xue and his mother and father

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: |xue bites his father, breaking his father's finger. |xue's father goes away. |xue becomes a shana (the fruit of a small tree). The rain falls on him, and he lies down and cries when the rain is over. His father hears him and throws him over his shoulder. |xue cries very loudly so his father puts him down and he follows his father. |xue grabs a little |ou (a little buck, probably a steenbok) from some birds (!kuara). |xue's father roasts some of the meat and leaves for his own country. |xue sits at the fire and cries for his father to carry him. |xue hears his father's laughing and gets up, crying. He becomes rain and tells the rain to pour down on his father. |xue's father beats |xue and tells his wife to give |xue to another person so they can kill him. |xue hears this and cries and his father leaves. |xue follows his father and at sunrise he becomes !naxane. |xue's father puts two of the !naxane into his bag. |xue changes back to |xue and |xue's father searches for the !naxane. |xue climbs a !gua tree and refuses to come down, being afraid of being beaten. |xue's mother slaps him so that he falls from the tree. |xue becomes a lizard (gora) and then a bird (called ||kanna
tatta). [It says 'to be continued' on page 9489v, but it is not clear where the story is taken up.]
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: |xue and his father

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: !nanni recites a prayer to the young moon. The people pray to the moon so that they may find food and eat.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Prayer to the young moon

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: A (violent and lengthy) account of what happened after the death of !nanni's uncle (|un'ta), who died in the Makoba's house. Karu cries for his dead child. !nanni's father, ya ||ne, tells his father to be silent, as does Karu's wife. ya ||ne and Karu's wife beat Karu with a stick until people take hold of ya ||ne. ya ||ne and Karu threaten and attempt to kill each other a number of times and Karu threatens to kill his own wife. Karu's wife's father (||namme) beats Karu. Karu shoots his father
in
law in the head with an arrow. Karu runs away and the people chase him. Karu's wife beats him and he aims his arrow at his wife. Karu's people beat him with knobkerries.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: !nanni's uncle

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: A description of the set of wood pieces (or |xu) used by the !kun for divining. This set of pieces is said to assent 'to me about the thing'. The set consist of four pieces – two male and two female. The Makoba call the set |nu |num, although the boys say it is a 'Bushman institution'.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Pieces of wood for divining, or |xu

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: The !kun (particularly women) call the young moon `!ka !karrishe’ and blow on the horn of a male |ou (a small buck, probably a steenbok). The young moon points out food to the people (for example bees). This story includes Karu's prayer to the moon, in which he asks it for food ('Tell me of things, that I may eat!'). At sunrise the man (possibly Karu) goes out and kills a lizard that the moon has shown him. The wife cooks the lizard and fetches a dish to cut it up in. The man gives his wife the lizard's head to eat and she cries loudly. The man beats his wife and threatens to kill her. The wife does not speak to him because she is afraid.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Young moon's story
Covers and first pages of Lloyd's Book XI & XII
7 or BC151_A2_1_115

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: |xue, both his wives and his child inflict various forms of violence on each other. In the course of the story |xue becomes a number of people all at once to beat his wives and child. When he has died, |xue's father makes a grave for |xue. |xue's father and father
in
law put |xue into the grave. |xue cries out for them to leave him alone. |xue's father
in
law burns his eyes with fire and his mother beats |xue's father
in
law with a stick. The father
in

law shoots |xue's father with an arrow, killing him. |xue lies on the ground crying for his dead father. At sunset |xue's father returns to life and pursues |xue to beat him. |xue's father ties him up in a skin and carries him home. |xue's mother tries to give |xue food but his father says she must not. |xue lies silently on the ground and then shoots his father. |xue, his father and his mother continue to beat each other up. |xue goes into a mouse
hole and bites his father, breaking his 'first fore
finger'. |xue's father beats |xue as he runs into the mouse
hole, breaking off a horn that he has tied to his back. [This story should have been continued elsewhere, but appears not to have been.]
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: |xue and his parents and child

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: A few words and sentences given by !nanni and|or Tamme in January 1880.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Words and sentences

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: !naxane

Karu did not speak of |xue at night, but only in the daytime. When Karu told !nanni (during the day) about the doings of |xue, !nanni was afraid of |xue and cried. Karu put into a dish and !nanni stopped crying and sat down to eat it.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Karu on |xue

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: When a !kun man dies, his things are not given to another person. This would make the deceased's wife cry and the people afraid ('we should tremble'). There follows an account of the interaction between the dead person's child (son) and wife.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Actions after death

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: An account of what is done with the body of a deceased man and how it is dressed and arranged (by his father).
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Dress after death

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: The !kun use wooden pieces called |xu for divining future events. These pieces are made of wood from the !ke tree (also a 'food' tree). Women do not touch these pieces but men can. Little girls also respect (or 'fear') these sets of pieces. A mother tells her daughter to respect the pieces, which she does. Little boys do not fear the pieces and are allowed to handle them.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The pieces of wood used by the Bushmen of !nanni's country for divining future events
Covers and first pages of Lloyd's Book XI & XII
8 or BC151_A2_1_116

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: A few words given by Da in October 1882.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Words given by Da

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: Kai

Tamme and !nanni name and describe poisons used by the !kun, most of them taken from trees and plants. There are many poisons. The poisons are prepared (often boiled in a pot) and put onto arrows to shoot game. The people also gather caterpillars called from large trees, with which they make poison. !nanni describes one of these excursions to gather this poison by his people. His father and grandfather (Karu) were on this excursion, and Karu was injured during the outing.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Poisons and a description of gathering them

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: !naxane !naxane
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: |xue as !naxane and butterflies and with people who are afraid

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: |xue is at the top of a large palm tree and asks his wife to cut off his ears (it seems that the wind is loud and frightens him). She refuses and says that he is not her husband, because her husband is a man. She runs away from him. |xue goes searching for the woman (his wife). He cries and calls for her as he goes, and when his wife hears this she returns to him. |xue threatens to kill his wife if she runs away again so she runs off crying out in fear for her life. |xue chases after his wife and later makes an earthen house and lies there to sleep. The rain falls on |xue and then stops, and the Moon rises. |xue awakes and leaves the hut to sleep on the bare earth. [It says 'to be continued' on page 9626, but appears not to have been.]
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: |xue and a woman

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: bobo shao
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: |xue and his son

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: U'we (or |xue) creates things (including food animals). The Moon says that the people shall return again from death (and not die outright). The Moon tells the Hare that the Hare's dead son will return to life, but the Hare objects, saying that his dead son smells bad. |xue laughs at the Hare and beats him. The Moon tells |xue to leave the Hare alone, but |xue ignores the Moon. The Hare's wife beats |xue. The Moon tells the She

Hare to leave |xue alone, but she tells the Moon that she will kill |xue for beating her husband. The male Hare gets up and kills |xue, who does not die outright. The Moon kills |xue a number of times, but he does not die outright. The Moon and his wife threaten each other. The Moon's wife tells the Moon to kill |xue, but the Moon is afraid.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The Moon and the Hare and |xue
Covers and first pages of Lloyd's Book XI & XII
9 or BC151_A2_1_117

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: Tamme (and occasionally !nanni) provides Lloyd with the !kun names of animals, birds and insects at the South African Museum.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Words and sentences: names of animals given by Tamme at the museum

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: The people in Tamme's country respect the mantis (||gan
a) and do not eat it. A person who eats the mantis dies.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Respect for the mantis
Covers and first pages of Lloyd's Book XI & XII
10 or BC151_A2_1_118

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: |xue is afraid of a large bam
bam bird and becomes (or makes) a leopard (!khumm). Woodpigeons, an owl, a korubo and some ||kuorres (small mouse
like animals with cat
like eyes and tail) all laugh at the leopard. The leopard stalks a number of animals and searches for the carcass of a bam

bam bird. At sunset the leopard becomes |xue again and lies down to eat shana. He walks to the water, which is far off. He drinks all the water and shoots a young |ou (a small buck, probably a steenbok), breaking its foreleg. When |xue tries to shoot again his bow breaks. |xue goes to sleep on the bare ground and then makes a new bow from a stick.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: |xue and the bam
bam, and as other things

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: Tamme describes what wild animals are eaten by the !kun.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Animals eaten by the !kun

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: !nanni recites a verse relating what is said by the lion. In it, the lion tells the people to stop laughing at it and to respect it.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: What the lion says

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: Words and sentences provided by !nanni and|or Tamme.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Words and sentences

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: A description of the coming of the rain and the appearance of ||kum'm, or great black clouds. The rain in the boys' country affects the falling of the flowers and the behaviour of the caterpillars on the trees.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: A note on ||kum'm or rain
clouds

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: !gauru
A description of the drum (called ) made and played by the !kun.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: A drum

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: !ha
A description of the making of 'wells' (or ) in !nanni and Tamme's country. They say that the water has 'one root', which refers to the well in Mowbray.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Water and wells

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: The !kun terms for people who are intelligent (their thoughts are not absent) and foolish (their thoughts are wanting).
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Intelligent and foolish people

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: Little girls do not eat the |no, and respect it. Adult women do eat it (its head, its body and the bones).
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Respecting and eating the |no

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: An account of how women 'work', or cut themselves. Men cut (or bleed) themselves between the eyes with a knife. The blood is caught in a cup made of animal horn, held by another person.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Bloodletting

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: The !kun do not 'throw away' their old people, but keep them with them. The old people take care of the small children when the mothers are off collecting food.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Treatment of the old

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: !nanni and|or Tamme give the names of plants and animals found in their country, as well as other words and sentences from their daily life.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Words and sentences: plants and animals

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: The names and descriptions of some of the different seasons in !nanni and Tamme's country.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Names of seasons

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: !naxane

|xue pours water into his pot and carries it on a stick over his shoulder (he has attached an ox-head at the other end of the stick). He trips and wounds his knee and the pot breaks. He leaves the ox-head in the tree and departs for his mother's country with a bag of . The people hide from |xue. |xue searches for his people in vain, and turns back crying.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: More about |xue

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: Tamme explains that his people respect the eland ('with certain observances').
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Respecting the eland

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: The |nu'she (a small black bird) calls when the sun is small and has not risen (it is in the ground). When the wind blows hard the rain comes, and the wind ceases when the rain falls. While the people eat the !naxane, the tt' e (a fowl
like bird) calls. These birds also eat !naxane.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The |nu'she, the tt' e, and the wind and rain

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: When a woman's husband dies, the widow is 'taken' by the dead man's younger or next brother. In this way her children are brought up with a father ('nicely'). When this man also dies the wife lies down and sleeps alone. Her son goes away and marries and the widow has to rely on her daughter to give her food, wood and water. A man comes to take her daughter away to live as his wife in another country.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The widow married by her dead husband's next brother

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: ≠khumm
A man respects his mother-in-law's name and does not speak it. His mother-in-law addresses him as 'son-in-law'. When his mother-in-law is silent he is silent. He addresses his wife's father as his .
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: A man respects his wife's mother

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: !kun husbands kill their wives by placing a poisoned arrow (a |nu'bbo) upright in her bed. The husband tells the crying mother to stop crying, as his actions were justified. The mother
in
law says she will mourn her daughter for many days and will not listen to a 'stranger' who has killed her daughter. The husband says that he will kill his mother
in
law if she does not consent to go away.
