oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Killing a wife by means of a poisoned arrow in her bed
Covers and first pages of Lloyd's Book XI & XII
11 or BC151_A2_1_119

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: An account of the methods favoured by the !kun in dealing with theft among their people. If a woman steals and her parents are alive she is given over to them and taken away to their country. The husband returns the stolen item and beats or kills his wife. Another part of the account deals with children that steal. If an orphaned female child living with others steals, her foster family gives her to the person from whom she stole. They put her in a hut where they burn and kill her. In another part of the account a man who has stolen is shot with many arrows. Men are shot and women are burned. If a child steals the child is scolded but not killed. If that child grows up and then steals, it is killed.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The treatment of thieves

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: A story about stars and some of their doings. The star has small arms and no horns. It is a small thing. When the 'darkness sits' or night falls, the star runs off into the sky. The children pull the star from the earth and play with the star. The children take it up and then throw it away. In this way the children kill the star. When stars fall to earth they die.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Stars

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: The Goba
|nua
me ('Makoba
boils
me') bird is so called by the !kun because they believe it is crying 'The Makoba boils me'. Its appearance and habits are described.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The bird called by the !kun Goba
|nua
me

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: The |nu'she bird calls at sunrise. There is a description of its appearance and call.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The |nushe

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: Maiya Maiya Maiya
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The Maiya

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: dzana
The taps on dry trees. It frightens away other animals who think its tapping is made by people.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The Dzana

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: A short piece describing the different states of being alive, or not 'quite' not dead, or 'quickly dead'.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Terms for being alive or not quite dead

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: ≠xo gure
A description of the bird, which is eaten by the !kun (Tamme in particular).
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The ≠xo gure bird

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: A description of an edible plant called the |khoro. It grows on the ground and the root is cooked in the fire. The birds eat the fruit. Certain practices relating to phases of the moon are observed when eating this or the ≠gue

||na plant. There is a description of the two plants and where and how they grow. Their stems climb trees and are long, but the edible parts of the plants are short. Both of these plants can be harmful if eaten at the wrong time.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The |khoro and the ≠gue
||na

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: !nanni's grandfather Karu told him about Hu'
we, who is a !kun. 'Hu'
we' is what the !kun call a person who works many things, and the people also call him |xue.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Hu'
we (is |xue, and is a Bushman)

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: According to Tamme's people, |xue is Hu'
we and also the Hare (who creates things). The Hare puts the person he has made into an antelope

skin bag (there are four bags and four kinds of people, each speaking different languages). He takes one bag of people and throws it far away. He throws a bag of thread or string far away so that the people may catch and eat antelope. At sunrise |xue comes to him and says that the Hare is a mere hare and must behave like a mere hare. The Hare says he is also |xue and speaks !kun (he says this somewhat peevishly, as he seems to feel that he has been doing so all along). |xue tells the Hare to put food into a bag for the people, but the Hare refuses to feed them, saying |xue must do so with his own food. |xue throws bags with food and with a bow and arrows to the !kun's country and tells them to shoot the Hare.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The Hare, |xue, the Antelope and the Bushman: a creation legend

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: An account of the procedure followed when a man kills another man. The man who has shot another does not eat or drink water for two days (he has 'done without two things'). On the third day he performs a cleansing ritual, which is described in detail.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Purification after shooting a person

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: The man who is cleansing himself (after shooting and killing another man) takes |kui fruit in his hands and speaks, saying that his heart must be calm and does not burn. The father
in
law says words that are intended for the relations of the man who has been killed.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: What the man says while cleansing himself

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: The man who is cleansing himself (performing a purification ritual, or |koa) puts some |u' ||ke (from the |u' ||ke' plant) into the |kui food he has cooked on the fire. He scrapes a little into the food. After eating it he lies down. The |u' ||ke' plant intoxicates people.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: |u' ||ke' in food

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: The |u' ||ke'. or Tshaka, is a small plant and is used as part of the purification ritual, or |koa. It intoxicates and can kill people if handled incorrectly (at the wrong time of day), and is thus feared. The ≠nabbi does not kill people and is given when the people 'seek their hearts'. Both plants seem to be effective at specific times of day.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The |u' ||ke' or Tshaka

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: During purification (or |koa) the man being cleansed is prepared for drinking water. His father squirts water over him (on his chest and back) from his own mouth. The man being cleansed then drinks water given to him by his father. The man drinks water, but does not eat (the man is allowed to eat 'water food', or water plants, or tcha, if there are some there, and if the appropriate preparatory ceremonies have taken place, given by his father or another 'proper' person). The man must abstain from food for two days but does not abstain after he has been cleansed.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The manner in which a man who is being cleansed, is prepared for drinking water

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: A description of further aspects of the purification or cleansing ritual (|koa). The father (of the man who has killed another) blows smoke onto his son's back and chest and then gives him some to smoke. He warns his son not to smoke Indian Hemp until he has been cleansed.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Further particulars regarding the purification or cleansing (|koa)
Covers and first pages of Lloyd's Book XI & XII
12 or BC151_A2_1_120

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: The |||hin is a snake found in !nanni's country which announces death if it lies on its back. If the snake turns over when struck, the people immediately leave it alone and return home. If the snake does not roll over when struck, the people kill and skin it and trade the skin with the Makoba. The snake appears when a person has died and the news has not yet reached other people.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: A certain snake, which, by lying upon its back, announces a death in the family; and must not, in these circumstances, be killed

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: The people of !nanni's country do not kill the snake that is found near a grave, because the snake is the dead person's snake and it is the spirit of the dead. Similarly the people do not kill other animals (such as antelope and lizards) which are found near graves. They are considered to be spirit
animals or spirits of the dead.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: A snake found near a grave

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: People become spirits when they die. A dead man has a mere spirit as well as an other which is a snake. Spirit

animals live near graves. If a man dies he becomes a snake. Men also become snakes when bitten by them ('and his snake is a spirit'). If a woman dies she becomes a mere spirit unless she dies of a snakebite in which case she becomes a snake. Mere spirits go away.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Snakes and spirits of the dead

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: Tamme provides a short account concerning a Makoba who goes to his country when it rains. The Makoba say they see a rainbow and the rain falls.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The Makoba

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: !nanni and Tamme give the !kun equivalents of some questions.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Words and sentences: some questions
Covers and first pages of Lloyd's Book XI
1 or BC151_A2_1_121

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: !nanni concludes the legend of the Hare and the Moon in which the Hare has told the Moon that the people and others must really die.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: End of Moon and Hare story

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: The Moon instructs the Sun to go to a certain place. The Moon says that he is the Moon and that he and the Sun do not listen to the Hare. The Hare is torn between laughter at the Moon's beauty and tears for those who die outright. The Hare and his wife quarrel and the Moon becomes heartsore and vanishes, making the night very dark. The She
Hare calls her husband who steals up to her in the form of a jackal and catches her. The Moon seizes the Hare and rips off his jackal
skin, which he gives to the jackal. The Hare insists that he is a jackal. [It says 'to be continued' at the bottom of page 10117 but it is not clear where this occurs.]
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Moon and Sun and Hares

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: |kui
A note referring to !nanni's drawing of the fruit, which describes how it is eaten and prepared when ripe and unripe.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: !nanni's drawing of the |kui
Covers and first pages of Lloyd's Book XIII & XIV
1 or BC151_A2_1_122

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: |uma provides words and sentences at Mowbray in May 1880. These include parts of the body, some biographical information, things eaten in his country and the names and some descriptions of various plants.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Words and sentences: |uma at Mowbray, May 1880

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: |uma and Da provide words and sentences at Mowbray. These mostly include terms from everyday life, such as objects of use and parts of the body.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Words and sentences: |uma and Da at Mowbray

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: |uma relates his personal experiences and his capture by the Makoba. The account includes his meeting with Da, and describes the travels of the two boys with a series of 'masters' and their journey to the Cape.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: |uma: his capture by the Makoba and his Boer masters

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: |uma tells of his experiences with a ghost (or ||gaun
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The ||gaun
a. The Ghost

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: When one of the !kun dies, the people dig a grave and put the dead person into it. The body is covered in earth and the grave is filled in. A tree is cut down and laid over the grave. |uma relates the death of one of his relatives who was killed by an arrow. His people put the relative into the earth and the women cried for him. If a stranger is killed they do not bury him. The account includes mention of how tobacco is shared with a stranger. If the man returns with none to share he is killed.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Burial; also avenging a death

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: Words and sentences provided by Da in May 1880 (and added to in October 1881). The other boys have also added various explanations, corrections and notes which Lloyd has noted on the verso pages and throughout some of the text. Da has provided the names of parts of the body, details of practices and objects he encountered in his daily life, and the odd detail relating to his experiences (and capture) and his parents and relations (before he was taken away from them). Da also gives the names for parts and markings of arrows and their uses, as well as the names of other implements and weapons used by his people. Da also mentions some of the other peoples found in his country (such as the Makoba and the Damara) and some of his people's experiences with them.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Words and sentences: Da, May 1880

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: Da describes his capture by the Makoba and the deaths of his parents and other members of his family. The Makoba came and took Da in his country. The Makoba put the children into the water where it seems they were eaten by alligators (crocodiles). Da escaped this fate and was not put in the water.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Da: his capture and the death of his parents
Covers and first pages of Lloyd's Book XV
1 or BC151_A2_1_123

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: Lloyd takes down information and personal details from four prisoners at the Breakwater Convict Station on 17 April 1880. The four men were |nu'xa (or Hans), Mkuan (or |kabbeten, his |xam name), Mosunyan, and Molef. The information noted includes their prisoner numbers, the names of their relations, some measurements, and personal details about the men.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: At Breakwater, 17 April 1880

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: The prisoner Mkuan provides Lloyd with words and sentences at the Breakwater Convict Station in April 1880, including details of his personal history. He also provides the names for parts of the body, plants and animals, and other objects and elements from daily life.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Words and sentences: Mkuan at the Breakwater

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: Mkuan gives the names of some of his relations, namely his paternal grandfather and two of his children.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The |xam names of some of Mkuan's relations
Covers and first pages of Lloyd's Book XVI
1 or BC151_A2_1_124

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: !nauxa (or Willem) is accompanied by his !Ora, or Hottentot, companion, !khannumup (or Petros Willems). He tells Lloyd his mother's and father's names, the name of his people ('Grass Bushmen', or |nu'sa'), the names of some mountains near his country, and other personal details. The two men were photographed by Hermann, apparently on the same day of the interview, at the South African Museum.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: !nauxa (or Willem) at the Museum, 24 September 1880

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: !nauxa and !khannumup (at the South African Museum) give words and sentences in |xam (on the recto pages) and in !Ora ('Hottentot') on the opposite pages. These are largely the names of plants and animals and some descriptions of their habits or appearance.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Words and sentences: at the Museum, 24 September 1880 (!nauxa and !khannumup)

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: Lloyd notes some personal information about !khannumup (or Petros Willems) including the names of his relations, his place of origin and his wrongful imprisonment.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: !khannumup (or Petros Willems): his personal history

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: Lloyd copies a memo from Mr A. Martin in which he has noted !nauxa and !khannumup's measurements, and other details of their personal information and history.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Memo for Miss Lloyd' (regarding some personal details of 'Petros Willems' and 'Willem') (a copy)
Covers of Lloyd's unnumbered book BC151_A2_2_004

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: A small red notebook containing lists of words and sentences and notes on the |xam language.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Notes on |xam
Covers and other pages of Lloyd's unnumbered book BC151_A2_2_005

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: A small blue notebook (dated 1913) in which Lloyd lists words and sentences which she took down in Book II

23 (||kabbo) that needed translation. It contains notes to herself and explanations relating to the translation of the terms. There are exact references to lines and pages in the notebook where the terms appear.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Some Bushman words to be translated (L.C. Lloyd, June, 1913)
Covers and first pages of Lloyd's Kora Hottentot Book I
1 or MP1

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: Griet gives words in her language to Lloyd in Mowbray, mostly concerning parts of the body and animals.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Words and sentences: given by Griet

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: Piet Lynx gives words in his language to Lucy Lloyd in Mowbray, often providing plural and singular declensions. There are sometimes additional columns on the opposite pages, most notably when vocabulary is supplied by Sila, |han≠kass'o and Piet Lynx.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Words and sentences: given by Piet Lynx

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: The moon said that men should die as it dies. The hare disagreed so the moon struck the hare and split its mouth.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The moon and the hare

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: The hare, angry with the moon for wanting men to die as it dies, said that the moon must 'become the Boschvark's shoulder blade bone' and go into the sky 'and make the world light'.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The hare and the moon

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: A Koranna makes a fire which attracts cattle. He asks the Bushman if he wants the thing that shines or the blackness. The Bushman says 'what shines is mine' and the Koranna says 'mine is the blackness'. When day breaks that which shone is gone and the Bushman appears to leave as if upset ('as if thou wert vexed with me'). This is why the Koranna possess cattle and the Bushmen go without cattle.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: [The Koranna posssess cattle and the Bushmen do not]

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: Piet Lynx gives words in his language to Lucy Lloyd. The words cover topography, animals, people, kinds of lizards and more.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Words and sentences: given by Piet Lynx

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: A fragmented and partly translated story about hunting, quaggas and the slicing of flesh. Two lions jump upon the original hunters and carry off the flesh. There is a significant break in translation and then "Korhaan Malkop" is talking about carrying a child to fetch water. Eventually two women leave the child with a man and fetch water by themselves, and are berated for doing so. A woman goes back and is killed and eaten. The korhaan and the lions feature again.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: [Story about lions and korhaan malkop]

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: Declensions of various nouns (animals) and pronouns, mostly to do with people and animals.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Words and sentences: given by Piet Lynx

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: Declensions of various nouns (animals)
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Words and sentences: given by Piet Lynx

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: Declensions of various nouns (animals, anatomy, family)
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Words and sentences: given by Piet Lynx

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: Declensions of various nouns (animals)
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Words and sentences: given by Piet Lynx

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: Declensions of various nouns (body parts and animals) and verbs.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Words and sentences: given by Piet Lynx

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: Very little of this story has been translated. 'the living things which move about in the world. all came out of one hole': Kafirs, Englishmen, !koranna, Boers, Bastards, Orlams, Bushmen all 'passed out' (through the hole, presumably). The rest is harder to piece together.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: All came out of one hole
Covers and first pages of Lloyd's Kora Hottentot Book I
2 or MP2

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: Not translated.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: [Not translated]

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: Words and sentences about animals, family members, body parts and plants given by Piet Lynx (some at the Museum in Cape Town), with some additional information from !nanni and Tamme.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Words and sentences: given by Piet Lynx
Covers and first pages of Lloyd's Kora Hottentot Book I
3 or MP3

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: A story mostly translated by Louis Maingard about cleverness and the use of it to make a living.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: [Making a living through cleverness]

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: About four rivers in a cave.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Four rivers

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: Declensions of the verb 'have'.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Words and sentences: given by Piet Lynx

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: Porcupine worked in the clay while Jackal lay on his back playing the goura. When Porcupine had finished working Jackal covered himself in clay 'like one who had worked'. One day Porcupine told the Master who saw Jackal lying on his back. Jackal then said to Porcupine that the master would kill them and that Porcupine must pull out quills so that they might pierce their eyes and jump into the water and die. Porcupine drew out quills and pierced his eyes, while Jackal only put the quills into the corners of his eyes. Then Jackal threw a stone into the water, pretending it was he, and Porcupine jumped in too, and then asked Jackal to help him out. Jackal went to the Master for help and when they got back Porcupine was dead. The master was angry and tried to catch Jackal, but fell into the water and drowned and Jackal became the master. The children of the master grew up and the young master chased Jackal away, so that he lived in the veldt. Jackal and leopard met while leopard was catching fish. Jackal said that Leopard must go into the water and Jackal took the fish that Leopard had caught. Leopard followed his spoor and waited at his home, so Jackal slept in the veldt. Jackal asked why his house did not answer and so it answered "he", and then Jackal asked whether Leopard thought that he was stupid, and went away. He met a lion and said to him that the lion must hold the cliff up while he went to fetch a stick to prop it up. He went away. The leopard came upon the lion while looking for Jackal and said to Lion that the cliff will not fall. The lion pushed at the cliff and fell on his back.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The Jackal and the Porcupine
Covers and first pages of Lloyd's Kora Hottentot Book I & III
1 or MP4

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: Words and sentences given by Griet, Piet and Jantje to Isabella Lloyd.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Words and sentences

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: Thirty pages of interviews collected by Jemima Bleek in late 1879 with !nanni (XI) and Tamme (XII). The notebook contains mostly vocabulary, largely relating to animals.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Jemima Bleek's interviews with !nanni and Tamme, September to November 1879

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: Thirty pages of interviews collected by Jemima Bleek in 1879 with a three 'Hottentot' informants (I, II and III), members of a family ('Lynx') sent to the house in Mowbray in error. The vocabulary mostly concerns parts of the human body, features of the landscape and daily life, and names of animals, and there are some sentences and phrases (most of which were given by 'Piet') concerning times of the day and daily life. There are also snippets of personal history and many examples of communication in Dutch in the course of the interviews.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Jemima Bleek's 'Hottentot' interviews, 1879

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: Notebook on language (words and sentences) of Langeberg Bushmen, met by DB on Mount Temple farm. Some personal details relating to contributors. Most of the words and sentences taken in the book have been written on the numbered right hand pages, with notes & explanations & vocab on the facing verso pages. At the back of the book is a 'Visitors List', dated 1908, with names and addresses written in 2 columns (10pp).
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Dorothea Bleek
Book BC151_A3_001

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: Notebook on language (words and sentences) of Langeberg Bushmen. Some personal details relating to contributors (the Bushmen she met on Mount Temple farm) including names and some genealogical details. Some pages loose. Mostly sentences.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Dorothea Bleek
Book BC151_A3_002

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: Notebook, preliminary pages unumbered in German script. Words and sentences. Much personal history.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Dorothea Bleek
Book BC151_A3_003

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: Notebook. Includes some words and sentences. Mostly personal history (genealogies, and places of of contributors and their relations). Customs, especially burial practises. A segment of a diary of DB. Contributions taken from conversations with people at Stuurman's pits, Eyerdoppan etc.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Dorothea Bleek
Book BC151_A3_004

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: Notebook. Mostly words and sentences. Some personal history (some genealogies). Contributors at same location [?].
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Dorothea Bleek
Book BC151_A3_005

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: Diary. A5 size. DB's journey to Kakia, Bechuanaland. Lots of blank pages. Not paginated by DB but has been paginated by library [1]

[165]. Features comments on journey, settlements, weather, rivers etc, peoples spotted (Masarwa, Bakalaharies etc), the odd little sketch, dictionary work done, photos taken, trading (buying & selling), people measured, artefacts purchased. Report on Lake Chrissie Bushmen.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Dorothea Bleek
Book BC151_A3_006

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: Notebook. Mostly words and sentences, some personal information. Bechuanaland.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Dorothea Bleek
Book BC151_A3_007

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: Notebook. Notes and words, Masarwa.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Dorothea Bleek
Book BC151_A3_008

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: Notebook. Words and sentences and geneaologies, personal history. Bechuanaland.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Dorothea Bleek
Book BC151_A3_009

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: Reporters' Note Book. Naron language notebook. Words and sentences, some personal history. Reference made to recordings made by DB. Some information regarding customs and daily life.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Dorothea Bleek
Book BC151_A3_010

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: Reporters' Note Book. Naron language notebook. Short narratives concerning daily life and rituals
especially menstruation, marriage, birth, healing, rain, treatment of bones and hunting; some words and sentences. Photographs mentioned.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Dorothea Bleek
Book BC151_A3_011

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: Naron & !kun notebook, Vol. I. Words and sentences. Some descriptions of daily life including names and uses of artefacts and relations with others; personal histories.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Dorothea Bleek
Book BC151_A3_012

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: A manuscript book. !kun or Auen and Naron notebook, volume II. Words and sentences, lots of history of the region (leaders, borders, wars), odd bits of personal history, some local description. Comparisons of daily life and ritual between Naron and !kun, and other groups. Brief narratives describing daily life and ritual eg marriage, living arrangements, artefacts, death.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Dorothea Bleek
Book BC151_A3_013

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: A manuscript book. Auen and Naron notebook, volume III. Words and sentences, mostly the latter.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Dorothea Bleek
Book BC151_A3_014

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: A manuscript book. Auen and Naron notebook, volume IV. Words and sentences, mostly the latter. Some interesting descriptions and notes on relations with others, customs and names for things, mention of history of the peoples of the region, cultural practice, markings on the body, birth, death, and so on.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Dorothea Bleek
Book BC151_A3_015

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: Naron & Auen notebook, Volume IV. Much personal history and of the inhabitants of the area. Considerable detail as to practises and rituals, especially songs and dances and work hunting and looking for veldkos. There are also detailed descriptions of healing rituals, sorcery or doctoring, beliefs about and prayers to the moon, and about ghosts (or ||gauwa). Recordings (‘ediphones’) are mentioned. Much about artefacts made and daily life especially the finding and pursuing of food, making poisons and medicines and what is done with skins.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Dorothea Bleek
Book BC151_A3_016

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: Naron notebook (volume V) Detailed description of dances, ghosts and spirits, burial of the dead, sorcery and magic arrows, addressing the rain, and related practices. Much personal and local history, names and details about the past and what the old people used to teach. References to recordings. Descriptions of hunting and cooking, arrow

making, cutting and healing, trading, smoking and eating, male and female practises, songs & different types of dances. Mention of creatures/beings/spirits and gives their names and beliefs related to them (||gauwa, |gone, !xuba, Hisesha).
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Dorothea Bleek
Book BC151_A3_017

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: Naron notebook (volume VII). Descriptions of daily life, contemporary life and personal history. Much about sorcery (doctors and old people), healing, cutting practises, games (eg the 'war game'), dancing and magic animals (such as baboons and lions); artefacts and dress, food hunted and eaten, relations with inhabitants of the region; marriage, birth, name
giving and other family life; and naming stars and asking stars for food, as well as rain and related animals such as the mantis. References to the coming of Christianity and associated beliefs.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Dorothea Bleek
Book BC151_A3_018

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: Auen notebook, volume VIII. Much description of daily life, current life and personl history, including relations with others and the inhabitants of the area/settlement. There are interesting descriptions of dancing, sorcery, healing and magic animals, as well as practises relating to death and marriage and family life. There is much given relating to hunting, cooking, eating and finding food, as well as the coming of Christianity to the people and associated beliefs. There are also many names and descriptions of artefacts such as weapons, instruments and ornaments and dress.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Dorothea Bleek
Book BC151_A3_019

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: Naron notebook, Vol. IX? (with Auen contributions too). Fairly fragmented accounts of contemporary life, history and building of the settlement, and personal history; much daily life, including illness, names of plants and animals, rain and seasons and food, fire, habits of animals, and burial practises and family life. Some interesting descriptions of using buchu to say 'goodbye' to the dead. Mostly in the form of words and sentences with some scattered narrative.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Dorothea Bleek
Book BC151_A3_020

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: Notes made in Angola[?], 1925. Originally a visitor's book (pre
1918) and includes signatures of numerous well

known people (first 64 pages). A scrap of paper written by the library says !O !kun. Words and sentences and brief genealogies with names of people and their relations. Brief references to daily life of the people interviewed. Some of the clicks are different, for example what resembles an elongated 'S' [what I have as ς].
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Dorothea Bleek
Book BC151_A3_021

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: Notes made in Angola, 1925. 5 inserts and maps. A dense notebook containing words and sentences with large amount of personal history, names of relations, descriptions of ways of life of Bushmen and others, history of the region and its inhabitants, and things from daily life, includes mention of illness, a lot about spirits, death, sorcery and burial practises. A library note in the notebook says 'Angolan !kung'.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Dorothea Bleek
Book BC151_A3_022

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: Notes made in Angola 1925. Words and sentences and personal history and history of the inhabitants of the area, and descriptions of objects and actions from daily life, as well as fragments relating to markings, and songs and dances. Most of the book is blank p.205
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Dorothea Bleek
Book BC151_A3_023

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: Notes on rock paintings in caves in the Orange Free State c.1928, including comments on condition of the paintings, location of the caves and comparision between Stow's copies and originals. Also some fragments of stories and some words.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Dorothea Bleek
Book BC151_A3_024

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: Notes on rock paintings in caves in the Orange Free State c.1928, including comments on the condition of the paintings, the location of the caves and comparisions between Stow's copies and originals, as well as notes as to paintings to be copied in the future.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Dorothea Bleek
Book BC151_A3_025

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: Notes on rock paintings copied by Stow, and revisited by DB, mainly in the Eastern Cape near Queenstown. Notes about other paintings discovered as well as the farms they are found on and who to ask for directions. No pagination. Reference to 'Films' or photographs taken [?].
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Dorothea Bleek
Book BC151_A3_026

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: Record of D Bleek's visit to the Hadza of Tanganyika, 1930. Words and sentences with very fragmented narratives towards the latter half of the book. Also some names and descriptions of personal history and of the region, and comments about things that Bushmen do (such as taking a wife, and burial) and eat, especially according to the seasons; some fragments of what seem to be myths. Loose inserts, words and maps.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Dorothea Bleek
Book BC151_A3_027

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: Record of D Bleek's visit to the Hadza of Tanganyika, 1930. Words and sentences and fragmented narratives towards the latter half of the book. Also many descriptions of personal history and rough genealogical diagrams, and comments about things that Bushmen do and eat, especially cutting and tattooing by doctors when people are ill.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Dorothea Bleek
Book BC151_A3_028

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: Notes on |auni, Vol.1, made at Frankenwald Research Station, Witwatersrand University. Words and sentences and much personal history. Also some fragmented information about artefacts, ornaments and daily life, markings (cuts made for hunting and the cutting of girls for example).
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Dorothea Bleek
Book BC151_A3_029

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: Notes on |auni Vol.2, made at Frankenwald Research Station, Witwatersrand University (presumably, it doesn't say so in the notebook). Words and sentences and personal history, including some rough genealogies. Also some fragmented information relating to daily life including hunting, taking a wife, making huts, 'curing', and artefacts, as well as the 'retirement' of menstruating girls in huts. The final unnumbered pages of the notebook have been left blank.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Dorothea Bleek
Book BC151_A3_030

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: A dictionary, A

Z. Language unknown, but likely to be Mbunela, as there is a reference to the Mbunela language in the notebook. The notebook also contains grammar in same language: pronouns, alphabet, tenses, prefixes and verbs, 'Capula' [?], pronouns, numerals, demonstratives, adjectives. Most of the pages in the second half of the notebook are blank, except for the odd note, address and bit of language (others) recorded, drawing of river and part of an intinerary, objects and 'Miss Wilman', as well as some names of people 2 pages from the back.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Dorothea Bleek
Book BC151_A3_031

oai_dc:dc.dc:descriptions: Bushman genealogies, undated. Some brief descriptions and personal histories, such as where individuals worked, came from, who they married, how many children they had and so on. Information about different groups such as the 'Vaalpens'. Names of people according to huts they occupy (10 of them), also some numbers next to their names.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Dorothea Bleek
Book BC151_A3_032
